PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of standing order 48A, as amended by sessional order, be suspended as would prevent (a) Mr Speaker proposing the question That the House do now adjourn at 10.15 p.m.; (b) Mr Speaker interrupting the debate at 11 p.m., and (c) a Minister requiring that the debate be extended until 11.10 p.m., on each Wednesday, for the remainder of this period of sitting.

This will allow the Parliament to take up the time that we would normally have set aside on Wednesday evenings over the next three weeks. It merely gives the Parliament another four and a half hours sitting time. I know that members opposite are very excited about the opportunity to spend a bit more time in Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Worst Leader of the House we have ever seen.

—The honourable member will have to work a lot harder to get rid of me. I will be sitting here for a long time. This is the most preferable of all the options that are available when the Parliament is looking for additional time to sit to cover the business we have before us over the next three weeks. I tried to indicate to the Manager of Opposition Business, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the amount of legislation that would be coming before us in this three-week period. It is the intention of the Government that that legislation should pass. This merely requires that the Parliament sit on each of the Wednesday nights that are available to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the House (Mr Young) is long on his instincts for survival but not too long on his judgment. Be that as it may, I think the fact that we will now be required to sit on Wednesday nights is another one of the illustrations of the absolutely ridiculous character of this present four-day sitting pattern. I know there are others who agree with me on this subject. The Government of course does have a legislative crunch at the end of this session. We know that the Government is having inordinate difficulties in trying to draft its tax package. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has gone out with a fanciful description of his objectives in what he sees as his fifth attempt at tax change-
—I am not having as much trouble as your party room.

—Do not rely too much on the media reports, my friend. I think some of the media reports of his caucus meetings might make even more interesting reading. The problems that there are in the Government interpreting its tax package into legislative form are known to us all. We need to understand that the purpose of this motion is really nothing to do with the reasons the Leader of the House has just advanced; it is just that the Government has not been able to get its act together. When the tax package was presented we were told that we were going to know all about the details of those tax changes before the end of this year. What has happened? We now know that most of those Bills detailing the tax changes will be introduced some time in 1986, perhaps in March, perhaps in April. They will be there some time before the end of this financial year. That, frankly, is no consolation to those who seek to take investment decisions and who necessarily are working in a very difficult market place. With the balance of payments figures yesterday declining and with interest rates soaring, there is an enormous problem for business in trying to determine where it will go.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for this motion is significantly that the Government has not been able to get its act together. It is trying to get up and away from this place as soon as possible. The reason for the motion is that the Government, instead of sitting for the fourth sitting week as we were told we would be required to do in order to get the legislation through, wants the Parliament to rise so that it can get away from this place. One can well understand that, having seen the average of its performance. One can understand why it does not want to be around for very long if it can help it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just noticed how tired you get.

—I can understand the Minister getting so tired. He always looks tired. I am worried about his well-being. But I am even more worried about the well-being of the people of this country with the sorts of policies that this Government pursues. However, if there are to be changes, sitting on a Wednesday night makes far more sense than some of the other proposals that the Government has come forward with. In those circumstances the Opposition will not oppose this change. However, I put it to the Leader of the House that, with perhaps a little more expedition in consideration of the legislation that should be before us, we would be prepared to sit for an additional week so that the people of Australia can know finally what the Government will do with tax reform, if that is what the Government calls it, or, as we see it, tax regression.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that the people of Australia can go on much longer with the sorts of economic management that the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) has provided for us, certainly with the indecision, imprecision, rising interest rates and all the other ills that seem to be characteristic of the form and manner of this Government. The Opposition will not oppose this motion but I trust that, when the legislation on tax reform finally comes before us, we will have adequate opportunity to debate it, even though that will be well into next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to answer a couple of points raised by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). Firstly, I think we have sufficient time to pass the legislation in the three weeks. I do not think it requires the fourth week. As I suggested to him, if more legislation had been drafted, the fourth week may have been required. It is important that we notify all honourable members that we will not be sitting the fourth week because a number of them from both sides of the House have raised with me the matter of invitations to which they need to reply, particularly in response to schools.
—You are not sitting a fourth week because the dollar is falling. You don't want to know about the dollar.

—The honourable member for Boothby may not be interested. He will probably be going door knocking in Boothby to try to help poor old John Olsen, who will certainly need some help. But a number of honourable members have raised with me the necessity to be able to reply to those invitations. It is for that reason, amongst others, that I have notified the Parliament that we will not sit the fourth week.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 12 November.
Consideration of Senate's amendments.
Senate's amendments-
No. 1-Page 5, after sub-clause 3(10), insert the following new sub-clause:
``(10A) Notwithstanding sub-section (10), a prescribed fee shall not exceed $100.''.
No. 2-Pages 20 and 21, sub-clause 27(1), line 36 (page 20) to line 3 (page 21), leave out the sub-clause, insert the following new sub-clause:
``(1) Subject to this Act, where a court, on application made to it by a Licensing Authority for an order under paragraph (d), is satisfied that-

(a) a person has, after the commencement of this section, on one or more occasions, contravened, attempted to contravene, or been involved in a contravention of, one or more relevant safety provisions; and
(b) it is in the interests of public safety to do so,
the court may-
(c) except where the person has been admonished under this paragraph on 2 occasions in the period of 10 years ending on the day on which the application was made-admonish the person; or
(d) make an order disqualifying the person, either permanently or for a specified period, from participating in long distance interstate transport business.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Government has already indicated that it is prepared to accept the two amendments moved in the Senate to the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985. As a result of a number of concerns that have been expressed, we have accepted an amendment which would limit to $100 the maximum fee chargeable by the State in administering that legislation. We also accept that it would provide for a reasonable graduation of penalties in the operator licensing area and for a court to issue up to two admonishments or warnings in every 10 years as an alternative to removing an operator's licence for a specified period. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will oppose the amendments. We will not divide on them; we will oppose them on the voices. We will do so consistent with, first of all, the attitude we adopted in the Senate to these amendments and, secondly, our whole approach to the Interstate Road Transport Bill. When we looked at the legislation, we did so in a positive and constructive way because in general terms the legislation is valuable.

SPEECH.PARA: It provides a framework whereby the States can introduce some necessary reforms and forms of assistance for the interstate road transport industry. When we looked at the legislation we believed that it was going through in an unnecessary forced or quick way. First of all, for the legislation to be effective, each of the States is required to provide complementary legislation. None of the States appears to be in any hurry to introduce that legislation.

Evidence that we have had since indicates that our view has been confirmed-that the earliest starting date for the legislation is 1 July next year and that there is a need to consult more with the industry because of the vagueness of much of the legislation, the reliance on regulations and the uncertainty that this has created in much of the industry. That in itself was one of the reasons for our amendment proposing that the legislation be withdrawn and re-presented in six months so that it could be drafted in a more complete and acceptable way and, by then, the report of the Inter-State Commission, which is investigating the comparative cost recovery of rail and road interstate freight costs, would also be available. This is a very important aspect of the interstate registration fee which is the subject of one of these two amendments.

I am referring to the amendments in the sense that one of the two deals with the question of the $1,400 maximum fee. I note that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) made it known during the Senate debate on this legislation that that fee would remain until the end of next year-December 1986-that one of the amendments puts in legislative form the fact that it is that figure and, therefore, that legislation rather than regulation is required for its alteration. As that was a part of our in-principle complaint over the legislation, obviously it is an improvement; and that is acknowledged. The point still remains that, whether by regulation or legislation, a Senate majority will still pass whatever that fee will be.

We looked at a number of amendments proposed in the Senate when it was obvious that the Australian Democrats would not accept our overall amendment which I believe was in the best interests of the industry, and we decided that it was pointless to propose one or two amendments. When we reached a total of 30 amendments to bring the legislation up to the standard that we considered necessary, we decided that that was not our role or within our ability as an Opposition and that really it was the responsibility of the Government. It is an indictment of the Government for its failure to properly draft its legislation. We opposed those amendments because we said: Why pick out those two when there were 30 that could be proposed? We opposed those amendments then and we oppose them now.

In conclusion, just to confirm the point that I and others have made-why should we be in such a hurry when the States, who are supposed to be the beneficiaries of this legislation, are not more anxious to get on with the job of introducing legislation-I wish to refer to a question on notice in the Western Australian Legislative Council. I think my colleague the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who will speak in this debate, will also make reference to this. That question on notice was addressed to the Minister for Employment and Training representing the Minister for Transport in the Western Australian Parliament. The question basically was: When will the Western Australian complementary legislation be introduced? The answer to this question was given only since 24 October; in other words, in the last couple of weeks. The answer was:
Details and timing of possible future State legislation have yet to be determined.

That really indicates the sense of urgency that people in Western Australia have regarding this legislation. One other matter of concern in the reply refers to the operators licensing provisions in the legislation. The Minister stated:
This matter has yet to be fully discussed in a Commonwealth-State forum.

I think that is further evidence of the fact that part of the legislation was really flying too much ahead of getting the consultation that we believe is necessary so that in turn the properly drafted detail would be able to be included in the legislation.

The Opposition opposes the two amendments for the reasons given. We believe still that the legislation should be totally withdrawn for six months and redrafted. There should be further consultation with the industry and the States and when the legislation is introduced it should be more specific. That will still be adequate for the proposed starting time of 1 July next year. By then we will have some indication of how genuine the States are about this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments do practically nothing to assist the trucking industry. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) stated in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The fast-track package endorsed by ATAC involved the following initiatives-

He then listed a number of initiatives. As has just been stated by the shadow Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), on 24 October 1985 the Hon. N. F. Moore asked the Minister for Employment and Training representing the Minister for Transport question on notice No. 297 in the Western Australian Parliament. He asked:

(1) I refer the Minister to the `Interstate Road Transport Bill, 1985' currently before the Senate and ask whether or not it is necessary for the State Parliament to pass complementary legislation for this Federal Bill to be implemented?
(2) If it is necessary, when is it expected that this legislation will be introduced?
The Minister in Western Australia made it very clear that on a number of matters agreement has not been reached and, in fact, has not even been discussed. He stated:

The second part of the Federal legislative package is intended to be proclaimed later. It provides for the licensing of interstate transport operators. For the intent of this to be effective, corresponding State legislation would be needed. This matter has yet to be fully discussed in a Commonwealth/State forum. The aim is to enable those who operate in a manner which compromises public safety, as determined by the Courts, to be disqualified.
Details and timing of possible future State legislation have yet to be determined.

Yet we have the Minister for Transport keeping the heat on this subject and agreeing to something that has been put up by the Australian Democrats as a token example. Under the new agreement the Democrats have with the Government everything the Government puts to them now is to be agreed to by the Democrats. They have sold out on tax and they have sold out the small business truck operator. This is tokenism.

Let us look at the amendment which takes people's livelihoods away from them. I am talking now of the amendment to sub-clause 27 (1), line 36 on page 20 to line 3 on page 21. What a big deal! It states:
Subject to this Act, where a court, on application made to it by a Licensing Authority for an order under paragraph (d) is satisfied that-

(a) a person has, after the commencement of this section, on one or more occasions, contravened, attempted to contravene, or been involved in a contravention of, one or more relevant safety provisions; and
(b) it is in the interests of public safety to do so, the court may-
I emphasise the word `may'; it is not `the court shall'. It continues:
(c) except where the person has been admonished under this paragraph on 2 occasions in the period of 10 years ending on the day on which the application was made-admonish the person; or
(d) make an order disqualifying the person, either permanently or for a specified period, from participating in long distance interstate transport business.

What has changed? The court now has the right to say: `I admonish you'. Previously the court had the right to do nothing. The Government has only imposed another sanction on truck drivers. This legislation is supposed to help them. It puts another burden on them. The Democrats were too dumb to see that. The gentleman who operates in another place is too overweight to get behind a truck wheel let alone know what trucking is all about. The reality of the situation is that previously a judge in his own right may have come to a decision to take away this operator's licence, which we all oppose, but on the other hand he might also have imposed a penalty which was a disqualification for some period. Now a series of admonishments can be set in train which would then require a judge to impose a penalty. That is supposed to be some improvement; it is the reverse. It will make things more difficult.

I turn to a question which is relevant to the amendments. It is one which the Minister might like to answer. Agreement has been reached on certain matters with the Australian Transport Advisory Council, including the introduction of graduated licences for truck drivers, which will require that drivers operating large interstate vehicles will have had appropriate experience. The other day I talked with 40 truck drivers at Naracoorte. Something that Western Australians do not clearly understand is that one who takes a 20-mile journey around Mt Gambier or Naracoorte can become an interstate truck driver, because that is the distance one has to travel to cross a State border, and that is a heavily populated area. I am told that the number of truck owners as a percentage of the population is probably higher in Mt Gambier than in any other part of Australia.

So how does a farmer in that area get a licence when the Bill requires that a licence to operate large interstate vehicles will not be granted to a person without appropriate experience? What does the son of a farmer have to do? He would have to join the Transport Workers Union of Australia and go and work for Brambles. If the union and the company did not have any places for that person, he would not get the appropriate experience. If the Minister had occupied any part of a truck other than the passenger seat he would know that the requirement for appropriate experience is another myth, as is the claim that finance companies stand out on the footpath and drag unsuspecting blokes in black shorts and blue singlets off the streets to sell them a truck and to force finance upon them. That is a load of rubbish. I have been in the industry and I know some very good people with long trucking experience who have had quite significant finance, including a family home, who have been rejected by the finance companies as having insufficient capital to buy a truck. They have come to me for assistance by way of providing a guarantee. On a number of occasions, knowing those people, I have taken the risk and given them that guarantee so that they could get into business.

This proposal is one that the State governments have not yet considered. I suggest that they will not do so. Eventually, the only feather that the Minister will have to fly with will be the paper on which this legislation is printed. He can go flapping around with that. The proposed amendments are not appropriate to the trucking industry. The only purpose of this legislation and the proposed amendments is to gain money and to take people's livelihoods from them.

The amendment, which will require an operator to be licensed, will take people's livelihoods from them and will result in regulation of the industry. We will have the situation whereby if one has not been a member of the TWU and has not worked as an employee for Brambles or Thomas Nationwide Transport one will not be able to take the final step into owner-driving and small business, which has been a wonderful part of the transport industry. Yes, there have been failures and there have been people who have found the going very rough, but they still queue up to get into the industry. A lot of them like the life and have done very well out of it over the years. Strangely enough, they are all working at very similar rates. So that puts down the argument for introducing the amendment. We have to oppose it. It will make the situation worse. It is tokenism, because Australian Democrats have caved in.
The other amendment relating to a fee of $100 for an operator's licence is hardly relevant. That again is tokenism. I have received a telex that states:
A fleet operator will if he has 10 trucks have to outlay $24,000 in the first year.
The haulage contractor with 10 trucks and subbies will have to outlay $34,000 in the first year.

Yet we are arguing whether we should have a $100 ceiling on an operator's licence. Again, that is tokenism. The real problem is that the Bill makes legitimate a road maintenance tax on interstate operations. That is the absolute and only reason for the introduction of this Bill into this Parliament. All the other matters of safety which have been thrown up as the reason for introducing this legislation could be dealt with by State governments. Had the Minister, when he was negotiating the road funding agreements, said to the States `I think it is imperative before we finalise this legislation that you get your act in order on reasonable measures of safety and on reasonable measures of standardisation and uniformity' I believe that the States could have resolved overnight the silliness that exists in some of those areas.

But the Minister did not do that because he did not want to. He wants to be the king of transport and have more rides in big trucks. Maybe the truckies will give him the chance to blow the horn before long. He has produced this unnecessary legislation to which Democrat amendments were agreed to in the Senate by the Government to give the Democrats some credibility. Senator Vigor, having promised truckies in South Australia that he would help them, the Minister brings in this sort of tokenism. The Government is bad enough-we know its ambitions regarding socialism and regulation-but the real fault lies with the Democrats. They were asked to, and could have done, a simple thing such as referring this legislation to a committee in which the realities of it could have been discovered. But no, the Democrats caved in. I do not know what the Government has offered them, but it must have been pretty good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard from the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) a continuation of the baseless assertions they put forward in the second reading debate in this place. They are not arguing a case with any substance. It is simply a proposition to continue to do nothing. For decades in this country we have seen the contempt with which the conservative parties have treated the road transport industry. We would not be debating this matter now if, as a result of the 1979 Razorback Mountain blockade, the then Government had done something about it. We would not be debating it now if, as a result of the demonstrations outside this House in 1980 by the road transport industry, the then Government had done something about it. All we have heard from the Opposition this morning, as we heard in the Senate, have been rather futile arguments about why we should do nothing, why we should just leave the matter alone and it will sort itself out. It is really a filibuster, an argument for nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: The personal reflections by the honourable member for O'Connor on the stature of the spokesman for the Australian Democrats or his personal reflections on other persons do not do anything at all for the road transport industry. It is a pretty puerile and infantile kind of approach. I am surprised that the honourable member takes that kind of line. He rejects the safety arguments of the industry. He rejects the graduated driver licensing approach. The honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for Murray are really saying: `Do not recognise that this legislation is supported by the industry, by the masses of decent, responsible truck operators who have pleaded with successive governments for years to do something to restructure their industry, to put it on a decent, fair basis'. That is what the industry wants. From the Federal Government's point of view there is nothing in the legislation of a remunerative nature that attracts us. All we are doing is providing the means by which there can be a fairer basis of operation within the industry and a fairer contribution by all who participate in interstate trade and transport to the costs they generate by the use of their vehicles. By and large the industry accepts that.

What is before us is the result of two years work; a year of inquiry and a subsequent year of analysis and time for response to the recommendations of the inquiry. Honourable members opposite have led the arguments in support of the view put by the honourable member for O'Connor from a defunct organisation. It has not existed for several years. It did not make a submission to the road transport inquiry. It was invited to make a response to the recommendations of the inquiry but it declined to do so. However, at the last moment it hops in and wants to go against all the arguments that have been accepted by everybody else in the industry. The proposition has been put up again that we are trying to rush this legislation through the House. The opposite is true. I said earlier that we were being criticised for not having put the legislation through earlier. What we are carrying forward is the request of the industry. There will be some, represented by the honourable member for O'Connor, who do not want to see fairness across the industry. They do not want to see all those who use and generate expenditure on interstate roads and presently do not make a contribution, make a contribution. That is really the substance of their case.

What do the States think about the matter? The Opposition stands alone in its opposition to this legislation. The industry wants it and there is unanimity between all governments; they all want it. We are supporting it and carrying it through. Mr Hinze, the Queensland Minister for Local Government Roads and Racing, telexed his own members on 17 September saying:
Given the constitutional realities and the complexity of other alternatives, Queensland agrees that the Commonwealth Government should implement the type of scheme proposed.
He went on to say:
Generally there has been good co-operation between Commonwealth and State officials working out the administrative details of the scheme.

Contrary to the quotations put in this place by Opposition spokesmen earlier, Mr Gray, the Tasmanian Premier, in a subsequent speech to the Australian Road Transport Federation on 20 October, at which I was present, said:
My Government has expressed its support for the fast track package and is currently working on means of implementing those recommendations requiring State government action.
I have not quoted the State Labor governments, just the two conservative governments to show their attitude. It is the Opposition that is out of step.

The question of the operator licence, which was mentioned earlier, is yet to be fully discussed. There was a meeting of officials yesterday working on the basis of implementation on 1 July next year. The States are clear about the need for Federal legislation as a prerequisite for State action on their part on the fast track package. In respect of the court action mentioned by the honourable member for O'Connor, the court still has the option of taking no action. The argument put forward in this respect is quite spurious, as it was previously. The court can decide to take no action, to inflict admonishment or disqualification. Where there are two admonishments in the previous 10 years the option of admonishment is no longer available. But the other alternatives remain. There is no economic regulation of the industry. That is the nonsense of the case put forward by the Opposition. I will not rehash the arguments that were put during the second reading debate. The legislation is needed, it is long overdue, the industry wants it, the State governments support it and I commend it to the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 12 November.
Consideration of Senate's requests.
Senate's requested amendments-
No. 1-Page 3, clause 5, at end of clause, add the following new sub-clauses:
``(4) The amount of charge in respect of the registration of a motor vehicle shall not exceed $1,000.
``(5) The amount of charge in respect of the registration of a trailer shall not exceed $400.''.
No. 2-Page 3, after clause 5, insert the following new clause:
Indexation
``5A. (1) In this section-

`index number', in relation to a quarter, means the All Groups Consumer Price Index number, being the weighted average of the 8 capital cities, published by the Australian Statistician in respect of that quarter;
`relevant amount' means-
(a) the amount specified in sub-section 5 (4), being the amount that the amount of charge in respect of the registration of a motor vehicle is not to exceed; or
(b) the amount specified in sub-section 5 (5), being the amount that the amount of charge in respect of the registration of a trailer is not to exceed;
`relevant year' means the period of 12 months commencing on 1 July 1987 and each subsequent period of 12 months.

``(2) Subject to sub-section (3), if at any time, whether before or after the commencement of this section, the Australian Statistician has published or publishes an index number in respect of a quarter in substitution for an index number previously published by the Australian Statistician in respect of that quarter, the publication of the later index number shall be disregarded for the purposes of this section.

``(3) If at any time, whether before or after the commencement of this section, the Australian Statistician has changed or changes the reference base for the Consumer Price Index, then, for the purposes of the application of this section after the change took place or takes place, regard shall be had only to the index numbers published in terms of the new reference base.

``(4) Where the factor ascertained under sub-section (5) in relation to a relevant year is greater than one, this Act has effect as if for each relevant amount there were substituted, on the first day of that relevant year, an amount calculated by multiplying by that factor-
(a) in a case to which paragraph (b) does not apply-the relevant amount; or

(b) if, by virtue of another application or other applications of this section, this Act has effect as if another amount or amounts were substituted for that relevant amount-the substituted amount or the last substituted amount.

``(5) The factor to be ascertained for the purposes of sub-section (4) in relation to a relevant year is the number (calculated to 3 decimal places) ascertained by dividing the index number for the March quarter immediately preceding that relevant year by the index number for the March quarter immediately preceding that first-mentioned March quarter.

``(6) Where the factor ascertained in accordance with sub-section (5) in relation to a relevant year would, if it were calculated to 4 decimal places, end with a number greater than 4, the factor ascertained in accordance with that sub-section in relation to that relevant year shall be taken to be the factor calculated to 3 decimal places in accordance with that sub-section and increased by 0.001.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments requested by the Senate be agreed to.

The Government is prepared to support the amendments requested by the Senate in respect of the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985. The effect of these amendments will be to place a maximum limit on annual registration of $1,000 for a prime mover or motor vehicle and $400 for a trailer, with these ceilings indexed from 1986-87 to movements in the consumer price index. There will still be a requirement for the actual charges to be set and varied by regulations up to those limits. If it is decided that these charges should be increased beyond these limits, it will be necessary to introduce amending legislation. Whilst we have reservations about the necessity for such provisions, believing that there is adequate parliamentary scrutiny of regulations, the concerns that have been expressed in some quarters lead us to the conclusion that it will be a reasonable compromise to accept such a ceiling on the charges being included. This is what the Hawke Government's policy of consultation and consensus is all about. We listen to what people say to us and we are prepared to modify our approach where reasonable points or concerns are expressed. As all honourable members are aware, the basis of the initial charge of $1,400 for a typical 38-tonne rig is the report of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. Variations of those charges will be based on current and future investigations carried out by the Inter-State Commission, having regard to the equivalent State charges and the level of cost recovery achieved by railways. I recommend the amendments to the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOME AND COMMUNITY CARE BILL 1985[COGNATE BILL:HOME AND COMMUNITY CARE (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 October, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with order of the day No. 4, the Home and Community Care (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. If there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Home and Community Care Bill and the cognate Bill introduced by the Government to amend certain legislation covered by the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970, the Home Nursing Subsidy Act 1956, the States Grants (Home Care) Act 1969 and the States Grants (Paramedical Services) Act 1969. In fact, we congratulate the Government on moving towards what could be described as the privatisation of care in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has long supported the view that government has a role to assist people to live independently in the community and not to require them to move into institutions. Regrettably, in the past, the degree of funding available for this aspect of aged care has not been adequate, and there have been, I believe, unnecessary numbers of people who have been forced, because of circumstances beyond their control, to move into institutions on a permanent basis. If the support had been available in the past, people could have remained in the community, close to their family and close to their friends.

This Bill raises the important point about how we in Australia care for our aged people. I think even the most cursory reading of demographic statistics indicates that we do, in fact, have an aging population, and that over the next generation the number of people of retirement age in the community will increase considerably. There is an important need, I believe, for governments in Australia to recognise this fact and to incorporate it in the development of their policy. No longer can we go about thinking simply that we can put the aged people in our community, once they turn the magical age of 60 or 65, into an institution, sweep them under the mat, and forget about them. It is important that we have policies which encourage them to remain part of our community. What we need is care in the community and also by the community.

It is sad, I think, that in many cases the community is only too keen to move the aged section of our population out of sight; out of sight being out of mind. I have personally been aware of many cases where a nursing home which has been established in the past has become the site of redevelopment, and there has been tremendous community pressure to relocate that nursing home away from the centre of the community and out into an area away from the general population. That is sad, because I think it is important that we leave the aged section of our community well and truly in the centre of the community.

I know of one town in New South Wales where a nursing home has been established in what was formerly a hotel. This has achieved nursing home care in the middle of a town. The residents of that institution are able to do as they have done for all of their lives in many cases, to actually walk up and down the main street, to sit on a bench outside their converted hotel, which is now a nursing home, and converse with people whom they have known for many years. I think that is an appropriate tactic and strategy for aged care in Australia.

This Bill establishes a framework for home and community care. The program was originally announced in 1984 as part of the Budget. The home and community care program is to be a joint section 96 Commonwealth-State program to assist State and local governments and non-government organisations to provide basic community support and maintenance services. Services are to be targeted to aged or disabled people to minimise premature and unnecessary admission to long term residential care. As I have said, the coalition supports that philosophy. The Bill incorporates a Schedule which is to be a model agreement between the Commonwealth and States for funding for the program in the future. The Schedule also sets out levels of funding and growth for the program-$10m growth funding on an unmatched basis in the first year, $25m growth in 1985-86 on a 3 : 1 matched basis, and $30m in 1986-87 on a 2 : 1 matched basis.

I have mentioned those figures because later I would like to address the way in which this Government has approached the announcement and promotion of this scheme. It is, as I have said, a good scheme and philosophically the Opposition supports it. However, we do regret that the Government has found it necessary to promote the scheme for what amounts to selfish political purposes. It is creating expectations among aged people and organisations concerned with the care of the aged in our community which just will not be realised. I will return to that point in a few moments. It is important also to recognise that the Home and Community Care Bill has been the cause of some concern within State governments. I hope that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in responding to this debate, will explain what action the Commonwealth has taken in response to those concerns expressed by some State governments.

The home and community care program was first announced in the 1984 Budget. It resurfaced, amazingly, during the 1984 election campaign when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised a new sweeping initiative in the care of the aged. He promised a new cost-shared home and community care program at a cost of some $300m. They were his words in the context of the election, and I refer honourable members to the figures I read out, incorporated in the Schedule of this Bill, which provide for $10m worth of growth funding in the first year. That is not $300m, as promised by the Prime Minister. This is the same Prime Minister who during that election campaign made a number of promises, most of which have not been kept; the same Prime Minister who during election campaigns makes promises such as there will be no capital gains tax and then engages in the most incredible piece of sophistry we have ever seen, trying to explain that that was for only one fixed period of time and now the Government has been re-elected those promises can go by the board.

It is worth examining in some detail the short-comings of this Government's program in aged care. This Government has created unreal expectations for the HACC program, suggesting that $300m would be made available and inducing major welfare groups to believe that the Government had created a major new program, had instituted a major initiative which would be welcomed by the community generally and result in an increased standard of aged care for people in Australia. Frankly, assistance for the aged under this Labor Government has been nothing short of a disaster. The first thing we had when this Government came into office was an income test on pensions for people over 70 years of age. Then we had the 31 per cent income tax on lump sum superannuation payments. This is the Government which is supposedly concerned to encourage people to look after themselves in their old age, so what does it do? It imposes a tax on superannuation payments, on the capital that people have been accumulating over a working lifetime so that they can have a degree of security, a degree of comfort and a lessening of worry, and a degree of increased independence in their old age. This Government, with one stroke of the pen-contrary again to assurances given by the Prime Minister that there would be no taxes on superannuation-has imposed a lump sum superannuation tax which will force Australian aged people in the future to be increasingly dependent upon the state and the community generally. Their capacity to become independent in their old age has been reduced as their capacity to accumulate capital over their working life and to obtain the benefits of that capital, albeit modest, when they retire has been significantly reduced by this Government.

The Government further decided that it would pick on a relatively helpless section of the community by introducing the assets test. The real problem with the assets test is that it just did not work. It was one of those band-aid schemes that this Government is quite prone to. Instead of sitting down and coming up with a comprehensive retirement incomes policy, needs based and equitable right across the community, it came up with version one of the assets test.

Then of course there was an immediate public outcry and the Government realised that there were some problems with the assets test so we then had versions two, three and four and now version five; and it still does not work equitably. It still does not apply right across the community without discriminating against certain people. It still assumes that if someone lives in a modest bungalow in a country area on 25 acres that he is wealthy and not in need of any community assistance. It does not address the problem of people who live in very expensive houses in the metropolitan areas but it does discriminate against rural pensioners. The reason is that this Government does not care and does not understand the problems faced by people who live outside the major metropolitan areas. Increasingly, this Government subscribes to the philosophy that it can govern on the votes of the people who live in Sydney and Melbourne, and particularly in the western suburbs of those cities. There is no care, no policy and no determination to reflect the views and the needs of the people who live outside those areas.

I have mentioned that this Government, firstly, income tested people over 70 years of age, then introduced the lump sum tax on superannuation and then the assets test. In addition, we had the Medicare fiasco. Medicare has resulted in growing waiting lists in public hospitals. Pensioners, who are justifiably concerned, because of their age, about their health and the standard of health care they are able to receive, have in some cases been forced to take out private health insurance in an attempt to ensure that they can get the sort of health care that they want because they no longer have any confidence in the public health system in Australia.

I mentioned earlier that the Government had engaged in a lot of hype and self-indulgent publicity when it announced its home and community care program, and people were given false expectations. They thought $300m really would be available. The South Australian Labour Minister of Health, Dr John Cornwall has, I believe, shown this Government to be exactly what it is in terms of this Bill. Dr Cornwall admitted, in reply to a question in Parliament, that the amount South Australia will receive under this Bill `will be a little less than $1m'. I do not know where the other $299m are. Perhaps they do not exist in terms of a new initiative. Dr Cornwall then added:
Unfortunately I believe it may have been oversold . . .

Let me repeat the word `oversold'. The program came out in the 1984 Budget and suddenly, during the 1984 Budget election campaign, it turned into a bold new initiative with $300m. That amount really represented money which was already in place under the four other programs that are covered by this Bill. In fact, the Government has a $10m commitment to additional funding and South Australia is receiving $1m of that additional amount. That is quite an equitable share but it is a long way short from the public perception that $300m of extra funding was to be given to aged care in Australia. Mr Cornwall continued:

Unfortunately I believe it may have been oversold significantly in the pre-Federal election climate. I think that expectations may have been unduly raised . . . it will certainly not be the answer to all our problems.

That was said by the Labor Minister of Health in South Australia, the same Minister who is about to contest an election, and his Premier has suggested that the South Australian Government is independent of this Federal Labor Government and that it runs its own ship and it is not too keen to have the Prime Minister campaigning in South Australia. Is it any wonder when in Parliament he has to admit that the Government is prone to overselling its programs, and that instead of getting some share of the $300m South Australia will get only $1m.
In March we were told by Senator Grimes who was responsible for this program:

We see the new program to be largely about providing an essential service to maintain elderly people and older and younger disabled who need long-term support, to stay in their own homes or with supporting families.

In November Senator Grimes promised that the home and community care program could provide gardening, home maintenance, shopping and laundry services. I guess that is part of the same overselling program that Dr Cornwall referred to. Quite frankly, the whole thing has been wrapped up in this Government's hype. When it comes to an election it will say and do anything in order to dupe the Australian people into voting for it.

We have another example of that which is directly related to the home and community care program and that is the Office of Aged Care. This represents one of the greatest frauds ever perpetrated on the aged community in Australia. Mr Hawke promised to establish an Office of Aged Care in the 1983 election campaign. Of course the promise was not carried out. That is quite amazing, because this proposal has bipartisan support. The Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia agree that there is a need for an office specialising in the care and policy development of the aged section of our community. The Government promised it in 1983 and did not do anything about it. It rehashed the promise in the 1984 campaign, making it sound new and different and something that had not been promised before. Again, the Prime Minister promised an Office of Aged Care. Finally, I think in August of this year, it got around to establishing it.

We might ask why it took so long. I guess the answer is that as with everything else this Government has had so much difficulty; be it tax reform, maintaining the value of the dollar or coming up with a youth employment program. The great problem is factionalism. It just cannot get things straight. The reason we did not have an Office of Aged Care earlier is that we had this almighty Donnybrook between the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, and the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes. They were both engaged in what could loosely be described as power or factional politics within the Australian Labor Party. They and their departments could not agree on who would have responsibility for this new Office of Aged Care. Finally the matter was resolved when, after the last election-the Prime Minister would have liked to have reshuffled his front bench, but he was not game to do so because that would have unleashed this incredible war among factions within the Labor Party-we had what was described at the time as a reshuffling of the deckchairs on the Titanic. Out of that reshuffle was created the Department of Community Services and Senator Grimes is still the Minister for that. Dr Blewett is still the Minister for Health, although he does not have the same ministerial responsibilities he used to have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is that?

—He is now the Minister for plastic cards with or without photographs. Of course the Minister for Social Security is now a member of this House and the Office of Aged Care went to Senator Grimes. That is how factional wars are resolved in the Labor Party. It waits until after an election and then its members do a deal on the big issues, such as who will sit on the front bench. The Prime Minister then says: `Listen, stop fighting. You are going to do this'. We finally got the Office of Aged Care, and about time.

SPEECH.PARA: Now let the Government get on with the job of coming up with some policies and programs which will actually do something to help the aged people in our community. Like so many things this Government attempts to do its intentions are perhaps good, but it is distorted by factionalism and blind ideology. We really need a government which is committed to achieving an improvement in the standard of living of Australians, and that means keeping the value of the dollar up and doing away with those ridiculous policies of appeasement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which are increasingly forcing our dollar down. As many people in the community predict, it is likely to hit 50 cents before this Government comes to its senses and does away with its ridiculous agreement with the ACTU to govern for and in its interests and damn the interests of other Australians.

If we are to have good government in this country and good policies which will benefit the people and if we are to have a caring government we should do away with the hype. This Government should resist the temptation at election time to promote policies such as the home and community care program as a $300m new sweeping initiative and should actually say: `What we are going to do is to encourage the care of aged and disadvantaged people in our community by the community in the community and keep them part of that community'. It should resist the temptation to indulge in all sorts of hype. I guess it was probably only the shortness of the time span that prevented the Government from engaging some advertising agency to promote its aged care policies. Heaven only knows who it would have used. It is also a wonder that we do not have full page newspaper advertisements screaming and proclaiming the benefits of this Government's policy. If it had done that, it would probably have spent more on the advertising campaign than will be spent on the program.

As I have said, the coalition supports this program as a move in the right direction. We subscribe to the view that there should be care for the aged and disabled in our community in the community and by the community. We congratulate the Government on moving in what could be described as the direction of privatisation in this area. We offer to support it in further moves in this direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Opposition supports the Home and Community Care Bill but I am absolutely astonished that the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) chose to find criticisms. The only criticisms he could make were that we raised expectations and indulged in hype. He asked why it took so long to bring in this legislation. I will tell him why it has taken a decent time. This Government felt the need to consult. We wanted to find out what the community wants and we are now delivering what the community wants. He had the hide to talk about frauds perpetrated on the community and then to carry on about the assets test and the taxing of superannuation. Was there ever a greater fraud perpetrated on the community than the scare tactics of the Opposition on those issues? It terrorised little old ladies by telling them that we would take the gold wedding rings from their fingers and the gold fillings out of their teeth.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the Bill. In the August Budget last year the then Minister for Social Security-Senator Grimes-the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Geitzelt) announced a new cost share program, the home and community care program. The aims of this new package are to incorporate existing programs and include additional initiatives to provide an even wider range of community care for aged and disabled people and families in crisis who need home care services.

Four existing Acts are to be amalgamated to enable the HACC program to operate. They are the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970, the Home Nursing Subsidy Act 1956, the States Grants (Home Care) Act 1969 and the States Grants (Paramedical Services) Act 1969. Our Government is to be commended for initiating this new program which will be cost shared with the States and Territories and administered by the States.

The main objective of the Bill is to provide a comprehensive range of integrated home care and community based services for people who might be at risk of premature or inappropriate institutionalisation because of the absence of such support. It is targeted at the frail or at-risk aged persons and younger disabled persons in order to enable them to remain in their own homes or in the community in a non-institutional setting. The Commonwealth will be assisting State, local government and community organisations in providing a range of sub-programs covering services and capital facilities currently funded by the Commonwealth under the four existing Acts. Those services include meals, community nursing, home help, home maintenance, community paramedical services and senior citizens centres, and services not now funded, such as community respite care, transport, assessment and referral services.

New projects are to be approved jointly by the Commonwealth and the States, as are the allocation of funds. Significant variations to such allocations to those projects have regard to such matters as the views of local government councils, community organisations and service users on needs and priorities under the program. The community sector supports both the principle of planning and co-ordination of social support services and our commitment to increased resources. The Government has already been congratulated on taking the initiative. As we have seen, many areas of social welfare have been disgracefully neglected since the Liberals grabbed power in 1975, 10 years ago.

This area of home and community care has needed a new approach for many years. When in government the Opposition did nothing to recognise the changing needs of the frail aged, or of the disabled who might require long term support services to stay in their own homes. It did not care enough to develop a program that would give those people an appropriate choice between community and institutional care. Our Government recognised those changing needs. We wasted no time after being elected in beginning the process of shaping a more coherent direction in the delivery of community services.

To achieve this objective the Government has also recognised that for this program to be successful wide-ranging discussions must take place between government and non-government sectors, particularly over the next three years of the program's development. The most important administrative change is the introduction of three-year rolling cost sharing agreements. The introduction of a rolling program will allow the States and Territories to plan ahead for the next three years with confidence of the certainty of funding. The Government has set up Commonwealth and State negotiating teams, where organisations which provide home and community based services for aged and disabled people can present their views on the new program. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has already said in his Press release:

Once the program commences in each State later this year, I would also hope that consultative machinery will be established which will enable community groups to participate in the on-going planning development and administration of services.

I have spoken to many groups in my electorate who are providing these community care services and they all stress the importance of national consultative mechanisms. In New South Wales there is a coalition of non-government and community organisations which convenes regular forums to monitor the implementation of the program in the State. The HACC forum provides an independent voice for those groups in negotiations with State and Federal representatives. The forum acknowledges that this HACC program can offer a unique opportunity to review and restructure the framework for the delivery of home support services in New South Wales, providing the development of the program focuses clearly on the integration of services leading to a complementary range of service options for the target groups identified in the guidelines. It is a concern of the forum, as indeed it is a concern of many community groups to which I have spoken, that the HACC program cover a wide range of service types to meet the desperate needs of special client groups. The services required by younger disabled people, for example, may not be appropriate for the frail aged.

I want to concentrate now on the services provided for the disabled. There are many disabled people in Phillip and a concentration of groups involved in their care. First, there is the Prince of Wales and Prince Henry Hospital group, a centre vital to the work of many of the community services. For instance, the Prince of Wales Hospital provides meals for the Meals on Wheels service. The Australian Quadriplegic Association in Maroubra, while not in Phillip, certainly serves the needs of many of my constituents. The Randwick Disabled Persons Action Committee is one with which I have constant contact. It is full of articulate and vocal members. We also have in the electorate the Wairoa Special School, a State Department of Education school for developmentally disabled children and the Windgap Special School.

Since election to this House as the member for Phillip I have become acutely aware of the specific needs of the disabled. Because the HACC program will involve a range of community support services it is particularly important for disabled people because of the current moves away from institutionalisation towards independent living. It is therefore very important that disabled groups be involved in the consultation process. They are adamant that new services deployed under HACC will not perpetuate the models that enshrine dependency and that funding of these services will be not just adequate but fully supported and suited to their needs.

A disabled person living at home can need up to four hours personal care a day-two hours in the morning and two hours at night-seven days a week. Understandably the disabled are concerned about the proportion of funds allocated to their needs.

They are concerned that the disabled should not have to compete with the frail aged for services necessary for both groups to exist in the community. In my electorate an attendant care pilot program for the disabled has been operating. This initiative recognises that the Goverment understands some of the special problems that a disabled person faces in an endeavour to live independently.

This new legislation does not yet meet all the needs of the disabled, but it is a start. HACC is itself a pilot program and will, through the consultative processes, reveal both strengths and weaknesses and allow the Government to make a planned response. An example of the Government's commitment to consultation with disabled people on how best to help them participate fully in the mainstream of society was the handicapped programs review. After a most comprehensive public examination, involving over 6,000 individuals and organisations, the Minister for Community Services tabled the report and recommendations in the Senate in May this year. One of the significant recommendations of the review is the replacement of the current Handicapped Persons Assistance Act with new disability services legislation. This will allow for greater flexibility in service types and funding arrangements to meet the real needs of people with disabilities. Once again, the Government has been congratulated by the disabled groups for bringing out and supporting such a revolutionary document as the handicapped programs review. The Disabled Person International said:
Never before has a Government committed itself so strongly to a `philosophy' which is mirrored throughout the community of people with disabilities.

We are off to a good start. With the mutual goodwill of the Government and the community we will achieve fully what our legislation sets out to do. I look forward to New South Wales completing its negotiations soon to allow the HACC program to be fully implemented in our State. I commend these Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted that, in recent months, it has been standard for Government members, when referring to previous Liberal governments, just to make the bland statement that they did nothing. That is obviously nonsense but it is a trap that the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) has also fallen into. In contrast, this legislation and its heralding by the Government could be described as much ado about very little indeed. While it is certainly commendable that aged care programs be brought together the Government, in its election campaign and indeed even since, raised expectations in relation to its commitment to home care well above its intention. For example, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in his second reading speech stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Total Commonwealth expenditure on home and community services in 1984-85, 1985-86 and 1986-87 is estimated to be $317.6m.

In statements on this program before it was unveiled people were led to believe that the Government was committed to a new expenditure program of $300m. Certainly the wording of Press releases and statements during the election campaign would have led to a confidence that that was the substance of the Government's promise. The substance has proved to be a shadow. There is actually only additional Commonwealth funding in 1985-86 of an unmatched $10m. Further additional money is subject to the States agreeing to matching funding.

It is truly said that the worth of a community can be judged according to the care that it takes of its aged and its young. In the last couple of decades the Australian community has dramatically upgraded its care of the aged. That is not to suggest that care of the young has not been upgraded but the aged are the substance of the debate today. That upgrading has included actions by both Liberal and Labor governments over that period. It should be a matter of pride to Australians that we have attempted to take good care of the aged in our community, particularly the frail aged. However, the essence of this debate is about directions in the care of the aged.

I think it is commendable that elderly people be encouraged to stay in their homes if that is the appropriate form of living for them. The Minister, in his second reading speech, placed some emphasis on the term, `appropriate' and a number of comments in the early part of the speech refer to appropriate solutions in the care of the aged. However, the only alternative to home care he considered was care of the aged in nursing homes. That shows a blindness about trends in recent times. The honourable member for Phillip, throughout her speech, referred to alternatives as institutionalised care. The term `institutionalisation' in relation to the aged has very negative connotations indeed, particularly for the elderly. One would have hoped, however, that the negative connotations that attached to nursing home care 20 years ago had faded and for good reason. Standards have been lifted so substantially that nursing homes are a very important part of care of the aged in this country. People in other countries who become acquainted with the standards set in our nursing homes for care, and with the availability of nursing home care, recognise that they are remarkably above what obtains in other countries. I support the extension of home support for the elderly but am concerned that it should not be seen as an absolute alternative to nursing homes. Nursing homes have a very important role in our community. Naturally I am also concerned that nursing homes not be seen as the only alternative to home care.

One of the things that troubled me about the debate that preceded the introduction of this legislation on home care for the elderly was that many of the proponents of it, I believe, have not been fully aware of the realities of elderly people living in their own homes. It is true that there are many elderly people who are independent and vigorous and who, with a certain amount of support in essential matters, can live in their own homes quite successfully. My mother is one such case in point. Good luck to them. However, there are certain problems in maintaining one's own home. I have a sneaking suspicion that some of the most ardent proponents of keeping elderly people in their own homes really do not know very much about the realities of the day to day running of a home. I do not know whether they are aware of the reality particularly for a woman-many of the elderly in their own homes are women on their own, most of them widows-of the day-in, day-out and year-in, year-out grind of having to attend to the marketing, the cooking, the cleaning, the washing, the ironing, the gardening and taking out the garbage. After 60 or 70 years of that many people get a little weary and actively look for alternatives. We are not debating a program that suggests elderly people will not have to go on doing such things as the marketing, the cooking, the cleaning, the washing, the ironing, the gardening and taking out the garbage. We are looking at suggestions of support in fairly obvious areas.

As I have said, many of the people we are discussing are women on their own. Some, a fairly small percentage, are men on their own and some are married couples. I suggest to those who are proponents of these types of programs that, before they too ardently and blinkedly pursue this path in the future, they should consider some of the risks for elderly people in staying in their homes too long. In my time in Parliament I have spent some time with the Blue Nursing Service travelling with the nursing sisters as they have visited people in their own homes to provide a minimum amount of nursing care. I have seen some very heartwarming situations, such as an elderly parent living in a loving family relationship, where the Blue Nurses have made all the difference to that family's ability to cope and to keep a dearly loved parent living with them in good circumstances. In many of those cases these people are not by any means well off. In fact, I think some of them would be struggling financially to extend themselves to caring for an extra person in the home. But they do it with love and with joy. It is good that services such as those the Blue Nurses provide allow that to happen.

However, there is another side to that coin. I have also seen elderly people who really ought not to be attempting to stay in their homes. One case which stays very vividly in my mind is that of an elderly couple in their eighties, totally devoted to one another, where the woman was a bedridden invalid, and the man was in extremely frail health. They clung to one another and their home because it was what they knew and what they loved and they did not see themselves as having any alternative. However, the husband was literally killing himself looking after his wife. That is another side to the coin and one to which we should be alert.

I have long felt concern that many of those who have much to say on the subject of care of the elderly start from a proposition that profits are bad, therefore a nursing home which is run at a profit is an undesirable feature of our community. Not all nursing homes are profit making facilities. They are a mix of private and community facilities. My electorate of Moncrieff has a very high number of retired people. The majority of residents of my electorate live on the Gold Coast, the premier retirement area for Australia. The Gold Coast in many ways encapsulates what is happening to lifestyles of the elderly in Australia. In recent years there has been a development in the types of living facilities for the aged which has manifested itself in some of the more recent establishments in my electorate. I think the trend in these facilities is highly desirable and I am very attracted to it.

In my opinion the most desirable alternative to living at home is that development which combines independently standing units where people usually own two-bedroom homes, incorporates hostel living-whether that is single room plus bathroom facilities or bed-sitting facilities-plus a nursing home. There are many attractions and advantages to retired and elderly people living in that kind of community. The first attraction and advantage is that it is a community. A major problem for elderly people in our society is loneliness. As they grow older, after a spouse dies, as family moves to other parts of Australia in this very mobile community which we have and as friends die as they too grow old, elderly people become more and more isolated. They do not necessarily become ill at the same time, and therefore in need of nursing home care, but they do need company. Without a doubt people who have taken the step of moving into the sort of complex that I talk about say the first benefit, the reason they have no doubts they did the right thing, is that they have community living at their disposal if they want it. Company for elderly people, whatever their state of health, is terribly important in their expectations of life.

The hostels do away with the onerous home duties that I referred to earlier in my speech, but they add something else; they guarantee a minimum standard of nutrition in the diets of elderly people. It is a fact that as people grow older, as they stop caring for families, as women stop having the responsibility of thinking what the next meal will be that they will prepare for themselves and their husbands, they allow their nutritional standards to decline. They allow themselves to just snack and do not give consideration to balanced nutrition. Those who go into hostel accommodation often have an increase in their energy and their well-being simply because meals are provided for them. They no longer have to decide three times a day what they are going to eat, having to go out and buy it from the shops, with all those hassles, and cook it.

The most important element of this combination of facilities is the nursing home. It is important that nursing homes are available for the disabled and the very frail aged. Nursing home matrons and doctors of nursing home patients have said to me that some people considered to be in need of nursing home care have shortly after admission reached the stage where they really did not need that level of care. There were two reasons for that, which I have already mentioned. The first and most important reason is nutrition. Elderly people should get proper vitamins and a proper diet but many living on their own do not achieve that ideal. The second reason is having company rekindles their interest in life. Those institutions make a very valuable contribution, not only to the physical health but also the psychological health of our elderly citizens.

This Government has indicated that it does not want to see expansion of nursing homes. Its attitude towards the subject of profitability of private nursing homes has been such as to make private investment in nursing homes totally unattractive. In the last three years there has been a further noticeable trend, that is, the building of establishments containing the first two elements I mentioned-free standing units plus hostels, but no nursing home. That is better than elderly people living a lonely, aimless and sometimes neurotic existence, but it is not the most desirable option.

The inclusion of a nursing home in the aged person living complex is critical for a number of reasons. Firstly, the older people get the more traumatic it is if they have to change their place of living. One of the reasons many elderly people stay in their homes too long is that they leave consideration of moving into another type of establishment too late and it becomes too daunting a prospect for them. Imagine the trauma of elderly people who are too reluctant to make the move into hostel or community-type unit accommodation suddenly having to go into a nursing home. They have the trauma of acute illness which requires the move, they have the trauma of having to abandon their homes under those circumstances, and the additional trauma of being surrounded by strangers in an unfamiliar situation. From my own observation of the retirement complexes I discussed earlier, one of their great benefits is that if those residents need nursing home care they can move within an environment with which they are familiar and have their friends around them. Their friends can visit them and even help feed them at meal times if that is necessary. This makes an enormous difference to the morale of nursing homes residents. It also makes a big difference to the attitudes of elderly people not in nursing homes as to what their prospects are if the worst comes to the worst and they do suffer some severe disability, such as a stroke, which means that they are totally dependent on care.

Whilst saying to the Government that I certainly support reasonable, well thought out and comprehensive home care programs, I urge it to move away from the anti-nursing home attitude to which it has been moving. It needs to recognise the reality that many elderly people who are quite fit in recent times have chosen to leave their homes and move into the aged persons complexes I have described because they are realists about what the future may hold for them. I ask the Government also to face the fact that it is critical for elderly people to have first class medical care rapidly at their disposal. Those who have elderly parents living alone in their home on their own dread the thought of the chest pain that invariably comes in the middle of the night. When people reach a high risk age they should have within reach a button they can press which will summon within seconds the sort of medical care that is immediately required. I say to the Government: By all means pursue realistic programs for the elderly which will make living in their homes more viable and for whom it is the most desirable alternative, but please desist from programs that fly in the face of the realities of an alternative type of excellent care for the aged.

My greatest fear is that the path we are pursuing at the moment in relation to nursing homes will lead to a great bottling up of demand-a demand that will have to be met some time in the future. In fact, we are just deferring the cost of what has been an essential element in maintaining a standard of good, compassionate, loving care of the aged in the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is one area of policy debate that highlights the deep philosophical division that exists in this Parliament between the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties, it must be the policy area in the Bills that we are debating today; namely, the Home and Community Care Bill and the Home and Community Care (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill.
—We are supporting the Bill.

—The honourable member for Richmond will get his turn to receive some comments from me in a moment. I want to emphasise in my introductory comments on these Bills that so much of what we are talking about in terms of government support for the aged and the disabled concerns public expenditure-government expenditure-to meet the needs of those in the community who, without government support, would not be able to maintain a basic and decent standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: When we hear the rhetoric of the Liberal and National parties and their comments about small government and reduced government expenditure, they never tell us the areas in which they will make their draconian Budget cuts. They never specify that. On reading what some of their mentors such as Mr Stone and some other guiding lights have to say, we see that what they are on about is a massive reduction in the level of public expenditure required to meet the needs of the aged and the disabled. That is one of the many areas on the hit list of the Liberal and National parties should they ever regain government.

It is important that the Australian people understand that reduced government expenditure is not a question of some remote academic debate in the corridors of the Treasury. It will affect them-the men, women and children in the streets and homes of Australia.
