They are on the hit list, because they are the people who will suffer a greatly reduced quality of life should draconian Budget cuts occur in this area.

I raise these general questions in speaking to the Bills before the House because I believe that the compassion of the Government in this matter and our belief in the important role of government in providing support for the aged and the disabled go to the core philosophy behind this legislation. We reject the notion that the aged and disabled should be thrown on the social scrap heap and that government expenditure in this area should be cut.

The purpose of the Bills before the House is to authorise the payment of financial assistance by the Commonwealth to the States and the Northern Territory in accordance with agreements relating to the home and community care program and to amend the four Acts referred to by other honourable members to enable the home and community care program to operate. The first object of the Government's program is to promote the provision of a comprehensive and integrated range of home and community care designed to provide basic maintenance and support services, both directly and through their carers for aged and disabled people and, thereby, very importantly, to assist them to retain their independence in the community and to avoid their premature and unnecessary admission to long term residential care. A second major aim is to expand and develop home and community care services through joint co-operation with other levels of government.

One of the basic philosophies of the Australian Labor Party is that people ought to have the right to control their own lives. This policy has particular significance for the aged and disabled people who for too long have remained in a rather vicious cycle of dependency and have not had the resources to be able to exercise that effective control over their lives. We are the supporters of the promotion of human potential and personal development of the individual to the fullest extent. While that does not happen in our community, the wider Australian society will be the worse for it. While institutional care in the form of nursing homes and other accommodation has a vital place in society for those with no other alternative, it is far more preferable that aged and disabled people be empowered to take their rightful place in the community as active participants in society. It is my hope that the legislation before us will advance that end.

I believe that in the comments made by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) in speaking to the Bills the philosophical divisions were clearly highlighted. Those of us on this side of the chamber sat back in awe when we listened to the comments made by the honourable member. We thought that this legislation and this debate were about giving aged and disabled people greater power and the right to be able to determine their own lives and adopt their choice of lifestyle, but what we heard from a prominent spokesman for the Liberal Party was a defence of the profits of nursing homes. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to examine the intellectual and economic bankruptcy of the arguments that the Liberals advance in this area. One would think that nursing homes were operating out in the free market and that they were able to provide those wonderful services to people free of government support. What the Liberals do not tell us is that each bed in each nursing home is funded from the public purse to an amount in excess of $14,000 per annum.

I do not for a minute deny the important role played by nursing homes, but let us really do what we can for aged and disabled people and let us allow people to have a real choice. I thought that the Liberal Party was about giving people the right to choose. That is what its rhetoric says but, of course, the substance and the brutal reality are that it is the greatest defender of the privileged and the haves. The Liberal Party, when in government, simply failed to do anything to defend the lot of those who were not among the privileged group in the community who have managed to make it. We reject that philosophy. Clearly, our alternative philosophy is reflected in the terms of these Bills.

In relation to the aged, it is my view that future planning of services and support facilities is vital. In this regard, I commend the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) who was Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure which delivered a report in 1982 that paved the way for so many reforms that are occurring at present. The Committee reported that the aged population increased by almost 90 per cent from 1964 to 1980 and it is projected to increase by 66 per cent over the next 20 years. It also noted that the number of old people over 75 years of age in the community-if I can describe them in that way-increased between 1954 and 1981 by 114 per cent. It is projected that in the next 20 years a similar percentage increase will occur.

In public discussion about aged persons living in the community a distinction is drawn between care in the community and care by the community. As the McLeay Committee pointed out, the former involves policy measures giving public support to develop services in a variety of community settings, while under the latter view the responsibility for care shifts from public authorities to informal support and voluntary sector activity. Again, in that regard there is a very clear philosophical difference between the major political parties. In this area the issue of the implementation of draconian Budget cuts and privatisation policies coincides with the view of the Liberal Party and the National Party.

While the support of family and friends in the community is essential for aged and disabled persons, there are many occasions when, for various reasons, that support is simply not available. We, as members of Australian society, ought to be striving as much as possible towards that kind of caring and compassionate community wherein we have extended families and linkages between friends so that support can be given to those in the community who need it. As I have said, that support is not always available. Often it imposes an unmanageable load on family and friends and, importantly, a state of total dependency which operates to the disadvantage of all parties.

It is, therefore, vital that the support of family and friends be supplemented by an extensive system of care and support and the provision of government funding and programs in appropriate areas. This is particularly important because the great bulk of elderly people require some form of social and/or medical support to maintain their quality of life. A recent survey revealed that for every 1,000 elderly people in Australia aged 65 years and over, 776 experienced at least one chronic condition and most of them suffer far more than one chronic condition. Obviously, such people need considerable support to maintain their quality of life. I place on record that traditionally it has been women who have ended up taking almost full responsibility for the care of elderly relatives. In the case of married women, surveys have chronicled the adverse effect of such responsibility on the carer's marital and family life. This is another area in society where women have been the source of unpaid labour.

There has been a growing level of community and government awareness of the need for far more initiatives to be taken to allow disabled persons to take their rightful role in the community. Support by government for the disabled is increasingly thought of not in the form of some handout that has to be lobbied for at every Budget but, importantly, as a right of disabled people to allow them truly to take their place in the community equally with other Australians. The report of the handicapped programs review, referred to by the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) is an extremely important document for the future of this country. Submissions to that review stressed that home care services should be available 24 hours a day, seven days a week and that more emphasis should be placed on home visits by occupational, physio and speech therapists. Submissions also called for increased benefits, a national attendant care program and additional respite care.

Although a number of major concerns of disabled people and their families have been met by this program and the programs referred to by the honourable member for Phillip, much more needs to be done. I know, from discussions and meetings I have had with my constituents, of the enormous financial, physical and emotional burdens which are borne by disabled persons and their families. I conclude by calling on the House and, I guess, Australia to reassess seriously our national priorities as we move towards our bicentennial year. I only wish that the Australian community gave as much support and thought to future planning for services for the aged and disabled to allow them to take their place in the community equally with Australian citizens as we give to some of the more, perhaps, grandiose proposals that are being put forward in the lead up to the Bicentenary. If only we could channel half the money that is being spent, for example, on the America's Cup preparations into meeting the real social needs of the Australian community, the bicentennial truly would be a springboard for reform, social change and social justice in our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, before I begin my speech, can you clarify for me the position when there is no Minister in the House? Is that a serious matter, reflecting upon the Government itself?
—Is the honourable member taking a point of order?
—I would like some clarification of the matter, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—The honourable member has been called to address the question before the Chair. The Chair is mindful that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is temporarily absent. There is clear evidence that his absence is of a fleeting nature. I think the House might accommodate that circumstance.

—It is a very severe reflection upon the Government that there is no Minister in the House when we are discussing important legislation such as the Home and Community Care Bill 1985 and the Home and Community Care (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985. Another point I make is that this debate has been politicised in a way which I think is quite inappropriate for the discussion of a matter of this sort. I sat through a debate last night on veterans' affairs. I had a Minister on the other side of the House hectoring me and my colleagues about a monopoly of conscience as though nobody should be reflecting upon the Government in regard to the important matter that was being considered by suggesting that the Government was in some way derelict in its responsibility, views, compassion and concern. Yet today in this debate we believe, if we listen to the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) and the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), that the only people with any concern, care and compassion are on the Government side of the House. There is nothing further from the truth. The sooner honourable members opposite start to recognise that we might have more sensible debates on topics such as this. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) started this. He said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: When this Government came to office it had before it an array of reports done over the last 10 years . . .

He implied that nothing had been done before it came to office. If honourable members, including the honourable member for Hughes, had taken some time to read the brief prepared by the Legislative Research Service of the Department of the Parliamentary Library, they may have received some elucidating information about the history of care programs from 1945 when a referendum was conducted to give the Commonwealth power to legislate for health benefits, nursing home benefits and other matters. The brief records the dates upon which specific legislation was introduced into the Parliament dealing with matters relating to the care of the aged. In 1954 the Aged Persons Homes Act was introduced by a Liberal Government. The brief goes on to say that in the 1960s and 1970s a concentration on institutional care became apparent. It records that in 1966 the capital cost subsidies available under the Aged Persons Homes Act were extended and that certain additional Acts were passed in 1969 dealing with the care of the aged and the frail, such as the States Grants (Nursing Homes) Act and the States Grants (Home Care) Act. The brief talks about the institution of those Acts, again under a Liberal Government. The Delivered Meals Subsidy Act of 1970 again was introduced by a Liberal Government. It goes on to say:
A major attempt to make home care a viable alternative to institutional care occurred in 1972 when the National Health Act 1953 was amended.

So what we are talking about in relation to a range of programs, including the programs which are the subject of some rationalisation now, are programs which were instituted by the previous Government. Some credit ought to be given where it is due. I was prepared, in the context of this discussion, to go through and look at the proposals in a constructive way and to offer some constructive comments, except in relation to the New South Wales Government, a Labor Government which appears to be unwilling to co-operate with its Federal colleagues on this legislation. It is important when we are considering matters of this sort to give credit where it is due. I note that my colleagues have taken the opportunity to refer to the constructive role of the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), who will follow me in this debate, when he was chairman of a sub-committee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure of this Parliament under a previous Government and had the opportunity of considering expenditure in the area of nursing home benefits. We saw some constructive recommendations develop in that area in a bipartisan way by that parliamentary committee. Some acknowledgement in relation to those sorts of matters is equally due.

I hope that by raising these matters in this way I can indicate my concern that we ought to be constructive contributors and not seek to come into this chamber and score cheap political points in the way in which some of the Minister's colleagues have done in this debate today. I realise that there are very high expectations of people in regard to the way in which the elderly should be able to make valid choices about the way they live their twilight years. I understand that because I see it. I have experienced it in my family. One has had to make the choices and consider what provision is going to be made. When I was a young person my parents were away from home living with grandparents who were ill and in need of care. I saw the situation in regard to their home. In their more frail periods they were not able to provide for their own needs, to get up and down ladders, clean leaves out of gutters and do all the sorts of things that need to be done around the home to enable one to live in some dignified way.

I appreciate as much as anybody else in this Parliament why we are anxious to provide that level of choice. Time and time again I have had to sit in my office, as so many honourable members would, and advise people about the way in which they should provide for themselves and consider their own frailty and the possibility of illness when they are agonising about where they might go and what provision might be made for them. I appreciate that there are many people today who would like to live in their own homes but who feel almost compelled to move into an alternative environment because they know that at the end of the day if they are ill and in need of continuous care, particularly in a nursing home environment, unless they are already in an institutional environment-an aged village or a hostel-they will not be in a ready position to obtain accommodation in their own area, close to their friends and relatives. I have seen people agonising about having to move 20 or 30 miles from their own homes and their friends because they cannot find nursing home accommodation in their district. These are the sorts of problems that beset our aged community. They have been with us for a long time. I understand that and I welcome any programs that are designed to provide services and care for these people in a more meaningful way.

However, we must also understand, as the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) has said, that people's expectations have been very considerably increased by the way in which this matter has been discussed over time. I have before me a quotation from the Press statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of 15 October 1984, dealing with this particular program after it was first announced in a Budget context shortly before an election. It was obviously intended to attract support for the Government on the basis of its care and compassion. This quotation was: `The Government would provide more than $300m in a new program over the first three years'. I recognise that the Government has changed its language since then because what it is really talking about is taking all the money that has been previously allocated for programs in this area and using that, together with the small amount that will be used to top up the program, to provide a program for $300m. But in fact it is not, as people were led to believe, a new $300m program. That is the reality. That is the hype that the honourable member for Richmond was talking about. That is why the State Minister in South Australia is so concerned about the matter. If honourable members opposite have any concern about the way in which they project these matters, they might care to look at the language used by the Prime Minister in his statement of 15 October in order to appreciate why people might feel that they have been misled in their expectations of this legislation.

I recognise that this is not a matter which has turned out to be significiantly political. I note that the Minister in his speech told us of the States that are co-operating with the Federal Government on the implementation of this new program. He said that three States-South Australia, Tasmania and Western Australia-as well as the Northern Territory had to date indicated that they would sign or had in fact signed the home and community care program agreement-that is, two Labor governments, one Liberal Government and one Country Liberal Party Government. That is an indication of the way in which this matter is being approached. It is being approached in essentially a non-political way in order to try to devise the best form in which programs of this sort can be administered. I had hoped that there would be some recognition of that. As a New South Welshman I am disappointed about that and I had hoped there would be some acknowledgement from my colleagues in New South Wales who have participated in this matter before me and, perhaps, the honourable member opposite from New South Wales-the honourable member for Grayndler-who may participate later. No, he has just indicated that he will not drop a bucket on his colleagues in New South Wales. I was hoping that he might be prepared to recognise that there are problems in New South Wales in relation to participation in this program. In a spirit of bipartisanship with the Government, I would hope that all New South Wales Labor members of parliament would urge their colleagues in New South Wales to look at this legislation in a more realistic way and to see whether some accommodation could be reached which would enable New South Wales to participate in the development of these worthwhile objectives.

There is a concern in New South Wales and this is evidenced in the Pensioners' Voice, a paper of the Combined Pensioners Association. If I remember rightly this organisation has its office in the Trades Hall, so it is not particularly critical of this Government or the Government of New South Wales. I wish to read from that paper's editorial of August 1985. This editorial is very elucidating and it should be a matter of concern to all thinking Labor members and non-Labor members in this Parliament. The editorial, which is headed `HACC under threat', says:
As the deadline for signing the State/Federal Agreements draws near the HACC Program is already at risk in N.S.W.
The N.S.W. Government has dug in its heels over what it sees as the unsatisfactory financial agreements imposed by the Federal Government.
On the other hand, the Federal Government says that N.S.W. is getting a fair deal in which to maintain and extend the State's home support services.
The wrangle has placed the entire Program in jeopardy.

The Commonwealth has already given significant concessions in the dispute. Indexation for the Program is guaranteed and the funding has been considerably broadened in an attempt to placate the State Government. Yet N.S.W. is continuing to cry wolf.

Members of the N.S.W. Consultative Committee fear for the entire Program. `While Governments wrangle, home support services in N.S.W. continue to limp along with insecure and inadequate funding' said Linda Adamson, the Combined Pensioners Association representative on the Committee.
`We certainly don't want N.S.W. to come off badly in the financial negotiations. However, the Commonwealth's promise to index the Program is a significant and welcome concession.

It is difficult to understand the skittish behaviour of the N.S.W. Government when in fact the Consultative Committee has been provided with such little information on the State's financial provision'.

Right across N.S.W., consumers and service providers are establishing HACC Forums to share information and plan for the Program. It will undoubtedly prove to be a social disaster if such goodwill and enthusiasm is rejected.
Consumers always seem to lose out. They are the last ones to be consulted about the direction of Government Programs and the last to know why a Program is about to be dumped.
The outcome of this dispute is awaited with bated breath as the future of home support services hang in the balance.

That is a very severe editorial and I would hope that the Minister would be able to clarify the situation. As a New South Welshman, I am troubled that over time we have seen tremendous problems in the relationship between the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments. Some of this is seen in the New South Wales Government endeavouring to shift responsibility, which has traditionally been a State responsibility, for the care of the mentally ill. In relation to the psychiatric hospitals in New South Wales we even see disputes continuing today as the New South Wales Government endeavours to shift mentally ill people into the hospital system in the expectation that the hospital's funding, in which there is a Commonwealth contribution, will provide for those patients. In a psychiatric environment the New South Wales Government would be obliged to provide for them on its own. We have also seen efforts to shift such patients into the community health program, under what is called `the revolving door policy', so that the State Government can reduce its involvement there and transfer that responsibility to a Commonwealth program

I notice that in the agreements before us there is an effort to try to contain that sort of shifting of further responsibility from New South Wales onto the Commonwealth and to ensure that this program is able to be directed where the need exists and not to subsidise programs which the State is already funding through its ordinary programs. I will come to that in a moment because I am concerned about hospitals and their relationship with the HACC program which I would like to develop. This approach at limiting New South Wales Government participation in areas in which one expects that services will be delivered to people in need is at a time when that Government is involved in expanding its activities in a whole range of other areas which have traditionally been Commonwealth responsibilities. In passing I just mention the efforts that the New South Wales Government made in order to get involved in film funding, which was an area in which the Commonwealth was involved. I refer also to the area of migrant services, where the Commonwealth has accepted a responsibility. In that area New South Wales made efforts to set up its own commission and its own funding lines so that it could get some credit for that. One only has to look at the bicentenary, which was mentioned by the honourable member for Hughes, who spoke of the need to look at programs in this area as having as worthy objectives as programs in other areas. But in addition to the Commonwealth's funding for the bicentennial we have that huge program in Darling Harbour complementing so many other facilities of a community nature that have been provided for the central part of Sydney as against the western suburbs of Sydney.

I think that priorities are distorted in my own State and I feel obliged to say that in relation to this particular legislation, particularly when the conflict is over financial arrangements. I hope that my comments will be something that the Minister for Community Services can use in his discussion with the New South Wales Government to get it to come to the party in relation to this. I hope that they are the sorts of comments that will enable New South Wales members, in talking to their colleagues, to say: `We are embarrassed that we have you as our colleagues when we cannot get some agreement in relation to this particular program'.

There are many other matters that I could address in relation to this legislation, but time really does not permit me to do that, particularly in view of the injunctions I have had from my colleagues to try to sit down a little earlier than I might have otherwise done. But I do want to point out, referring to clause 7 of the agreement contained in the Schedule to the Bill, some of the points I was making about the problem of New South Wales shifting responsibility. In paragraph (3) there is a reference to the sorts of services that shall be outside the scope of the program, that is:
(a) the provision of accommodation (including rehousing and supported accommodation) or a related support service; or
(b) the provision of an aid or appliance.
Paragraph (4) states:
A service of the following kind shall be within the scope of the program but only to the extent and for the period that it is eligible for funding by virtue of sub-clause 8 (2)-
(a) a rehabilitative service directed primarily towards increasing a person's level of functioning;
(b) a service providing direct treatment for acute illness . . .
(c) a service designed specifically for persons with the same disability other than a service provided to persons within the target population suffering from brain failure . . .

I caution the Minister in relation to those particular matters. I am very conscious that within the hospital environments where hospital funding in New South Wales is being contracted at this very time, many of the rehabilitation services that are conducted within hospital environments now may very well become the target area for New South Wales to again try to shift responsibility from its own sources of funding to this new program, HACC, in order to escape some level of responsibility of its own. I caution the Minister to watch that very closely.

In relation to clause 10, I note and welcome the recognition of the need for co-operation and consultation between the Commonwealth Minister and State Ministers and, where appropriate, local government and community organisations and service users-using the words of the clause itself. That is very appropriate. I simply record that there has been criticism from the New South Wales Council of Social Service that there has been a lack of consultation in relation to this legislation in New South Wales, and certainly amongst community-based organisations that is the feeling; and it is a real feeling and a real concern. It is something that I hope the Minister will keep in mind and consider in conjunction with clause 25, which says:
During the first 3 grant years the Commonwealth Minister and the State Minister shall jointly develop standard terms and conditions to be attached by the State to payments . . .

No reference is made to consultation there. That, in a sense, is disappointing. I hope that in relation to the development of the standard terms and conditions to be used for payments and agreements with local government and community organisations, consultation will also be possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I take great pleasure in joining in the debate on the Home and Community Care Bill and the cognate Bill. Since 1980 I have lived, in a way, with some of the things that are in this Bill. I thank honourable members for their generous remarks about the report of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, `In a Home or at Home', tabled in 1982. I guess that report was a precursor of many of the things that are in this legislation. When the Committee looked at the aged care area in 1981 and 1982, it found that there were two things of great interest in regard to the funding of programs for the aged in those days: That there was a demand for nursing home beds, the cost of providing which was getting out of hand; and there were many other reports that had come in over the years that recommended that the imbalance between institutional and community based services should be rectified. But unfortunately, nothing was done. Indeed, the home and community care program, which was part of a package of programs that the present Government has brought into the Parliament over the last two years, has been the first move to bring about some recompense for the imbalance between institutional care and home care.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested in what the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) had to say earlier about the advantages of nursing homes. I think that she was a little off the track when she said that the present Government's policy is anti-nursing home. The Government's policy is not anti-nursing home. The present Government's policy is about giving older Australians a choice in what to do with their own lives, because prior to 1983 that was really no choice. It is interesting to look at what was happening in the community prior to the Government making these changes. Indeed, I will quote a few paragraphs out of the Committee's report. The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) mentioned that previous Liberal governments had brought in a number of pieces of legislation that provided benefits for the aged. Unfortunately, their approach was one very much of ad hockery and, indeed, a number of pieces of legislation were brought in by the McMahon Government in a helter-skelter to the election run-up. But it is interesting to hear what people said prior to 1982 about the delivery of health and welfare services for the aged. In August 1975 the Social Welfare Commission reported:

The present basis of care for the aged and handicapped is haphazard, expensive and inadequate. The lack of support given to large numbers of aged people and the limited alternatives of institutional care available to them may in fact contribute to the accelerated deterioration of their health.
In April 1975 the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty noted:

At least some of the deficiencies in the care of the elderly can be blamed on the complicated way in which the field is administered. In any State up to half a dozen government departments can be involved, divided between the centre and the State. And even within one department affairs are by no means straight-forward.
Two years later in 1977 the Committee on the Care of the Aged and Infirm referred to:
the largely ad hoc way in which programs had been launched;
the lack of co-ordination between the effort of various levels of government and between governments and the non-government sector;
past concentration on institutional accommodation rather than on the development of comprehensive domiciliary services;
failure to develop effective assessment and rehabilitation procedures which could improve the efficiency of programs by matching services to people's particular requirements.
In 1981 the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, which was set up by the previous Liberal-National Party Government, observed that:
. . . the machinery for administering the nursing home sector is something of a maze, the key to which gives various financial powers to the Commonwealth.

The Jamison Commission went on to note that the effectiveness of the sector had been criticised by all parties involved and suggested that this criticism reflected the `ineffectiveness of the profusion of machinery to produce effective policy'. With a touch of irony, Jamison added:
. . . it was striking to observe how effective the Commonwealth financial machinery had been in shaping the nature of available services for the aged with its predominance of nursing homes.
In the report of the Auditor-General on the efficiency of the nursing home programs of the Commonwealth, he made the more general comment that:

Effective interaction between Commonwealth departments (Health, Social Security and Veterans' Affairs) in the planning and evaluation of related programs of care for the aged and the infirm is largely absent . . .
The Australian Council of the Ageing, in its submission to the Expenditure Committee in 1982, said:

Once established, there appear to have been few attempts at systematic monitoring of services to establish levels of effectiveness and efficiency in relation to clearly defined goals. This has led to haphazard development that is patchy in coverage and often dictated by needs other than those of the intended beneficiaries, i.e., the aged.

I believe that that was one of the classic problems of the Commonwealth funding of programs for the aged until the present Government came to power, because the programs tended to be financed and operated for anyone but the aged. The programs were financed by Commonwealth bureaucrats for their own empires in some instances. There were very large State and charitable organisations that were interested in getting their share of the Commonwealth dollar. All the way along the line no one asked the aged what they thought about it.

We had this very simplistic approach that nursing homes must be good for them, so they could go into a nursing home or struggle along at home unattended. What happened along the way was that the system collapsed. One of the reasons it collapsed was the increased participation of women in the work force. But no one planning the delivery of these services ever considered that. The number of women who forsook their own careers or personal lives to look after an aged parent or relative has declined remarkably in recent years. People who in the past played out the role of being a family carer no longer did so. There was an increasing pressure for some other sort of service, and the only service that the Commonwealth provided was in the form of nursing homes. That suited State governments because it cost them nothing.

One of the real problems of the nursing home program was that it allowed State governments to make economic decisions that did not affect them at all. They were very much in favour of nursing homes because they were totally funded by the Commonwealth. They were willy-nilly approving services because it was good for them; it cost them nothing. But the people who were getting the service, the elderly Australians, were put in an unenviable position. In 1980 and 1981, when I spent a lot of time visiting nursing homes around the country, it was very difficult to find anyone who happily went into a nursing home. Many of the older people talked about that lack of choice. In the package of Bills that the Government has brought into the Parliament over the last two years there is an element of choice. It is an embryonic choice, I admit, and I had hoped that that choice would have been a bit wider by now, but at least we are getting somewhere towards providing for the first time some choice for elderly Australians.

HACC is part of a program that includes hostel provisions. The present Government has provided far more money for hostels than previous governments did. It is part of a program that provides for respite care, because it was only the recent changes in the nursing home system that allowed for respite care for people in the community being cared for by a relation or looking after themselves but who needed some time in a nursing home to build up their health, perhaps to recover from an illness. In the past that service could not be provided; now it can be. In the past the alternative was to put a person into a nursing home permanently. There was no system whereby people could go in for a little while, build themselves up and come out again.

The Government has also instituted a carer's pension, which acknowledges that it might not only be an older person's spouse who provides care but it could be some other member of the family. It is amazing that it has taken governments this long to recognise what in fact happened in what people term the good old days when the family looked after its older members. At least now we are recognising that there needs to be some assistance for those people in both financial and support terms. The HACC program is of great assistance in support terms. The Government's proposals to amalgamate many of these programs will make such programs more cost-effective and it is sensible for the Government to put for the first time all programs under the control of one Commonwealth Minister. We had a ludicrous situation in the past. For instance, under the arrangements for deficit financed nursing homes the Department of Social Security could give an approval and some funding to a person to start a nursing home but then the Department of Health picked up the continuing cost of running that nursing home. There was not a great deal of co-operation between the two departments and I believe that there was a quite significant distortion of the way the Commonwealth should have been carrying out its role in the provision of care for the aged.

As other members have pointed out, it was in 1949 that the Commonwealth first took on the responsibility of providing assistance to older Australians and I do not think that up until now we have come all that far. The present Government's policy of granting a choice to people, of allowing people to have some control over their own lives, is one way of ensuring that people will live out their remaining years in dignity and that their families can feel confident that they do not necessarily have to make the horrendous choice of whether or not to put a person in an institution as there is now an alternative. The Government should be commended for that.

I do not wish to participate in the debate for too much longer except to say that the discussion on these Bills and the previous legislation that has brought forward other changes in the provision of care for the aged has made me feel that there are some benefits in being a member of parliament in that if we work at it sometimes we can get change to occur. However, we should all consider why it has taken so long for this imbalance between institutional care and community care to be accepted by the Commonwealth. A lot of it probably goes back to some of the less fortunate things that governments and we as members of parliament do. Members of parliament like to think that governments build buildings or do other things in their electorates. The old syndrome of the brass plaque has a lot to do with it. Some of us often think that to measure our ability to serve our electorate we must count up the number of buildings in the electorate. Executive governments must have thought that that was a good idea too because under previous Labor and Liberal Governments there were Cabinet decisions that anything that the Commonwealth had funded had to have a plaque on it saying that the Commonwealth had funded it. So obviously executive governments thought that there was some value in being able to tote up these buildings.

Of course, it is hard to point to a community service and say: `That is what I have been able to provide'. They are very amorphous things. We need to be a little more careful in our thinking as members of parliament and maybe treat our constituents with a bit more respect. I really do not think that Australians in the 1980s are venal enough to think that the only measure of their local representative is whether he gets another Commonwealth building provided in his electorate, or a building into which the Commonwealth has had some financial input. As we run up to the turn of the century we should be providing people services rather than buildings, and programs like HACC will allow us to do that. The aged and their lobby groups nowadays would not allow governments to get away with the things that they did in the past. I was interested to hear the honourable member for Dundas quote from Pensioners' Voice, the newspaper of the Combined Pensioners Association of New South Wales. In years gone by the pensioners did not have a newspaper, they did not write editorials and they never pricked the conscience of politicians. Had those organisations been as active in the late 1960s as they are in the late 1980s we would have had an entirely different type of service provision for older people in Australia.

I say to all my colleagues that whenever we support proposals that governments put forward we should ask ourselves whether the proposal is really going to help the people that it is supposed to help. The real problem with aged persons programs in the 1960s and 1970s was that no one was really taking too much interest in the well-being of the people the programs were supposed to be targeted to. Programs such as HACC and the changes that have been made in nursing home and hostel funding have ensured that at least there is a mechanism for reviewing every now and again whether the program is reaching its target.

In the HACC program in particular there is provision for consultation with community groups and service providers as well as the clients of the services, and I think that is extremely healthy. Any program that provides assistance to help people to make a choice for themselves is a program that should have support. I commend the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) for it.

Finally, while sitting here listening to some of the other speakers I had occasion to thumb through the report of the Expenditure Committee entitled: `In a Home or at Home'. Recommendation 7.74 states:
The following strategy be implemented:

an Extended Care Program be introduced to replace the States Grants (Home Care) Act 1969, the States Grants (Paramedical Services) Act 1969, the Home Nursing Subsidy Scheme and the Delivered Meals Subsidy;
the Extended Care Program include an Attendant Care Allowance to replace the Domiciliary Nursing Care Benefit and the Personal Care Subsidy;
the range of services to be funded be decided in consultation with the States to encourage a diversity of services to meet local need;
resources be distributed so as to achieve a basic provision in all areas rather than solely in response to submissions for funding; and
the Extended Care Program be funded through a grant without matching conditions.

Whilst the whole of that recommendation has not been adopted I think this program and previous programs put forward in this House by the Minister for Social Security and the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) have gone a long way towards doing that. I am very proud to take part in the debate today and I commend the Government for moving away from institutionalisation and towards providing community care for people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some pleasure that I rise to speak to the Home and Community Care Bill and the Home and Community Care (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill because they promise great benefit to an important section of our community, the aged and disabled. I do not think there would be any argument on either side of the House that it is really no good our striving for longevity if we cannot ensure at least some measure in that regard to the quality that that life will hold for us. Excellent initial work was done by the coalition when in government in providing some assistance to those eligible groups in the community under the provisions of the four Acts, the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970, the Home Nursing Subsidy Act 1956, the States Grants (Home Care) Act 1969 and the States Grants (Paramedical Services) Act 1969.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the inflexibility of the provisions of these Acts and the growing recognition of a great variety of additional needs in the community provided the catalyst for a series of reports as to what changes ought to be effected to accommodate these newly recognised needs. It is to the credit of the Government that it has collated the reports, important among which was the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure entitled `In a Home or at Home', which was completed in 1982. It has now produced a program which, if correctly developed, will offer an extension of services and flexibility. For this reason community organisations and other providers of services in the community are enthusiastic about the prospects of being able to provide improved services to those many people requiring them.

For country residents the prospect of institutionalising a loved one, not because it was wanted but because there was no alternative, often meant the virtual isolation of the aged person in a home many kilometres away from the relatives. Of course this situation results in less regular visits and is traumatic for the person taken away from the area which he or she has grown to know and love as they suddenly find themselves institutionalised in another environment which is completely different from what they have lived in for so many years. The decrease in the number of visits by the relatives is also a problem of great dimension. For those families and the aged and disabled there will now be alternatives which can be implemented in some circumstances but, we must remember, not in all circumstances.

The second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) submitted data revealing that only 10 per cent of aged people living at home regularly receive help from formal health or welfare agencies. A couple of conclusions can be drawn from that information. Firstly, there are a great number of families looking after their elderly loved ones and hence no need for outside assistance exists. Secondly, there are a significant number of people who are in desperate need of care and/or assistance but who are missing out at present. I believe that both conclusions have a degree of validity. Fortunately many families can provide the level of care that these people need. Some no doubt are trying to provide care at the required level, but would welcome additional support if it were available. Unfortunately the second conclusion-that people are missing out on aid-contains an element of truth. Community organisations in the electorate of Hinkler have confirmed a need for assistance to people, a need which is not being provided now because it is not covered by any of the provisions of the existing Acts.

I am delighted that the Government has recognised the importance of planning and co-ordination as an essential ingredient for the effective operation of the program. It is most important that all groups involved in the program continue to consult and be consulted to ensure that the noble aims of the program are met and continue to be met. The Government must recognise that what suits one locality may not suit another. I therefore stress that the program implementation must be flexible to accommodate local conditions and needs.

In attempting to achieve the second of the program's two main objectives-namely, to expand and develop community care services through the joint co-operation of the four tiers-it is most important that each group in the co-operative arrangement be fully informed and knowledgeable of the prevailing conditions. After all, the most important part of the program must surely be that the user receives the assistance he or she needs. Good intentions are no substitute for an informed mind. Education will therefore be an important component under the home and community care program.

The 11 sub-programs represent a significant expansion of services. Many of the community groups in the Hinkler electorate, who have provided an input to my contribution, have queried some of the terms used to describe the programs; for example, `information'. The confusion is probably conceptual in that they are unsure whether their assessment of each sub-program agrees with the Government's intention. However, I am appreciative that clarification will probably be forthcoming when the more detailed sub-program guidelines are delivered, following consultation and negotiation between the Queensland and Federal Government Ministers in regard to the Hinkler electorate.

At this point I feel obliged to digress for a moment to acknowledge the wonderful assistance given to me by officers of the Department of Community Services in Brisbane. Over a period of months they have been asked many questions about home and community care. The enthusiasm which they feel for the program is obvious in their answers and their attitude and I publicly thank them for performing an important job and doing it well. I think it is important that those people who are to help to administer the Act do take note of it and are anxious to see it implemented.

I have been asked about the `above the base' funding arrangement being distributed on a resident population basis and whether the formula would be applied intra-State on a regional basis and whether the local authority area would be the determinant of what constitutes a region. The absence of guidelines has prevented my being able to provide any accurate answer to this query, but I hope that the agreement between the Queensland Government and the Federal Government will be finalised in the not too distant future so that the specifics of the program can be sorted out and that information can then be provided to my constituents.

I recognise the importance of co-operation and liaison, this time intra-State, and between providers and users who need to work within an administrative framework which will be conducive to the speedy identification of gaps in existing service delivery. The providers of service who have been contacted by my office are in no doubt as to the shortcomings of the existing coverage but recognise that the program must maintain flexibility even while it is up and running.

One of the departmental officers in Brisbane mentioned the phrase `the dignity of risk' used by Dr Glenda Powell of Ipswich in Queensland. She was of course referring to the opportunity for our aged to stay in the community and be provided with those services that they themselves cannot manage, and yet maintain their dignity and an element of hope by being allowed to remain at home, of course mindful of any risk attached to that. This embodies the main thrust of the home and community care program.

We do not want to institutionalise people in the target groups if they can receive sufficient assistance to remain at home: We would be mindful, of course, of their respective wishes. Home and community care can now provide options which were lacking under previous initiatives.

It must be acknowledged that people may require more than one of the sub-program services, either permanently or occasionally. To do this efficiently and effectively will require a high level of local co-ordination, maximising the resources available. The involvement of local service providers in the development of a national database to enable effective monitoring of the program was regarded as most essential by those local providers in the Hinkler electorate who commented on this aspect of the home and community care program. They also agreed that the development of standards for service was complex and contained an element of subjectivity that was important.

The input from both providers and users of services will surely present both sides of the story and assist those developing a set of standards. Because of the variety of tasks likely within each sub-program, it could be a mammoth undertaking. Those service providers in receipt of Commonwealth-State funds will be most appreciative to receive written advice of what effect the introduction of home and community care will have on their operations. To date their response to the possibilities of the programs has been enthusiastic. Effective liaison right from the beginning will certainly give recognition to their work in the past and encourage them to participate and co-operate fully with the Government.

I note with pleasure the recognition that this Bill gives to service users and providers by offering them the continuing opportunity for involvement in priority setting. My only concern is about the mechanism by which these priorities are handled and determined. I know the last thing that the Government and the Opposition want is the proliferation of somewhat obscure services which squander funds but are not really what home and community care is all about. I consider that co-ordinating machinery to be very important.

This aspect of home and community care, that is, user and provider input, generated enormous interest in the Hinkler electorate. Some of the extensions to home and community care that were suggested include a home handy-person service to help the aged and disabled with house- housework; odd handyman jobs; such duties as shopping-a tried and proven service in that area under a community employment program grant but now dormant because of the lack of continuing funds-respite care to enable the family carer to have a holiday or to provide a back-up in the case of sickness of the carer; a day care centre for handicapped and elderly people where they can enjoy activities and outings under supervised care and to give relief to the relative at home who is providing care 24 hours a day; day care in facilities with fully fenced grounds for people who tend to wander and who normally live at home with relatives in order to give the caring relatives relief from the constant strain of supervision yet still provide the people with loving care; laundry services to include heavy laundry such as blankets and daily laundering for the incontinent, which is very important; and the provision of specialised diet facilities. We know that Meals on Wheels cannot cater adequately for people with dietary problems. Many other suggestions have been given to me by people through the length and breadth of the Hinkler electorate. I am very thankful for their co-operation in providing information and in displaying the enthusiasm that they have for this program.

The final point I wish to make, which is perhaps outside the provisions of home and community care, concerns the importance of communication facilities for the elderly and disabled. Some of my constituents are without a phone service or have a reduced hours service. I know that Telecom Australia is working towards solving that problem and I wish it God speed. But what I am really concerned about is the cost of phones and accessories and the absence of suitable phones for people suffering some impairment. I have seen the lengths to which some people very close to me have gone to maintain a phone facility for an aging sight impaired relative. When one is not able to see very well, it is very difficult. But when one's hands are not too nimble, it is virtually impossible to differentiate between buttons on some of those alternative phones which offer a memory facility of 10 numbers or so. If this does not fall within home and community care, it should, nevertheless, be looked at closely.

Those community groups which have been so kind, so concerned and so enthusiastic in giving me input on the home and community care program are looking forward to being involved in the decision making process and to submitting their proposals in an effort to utilise the flexibility this Bill promises to provide us. I certainly hope that they are involved in that decision making. I sincerely trust that the hopes and aspirations of these people and the many people who have worked so hard over the years to improve services to the elderly and disabled will be satisfied with the home and community care program when it is implemented. I heartily support the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin Ms W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased today to support the Government in the introduction of the Home and Community Care Bill. As many people will know, for years a number of people working in the health and welfare areas have been suggesting that the Federal Government, with co-operation from the States, should have a program which enabled more aged and handicapped people to stay in their homes rather than be admitted prematurely or inappropriately to an institution. I congratulate the Government and particularly the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) and his advisers and departmental officers, who have at last put together the Bill that we are debating.

SPEECH.PARA: Discussion has been going on in the community for many years. My experience has been that the nursing profession and others who have cared for people in the community, such as social workers, occupational therapists and others, have been saying for quite some time that a number of beds in our nursing homes could be released for people in more need of them. These beds could be released if we were able to keep in their own homes a number of aged or handicapped people who, with a little help and assistance, could stay at home and who, undoubtedly, would much prefer to do so.

The funding of this program relies on the co-operation of the States. In 1985-86 $25m of above the base funding will be available on a 3:1 matching basis for States which have signed the home and community care program agreement. In 1986-87 the amount allocated is $30m, which will be available on a 2:1 basis for eligible States. Already three States-South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania-and I think also the Northern Territory, have signed the HACC program agreement.

Co-operation between the States and the Federal Government is absolutely essential to this whole program. The Federal Government cannot on its own fund this type of program. I suggest that it is clearly the responsibility of both levels of government to involve themselves in this program. The services provided under the HACC program will be administered on a day- to-day basis by a unit in the various State health departments. Community groups will be asked to submit proposals for funding and there will be consultation with groups which provide services and with the people who use the services. National program guidelines and sub-program guidelines will be available. It is essential that the services offered reflect particular community needs and that there is a responsiveness and sensitivity to the needs of those elderly or handicapped people requiring our care.

If one asks people who are worried about becoming frail or who are concerned at the prospect of becoming dependent on others as they grow older what assistance they would need to enable them to remain in their homes, one can be sure that the suggestions will be many and varied. The Government is faced with determining a wide range of services to be assisted under this HACC program. I feel quite sure that, if in the future it is shown that there are some necessary services which are not available for funding under this program, the Government will amend its proposals and include these other services as appropriate. However, at the moment the range of services proposed is indeed very wide and extremely varied.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this? Did the Department write it for you?

—Not at all, my friend. It incorporates existing services and introduces new ones. The purpose of all these services is to enable people to remain as long as they can in the familiar surroundings of their own homes, in the streets where they may have lived for years and in the areas where they may have a network of friends, neighbours, shops and, of course, where they have their memories.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing services which the Government has been funding include delivered meals, home help, home maintenence, and day care and community care nursing. Those services not previously funded include community respite care, laundry and linen services and transport. In response to some of the interjectors on the other side of the House I just indicate that, for many years prior to coming into this place, I worked in the community with a number of people who required and received these services. Without doubt, services such as delivered meals, home help and home maintenance have enabled a number of elderly people to stay in their homes.

Those of us who have experience of men and women, whether they be single or in partnerships, who have lived in their homes as they have become very aged will know that, when those people are not able to have meals delivered or to have home help or home maintenance, many of them decide to leave their homes quite prematurely. It is not easy for aged people to sit in their homes and see the downpipes, the gutterings or the window hinges come apart when, with a little help, they would be able to have maintenance done to their homes and they would be more than happy to stay there. Delivered meals have been absolutely essential for aged people who are not able to shop, to cook and to prepare for themselves the appropriate daily diet. With this service we have seen many people being maintained in their homes. I am very pleased to hear that this service will be extended even further. Home help is a very important service which is essential for people to be able to stay in their homes. On occasions men and women will require anything from two, three or four hours help a week to be able to maintain their homes. When this help has been given to them they have been able to stay in their homes until they reach quite an old age.

The new community respite care program is also absolutely essential. As previous speakers have said, those who have cared for the aged in their homes in the past often have not been able to get any form of change or rest from this care. Often they have not continued caring for aged persons because they were not able to get relief or to have a holiday. Respite care enables a person receiving care to leave the home and enter a nursing home for a short period and be cared for while the carer actually gets a rest.

I am delighted to see the laundry and linen services included under this program. It has been my experience that, when these services are not extended to aged persons, a number of them cannot stay at home. Often, if there is just a few hours help each week with the laundry, those aged people who cannot actually work washing machines any more and who cannot physically put washing on the line are able, in many instances, to look after the rest of their homes. So this service will enable them to stay at home. I have a very vivid memory of a couple in their nineties, he blind and she very feeble, who were yet still able to stay in their home because they were given assistance with their laundry. Actually, this service was delivered by neighbours but I am now delighted to see that it will be extended still further to many other people and will undoubtedly be delivered by people who will be paid for doing it. A visit for may be two or three hours a week will enable such people to whom I have referred to stay at home. It will undoubtedly enable many people to stay in their homes longer and not take up a nursing home bed.

What we are really talking about today is supplying a much needed support service for our elderly and handicapped citizens. I am sure that most honourable members present in the House today will at some stage have heard someone, perhaps relatives or parents, discussing plans for their old age, perhaps putting their names on a list for a nursing home or perhaps selling their home in order to buy a unit in a retirement village or a unit with associated hospital facilities. I suggest that one of the main reasons for this is that people fear aging. They fear becoming frail and they fear becoming a nuisance to their families. They fear becoming dependent and they also fear being left in a situation where they cannot cope.

The services proposed in the home and community care program should help to allay some of these fears. The services will support people in their homes and they will deliver a health maintenance program so that people do not necessarily become ill while living at home. What is more, the community as a whole will benefit from having its elderly members remain in the community. What a shameful waste it is to have elderly people who are still mentally active and alert isolated in a nursing home where their accumulated experience, knowledge and wisdom are inaccessible to the wider community. Since the Government has begun to develop the notion of keeping people at home, many people within politics and within the Public Service have had an input into the development of this program. The result is that today we are seeing before the House legislation which I believe deserves support and which has been put forward by a government which is to be congratulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on this legislation with a great deal of pleasure because the care of the aged is a matter which is very dear to my heart. The Home and Community Care Bill is based upon the philosophy for the provision of programs for the aged and disabled outlined by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure in its report entitled: `In a Home or at Home: accommodation and home care for the aged'. That report suggested that it was vital that service programs for the aged be provided which would ensure that nursing homes would be available to those who need full time care and attention and, further, that programs would be adopted which would enable the aged to maintain themselves in their homes for as long as possible until such time as institutional care became necessary for them because of their state of health. Inherent in the latter proposal was that it would be necessary for there to be built up the structures of both personnel and facilities which would support aged and disabled people in the community in such a way that they would be able to live at home for as long as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: With the escalation in the proportion of aged people in the community and the demands that would be made on institutional facilities, such as nursing homes, if the Commonwealth did not promote alternative forms of aid services, both the report and the home and community care agreement are trying to ensure that alternative, less costly aid services are in place which will assist in controlling the amount which the Commonwealth has to spend on nursing homes. I really cannot argue with that. I think perhaps the more significant point is not that it is less costly but that we have to think in terms of the individual aged person. As far as I am concerned, the whole basis for supporting this legislation is not to save money, but because I believe that the extension of services to help people stay in their own homes and to live more of a normal life is the important factor. As I said earlier, I am pleased to support this legislation. I am prepared to support any move which will increase the services available for the aged in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have worked hard for your nursing homes.
—I have certainly done my very best.
—And you have achieved results.

—It is very kind of the honourable member for Gippsland to say so. When we are considering the provision of these additional services we have to be very careful to ensure that home care is not taken in isolation. There has to be a widespread and adequate support structure. There has to be sufficient finance and personnel for Meals on Wheels. There has to be home maintenance. If one is in that aged area, mowing the lawn can become an impossibility. If one is a pensioner with no other source of income one just cannot afford to hire anybody to do that. Even getting a broken window-
