TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I ask the honourable gentleman: In view of Australia's mounting economic difficulties, will he undertake that the Government at the adjourned hearing, amongst other things, into the new wage fixation principles, will seek the inclusion in the wage indexation guidelines of a new principle; namely, that there should be full discounting for the price effects of currency devaluations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position that we will adopt before the hearing to which the Leader of the Opposition referred will be determined by the Cabinet. I will not go into the details at this stage; no proposals have been put to us at this point by the Minister. But let me say this: We will be approaching not only that hearing but all hearings in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with the sorts of policies and proposals which will continue to produce in this country the outstandingly successful economic outcomes which not only are apparent in their own right but which become more starkly obvious when compared with the miserable outcomes which represented the implementation of the range of policies, including the non-wage policies, of the Leader of the Opposition when he had the responsibility for the conduct of the economic policy of this country. One of the more ludicrous features of the economic and political debate in Australia is that we have this blusterer from Bennelong who brought this country to its economic knees purporting to stand up and lecture this Government which rescued the country from the result of his ineptitude on how we should conduct ourselves.

ANSWER.PARA: The prices and incomes accord and the wages policy of this Government have been a central feature in turning the Australian economy around. We inherited from the Opposition a country which, as I have said before, had simultaneously double digit inflation and double digit unemployment, which represented more than anything else the impact on this country of the wages policy of the current Leader of the Opposition. It was the most disastrous approach to wages fixation that this country had ever seen and it is an act of unbelievable hypocrisy that, having inflicted that result upon this country, he should seek to lecture this Government on wages policy. We will continue to follow policies which will continue strong economic growth and strong growth in employment, which put us at the forefront of economic achievers in the Western world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is addressed to the Prime Minister. Will the Government press ahead with its proposed reform of the Australian taxation system following the Opposition's decision to oppose key elements of the taxation package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for this question. It is the fact, recognised not only here but around the world, that this Government inherited a taxation system which had been undermined by an avalanche of avoidance, evasion and minimisation which had been encouraged under the preceding Government. It is recognised that there is need for substantial basic reform of the tax system. At last this country has a government which, after extensive analysis and consultation, has the guts to go ahead and undertake that reform, and we will do so. By contrast, what do we have on the other side? We have an Opposition which, when in government, produced this shambles that we have inherited and which now, in opposition, is showing itself singularly incapable of achieving a responsible position in regard to tax policy. It is fascinating to look at the emerging story on this issue. Until yesterday the Opposition had said repeatedly that its vote on the tax package, other than on the capital gains tax, would be determined only when it knew the final shape of the Government's legislation. Just so we can see how recently that was the Opposition's position, let me quote from the Leader of the Opposition last week.
—Which one?

—This one here, for the time being. The honourable member would not like to put too much money on him staying there for too long. This is what he said last week. This was last week's statement of the Opposition's position on tax. On 6 November he stated: `We will make a decision on the fringe benefits part of the legislation when we actually see it. I haven't seen it yet'. So last week's position was: When we see it we will say it. But yesterday that all changed. Members of the Opposition yesterday said they would support the reductions in income tax rates, but they would oppose all means of getting there. They would take the goodies, but oppose the nasties. In case it be said that I coined the phrase goodies and nasties, I must confess that the language is not mine; it comes from members of the Opposition themselves. I want to share with members of the Government and with the people of Australia this quote from the minutes of the shadow ministry.

ANSWER.PARA: Government members-Who is the mole?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mole, one could not count them. There are so many over there who want to undermine this bloke and stab him in the back that one would lose count. There are more moles opposite than positions on taxation. Let me quote from this document because Mr Speaker, as you know, I never claim credit for something that is not mine. So the goodies and nasties phrase comes from those opposite. It is stated:

ANSWER.PARA: We can produce--
that is, members of the Opposition-

impeccable arguments for opposition to each element of the package, while not opposing the whole. However, it is important to present a face of consistency and responsibility. We therefore do not have the luxury of having our cake and eating it.
Government members-Ah!

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah, but it gets better. Here comes the language. Honourable members can see my plagiarism about nasties and goodies. They go on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The four main nasty issues are central to the package and are the main sources of funds for the `goodies'. By appearing to oppose the `nasties', while supporting the `goodies', opens us to the charge at the very least of inconsistency and more likely, of irresponsibility-in supporting tax cuts, but opposing the means by which they will be funded.

So that is the analysis of members of the Opposition, their own exposure of the hypocrisy of what they did yesterday. In these circumstances it is not at all surprising that the Opposition is totally divided on this approach to taxation. The Leader of the Opposition is known to be supportive of many of the measures which his Party now opposes. The former Leader of the Opposition has the biggest smile to be seen anywhere in Canberra. The Leader of the Opposition and the honourable members for Warringah and Denison are opposed to the new policy approach. Others in the Opposition, the third group, oppose any opposition to the revenue measures at all, and the other lot just have the pick and choose approach. The simple facts are that the current Leader of the Opposition went around undermining the previous Leader of the Opposition because he accused him of not having any firm, principled positions on any policy issues. That is how he undermined the previous Leader of the Opposition. What he is trying to do now is to straddle the wets, the dries and the rejects. In the end he is left in a position of total expedience. Let me conclude by saying that members of the Opposition can go on playing their games of wait and see and hide and seek with one another. The simple unavoidable truth is that this divided Opposition and its unprincipled Leader have made themselves totally irrelevant to the taxation debate in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to Senator Button's comments in the Senate on 11 November that both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer had been incorrect in their promises made prior to last year's election and repeated as late as April this year that interest rates would fall. Can we regard these promises as inoperative, as was the Prime Minister's unqualified promise in 1983 not to introduce a capital gains tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, would you give me a few minutes to recover from that mortal blow? The Treasurer and I have made it clear that the events that unfolded in 1984 unfolded in a way which meant that some of the indications we gave on how we thought precise-
—Ha, ha!

—The Leader of the Opposition may laugh his hollow laugh now, but it will be to no avail. The fact is that with regard to what the Treasurer and I were saying during 1984, that reference is true; things have not turned out precisely as we stated. That prediction was but one part of an unfolding economic scenario. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to look at the predictions of the Treasurer and of the Prime Minister speaking on behalf of the Government, it would be as well for him to look at the whole of those predictions and not just at one part. We predicted, not only this year but also in 1983-the Leader of the Opposition referred to 1983 predictions-that there would be an increase of half a million new jobs. The Leader of the Opposition ridiculed the Treasurer and me and said that would not be the case.

ANSWER.PARA: From the beginning of 1983, the present Leader of the Opposition predicted that the prices and incomes accord would fail. With regard to every central element of this Government's economic policy, the Leader of the Opposition said that each one would fail and would not work. The truth is that we have the best rates of economic growth in the Western world, we have the highest rates of employment growth recorded in the history of this country, and they have been achieved within containable levels of inflation. It is little wonder that the head of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, having come here and having looked at the operation of the economic policies overseen by the Treasurer, described them as brilliant.
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have had some difficulty since the start of Question Time trying to adjudicate between whether I should rebuke the cheers or the jeers. I suggest that the House settle down.

—The Minister for Health would be aware that I have made several representations to him on behalf of a family in my electorate regarding the possible resumption of the human growth hormone program which was stopped in May this year. As this program benefits several hundred children suffering from stunted growth, has the Federal Government reached any decision regarding a resumption of the program and what is the status of the synthetic growth hormone which is being developed overseas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Isaacs for his question. I am familiar with the questions that he has asked me in private about this problem. Until 29 May of this year, some 300 Australian children had been treated with a natural human growth hormone, but on that day we halted the program. This was because there was overseas evidence that it was possible that a viral disease might be spread through this natural human growth hormone. In several countries there had been deaths resulting from this disease, known as the Greutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is a rare and incurable infection of the nervous system. It was my view that this Government could take no other course but to halt that program. Since then, as a matter of urgency, we have sought to get access to a biosynthetic replacement. I am very glad to say that we have now succeeded in obtaining a biosynthetic hormone from Sweden. From the end of next month, we will be recommencing this program using this biosynthetic hormone.

ANSWER.PARA: I have to say that there is as yet insufficient data to justify making this new product available unconditionally for general use. However, it has been recommended to me by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee that we enter into clinical trials with this drug, and all 300 children under the present program will be offered participation in these trials using this biosynthetic drug.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to fund them?

—I will come to the funding point. This will cost us some 10 times more than did the natural hormone, but the Government will accept the cost involved in renewing this program. At the same time, we are working all out to get a biosynthetic replacement produced here in Australia.

—I refer the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to an answer given by the Prime Minister to the effect that the Cabinet had not yet received a submission from the Minister on possible changes to wages policy on the basis of the devaluation of the dollar. Has the Minister prepared such a submission as yet? Is he proposing to prepare such a submission to put before the Cabinet? In the light of his own concession yesterday that it may well be necessary to adjust aspects of the Government's policy if the value of the dollar remained below Budget forecast, will he inform us how long the dollar will have to remain at that level before there is any revision of wages policy and any further renegotiations of the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions prices and incomes accord?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first two parts of the question is no. With regard to the third part of the question, as I said yesterday, we will have to consider policy continually in the light of developments. At this stage, there is no intention to change that policy. As we continue on, we will continually re-assess it as things change or develop in the way in which we expect they will. At present, the Government's basic position is that the policy stance it has adopted is one which is right for the circumstances, that the adjustment to the wages policy in particular is appropriate for the devaluation price effects so that they will not be built into the system, and that by 1987-88 we will be back to the inflation rate that we had prior to the evaluation. Unless something happens later in the financial year or subsequently to change our minds about that, that is the position with which we will stick. At this stage there is no intention to change it.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst I am on my feet, let me say that I notice that the Leader of the Opposition is now talking about how he would effectively achieve discounting for the price effects of devaluation. I would be interested to know how he would achieve that, because in the deregulated world in which he would be operating if he were in government I would find it difficult to conceive how he would achieve these full price effects. Would he go along to a national wage case and argue for a full adjustment of wages to allow for the devaluation price effect?

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not be paid.

—I am presuming that there would be national wage cases in a deregulated system, which I find rather hard to envisage. If we had one, presumably, the Leader of the Opposition would argue for that adjustment. If the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission agreed that there should be a full devaluation adjustment and a full discounting for the price effects of devaluation, how would he have that enforced in the market? How would he be able to ensure that some compensating wage increase would not be granted outside the Arbitration Commission? That is the question to which the Opposition has no answer, except the answer that it had last time when it was in government. It would recreate the conditions of 1982-83 in which we had soaring unemployment, plummeting employment, declining living standards and the worst recession for 50 years. That is the only way in which the Opposition could achieve what its Leader says it would achieve if he were in government at present. We know that is the situation. The accord gives us the chance to avoid all of that by negotiating an adjustment to wages policy in a way which is simply not otherwise possible. That is what has been done. It is the most effective and appropriate way by far to do so. This country will be far better off as a result of that adjustment being made through the accord.

—Has the Treasurer seen reports of proposals by the shadow Treasurer for cut backs in funding to the States in the next Federal Budget? I ask the Treasurer: Is there any danger that the Hawke Government will adopt this advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We definitely will not be adopting that advice. We will not be adopting it because the outcome for the States which the Government secured at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meetings this year was perhaps the tightest outcome for the States for some years. It was a realistic outcome of a zero real increase in grants this year, a 2 per cent real increase the year after and 2 per cent the year after that. The fact is that the intention behind the proposals of the shadow Treasurer is to go back to the old, squalid policy of deflation-just deflate the economy and tear the guts out of it so one can handle inflation because one does not have any other policy, or handle external imbalances because one has no other ideas. That is the basis of that policy. The result would be to put very great hardships on the States. Given the fact that there is an election on in South Australia, an issue the South Australian people should ponder is that the coalition is urging the Commonwealth Government to cut back funds to the States, including South Australia. Finally getting under control the difficult position Mr Bannon inherited from his predecessor, that is, enormous fiscal imbalances, just as we inherited from Mr Howard, certainly would lead to a debilitation of the State's revenues or to increased taxes and charges being imposed by a coalition government upon the people of South Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: This is an old game played by the coalition. The former Treasurer used to try to suggest that lower outlays growth in various Commonwealth budgetary years was achieved by genuine reductions in outlays. What he did was throttle the States to try to cut back on grants to them, knowing full well that the States would then move into borrowings around the Loan Council by a whole lot of subterfuge borrowings, front end payments, lease arrangements and all sorts of things whereas when we became the Government only 25 per cent of Loan Council business was under the control of the Commonwealth. The previous Government attempted a cosmetic change in the level of outlays growth at the Commonwealth level by unreasonably squeezing the States, knowing full well that the States could not bear such a burden and that they would then balloon out their debts in their borrowing programs which, of course, they did. The rise in the public sector borrowing requirement in respect of the States throughout the Howard and Fraser years was the result principally of that policy. There was also the borrowing program for the electricity and infrastructure program, but that was for productive investment. The recurrent deficits on the States' accounts was the consequence of a foolish policy from Canberra, one which apparently, the shadow Treasurer enjoins us to repeat.

We will not squeeze the States unreasonably. We wanted them to share outlays restraints with the Commonwealth this year. They have done so. We will not be changing the deal. We will not make the people of South Australia pay more in State taxes and charges. We will not require Premier Bannon to go back to South Australia with charges induced as a result of changes in Commonwealth policy. I am sure that he will be very interested in the views of the coalition in this place which believes that his revenues ought to be cut back and that he ought to be keeping the wheels of government turning in South Australia with higher taxes and charges on the people of South Australia. I am sure that Mr Olsen will be very pleased with that policy shift.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Given the increasing upward movement in interest rates, with the notable exception of the Autralian Savings Bond, which is now clearly uncompetitive as reflected by the volume of net redemptions, I ask: Has the Treasurer now abandoned the Aussie Bond as a means of managing the Government's financial policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I have not abandoned the Aussie Bond.
—You have just cut it adrift. Ha, ha!

—The shadow Treasurer should not laugh. He never met his monetary target once in six years. He was bleeding all over the landscape. He was never able to do it. He should not laugh about any aspects of economic policy. He had better just keep quiet. This Government is running an appropriate monetary policy. I am currently reviewing the Australian Savings Bond as an instrument and its rate. It is a useful instrument, however, the Government has chosen to use other instruments primarily over the last 12 months. It is true that the Government-
—Go west, young man.

—There is the voice from under the dashboard again. The Government is running an appropriate monetary policy for the economic conditions of Australia. As the Prime Minister and I have said in recent days, we have tightened monetary policy. I indicated yesterday that I believed that domestic demand in the economy was running stronger than the Budget forecast. Of course, monetary policy will play a role in moderating that demand. In so moderating it, it will moderate what would otherwise be a potential for growth beyond the Budget forecast, which would be more consistent with our predictions in respect of the external accounts.

ANSWER.PARA: I find all these remarks about monetary policy, interest rates and inflation interesting, coming as they do from a party which has no policy on inflation or wages. I suppose that no remark demonstrates better the naivety and arrant foolishness of the Opposition than an absolutely laughable interjection made by the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party when my colleague was answering the last question. The remark was: `Without a centralised wage fixing system employers would not pay the wage increases'. I say to my friend that they would pay them with the first telephone call, as has been the case in years gone by. Does the honourable member believe that, in an economy growing this strongly, with pressure from trade unions and even the prospect of some bottlenecks in the labour market, employers would not pay because they have their eye on the external account? Is he really suggesting that they have their eye on the external account and in some way, according to their own economic model, they would not pay? Of course they would pay. That is the central, stupid, mindless, crazy tenet of the Opposition's wages policy. The fact is that employers will always pay because they have never had the cohesive strength not to. It is only by an incomes policy that one can keep that strength. Perhaps the best demonstration of the intellectual muddle which the Opposition is in was the Leader of the Opposition today speaking on television about wages. On 28 August the Leader of the Opposition said at the Press Club:

The first priority of an incoming coalition government will be to deregulate Australia's rigid and centralised industrial relations system. Freeing up our inflexible labour market is our next deregulatory cause.
Today, on a program on Channel 7 the Leader of the Opposition was asked the following question:
What about a wage freeze?
He said that if the economic circumstances required, he would do it again. He also said:
Well, our credentials on a wage freeze are immaculate. I was the Treasurer responsible for bringing in a wages freeze. Mr Hawke, let it be remembered, bitterly opposed that wages freeze all along.

That is the strength of the intellectual framework on the benches opposite. On the one hand, as a first priority, the Oppositiion would deregulate wages and have a flexible labour market, and on the other it would have the most centralised policy of all-a wage freeze. What sort of nonsense is that? Wherever one looks in the area of economic policy, one sees that the Opposition has no policy. It has no anti-inflation policy; it is in a total intellectual muddle on wages; and it is in a spiv position on tax because it wants reductions in marginal tax rates while supporting all the measures which have always made the economy rotten-a tax system which has always allowed high income earners to slip through the net. The Leader of the Opposition is the former Deputy Leader with the great platform, the Deputy Leader with the commitment to economic rationality, the Deputy with the policy commitment to market outcomes. He is now the Leader of the Opposition with no policy on wages, no policy on taxation, no sensible policy on inflation and no policy on interest rates. He is tugged, pulled and changed by the lowest common denominators in the Liberal Party. This must be the cause of great mirth for the honorable member for Kooyong, who was disposed of by his Party in seeking a return to principle and rational economic policies. Now we have this grab bag of policies coming from the Leader of the Opposition, who has given up any pretence of being a politician who is interested in decent, rational economic policy. The question, the interjection and the television remark all reveal that the Opposition will be in opposition for a long time. If the Leader of the Opposition wishes to keep asking me about what I said about interest rates after the next election campaign when I am Treasurer again, I invite him to do so with pleasure.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Mick Young, the very Special Minister of State. I ask him what new arrangements have been made by the Federal Government for increased coastal surveillance in the north of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to answer Graeme Campbell's question.
—The honourable member for Kalgoorlie paid you the compliment of also referring to you as the Special Minister of State. Perhaps you should refer to him as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie.

—There has been some Press about the question of coastal surveillance in the north of Australia in recent days. It appears that every time the National Party of Australia meets in the north and spends a bit of time in the sun, its members look around for an issue and it is always coastal surveillance. As the Treasurer just pointed out, they cannot talk about any of the major economic issues and, if they can, they remain silent about their policies. It is always coastal surveillance. The fact is that the Labor Party representatives, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, the honourable member for Leichhardt and the honourable member for Herbert, together with the honourable member for the Northern Territory-three out of the four representatives are Labor members-are looking after the north of Australia. They are looking after it very well. The honourable member for the Northern Territory has told us that he was doing his best to represent the north of Australia and he was sacked from the shadow Ministry. One can gauge from that that the Opposition does not take too seriously the question of coastal surveillance, which is one of the major issues of the north of Australia. Then Senator Kilgariff got involved when he got back to Darwin and he claimed that Australia was facing catastrophe as far as coastal surveillance was concerned. The Leader of the National Party told the audience in north Queensland that he thought the Defence Department should be running coastal surveillance and we had all sorts of predictions about what would happen.

ANSWER.PARA: Since the election of the Labor Government, coastal surveillance has been upgraded enormously because of the carrying out of the recommendations of the Beazley Review of Australia's Peacetime Coastal Surveillance and Protection Arrangements that the law enforcement agency of the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth police, should be used as the co-ordinating unit for all coastal surveillance purposes throughout the north of Australia. Those units were set up almost immediately in Cairns, Darwin and Broome to co-ordinate the work that had to be carried out. It is interesting that the Leader of the National Party, a former Minister for Defence, should tell us that the Defence Department should carry out this work. When these people go into oppositioin with all these views one wonders why they did not do these things when they had eight years in government. The Defence Department, in its evidence to the Beazley inquiry, put forward the view that it was not its role to be responsible for coastal surveillance functions. The Department takes responsibility for assisting, but in a democracy such as ours it does not see its role as that of a policeman. That is a very important aspect of the views that were put forward by the Defence Department in the conclusions drawn in the Beazley report.

In addition to that, since we have established these units in those three major centres in the north of Australia, I have visited each of them twice and held meetings with every representative of every State authority and every Federal authority in the three centres, together with those in Townsville and on Thursday Island. We operate under a user pay principle. There are meetings between Commonwealth and State and Territory authorities before each year begins so that the charter flights that have to be flown in each of the areas are agreed upon between those authorities. There has been no downgrading of coastal surveillance in this country.

Some people put forward the view that our coastal surveillance should be used to the extent that we know that we can cut off any aircraft that might want to fly into Australia. This Government, the previous Government and any future government in Australia can give no such undertaking. In June this year I was briefed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the United States of America about the problems it faces in relation to the illegal entry of aircraft into the United States. The United States spends billions of dollars on coastguards, coastal surveillance, intelligence and all the law enforcement methods that one would expect such a country to use, yet it cannot stop illegal entry. What we can do and what we have done is to invest a great deal more in the intelligence network of the Australian Federal Police by putting liaison officers in many countries outside Australia so that we can act on intelligence and stop those entries by stopping people before they leave their country of origin. For example, Exercise Lavender, which saw the arrest of many people in this country, was conducted not by intercepting lights in Australia, but on the basis of intelligence that was gathered in countries overseas by members of the AFP working with other international law enforcement agencies. That is the way to go, to cut off that sort of entry into Australia.

It is absolutely ridiculous for members of the National Party to whip up some sort of frenzy in the north of Australia and claim that the people in the north will be invaded because the Government is not doing enough. At the moment it costs the Commonwealth a little over $50m for coastal surveillance in this country-for charter flights, for use of the defence forces and for expenditure on the Australian Federal Police. That itself is kept under constant surveillance and before Christmas I will visit all the centres again. All members of parliament who represent those areas are invited to the meetings to put their views. If the Leader of the National Party and some of his cohorts who go to the north of Australia would like to talk to people who actually work in coastal surveillance operations, they would not be able to run to the Press with some of the predictions that they have made recently. In fact, a member of the AFP was made available to talk to the National Party Conference about questions of coastal surveillance in this country. It is not as if we were forgetting the issue or ignoring it. A great deal is being done but, by itself, that is not the ultimate answer. A lot of the other work we are doing in our law enforcement agencies, together with coastal surveillance, will make Australia a much safer place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In the light of Senator Siddons's comments on the Carleton-Walsh program last night that in the negotiations on modifications to the tax package the Treasurer has set a revenue limit on the concessions that he will give, will he advise the House whether that statement is correct and, if so, how much revenue he has agreed to concede.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not correct. I have not spoken about revenue at all. I saw the Australian Democrats yesterday and they have agreed to give us a letter expressing their concern about the detail, rather than the framework, of some of the taxation changes. They opened the conversation by rejecting the opportunist approach of the Liberal and National parties in seeking to destroy the Government's package by having the temerity to vote against it after the Government had secured a mandate for these tax changes in an election.

ANSWER.PARA: As they are also primarily fiscal measures, they are measures which should have the support of the coalition parties, on both the basis of the proprieties as well as the quality of the measures themselves. What we finally come down to in respect of the coalition is that it will take the reductions in marginal rates and oppose the rest. I do not know how coalition members can hold their heads up and be taken seriously after they made such a mess of the tax system throughout the 1970s. Not only did the coalition not move against the more subtle tax shelters of the kind which the Government is committed to changing; it actually left the blatant criminal schemes untouched for years. It was only under the public pressure of two royal commissions that it was forced to remove the blight of the criminal schemes from the Australian economic landscape. This Government has now taken it further to deal with the more rutted in tax shelters, the ones which Opposition members left for years to let their constituency slide through without paying their fair share of tax. Our removal of those they do not have the decency even to acknowledge. The Australian Democrats have approached us on an entirely different basis. I expect to receive a letter from Senator Chipp, and I will respond accordingly. But we are not giving away any principles, because we do have a few on this side of the House not like the sleazebags over there.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BROADCAST OF HIGHER SCHOOL CERTIFICATE EXAMINATION PAPER

TALK.START.PARA: — My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Communications. I hope that he is his usual very relaxed self today. Has the Australian Broadcasting Corporation given an undertaking not to broadcast the questions or extremely simple clues to the questions in the French paper in the current New South Wales higher school certificate exam which was also stolen and given to 2JJJ? Does this seem a more responsible attitude than its behaviour in relation to the ancient history paper, about which it claimed that any information in its possession should be broadcast? Does the Minister support 2JJJ's attitude that the only competition in our society should be for a position in the Top 10?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Prospect for his question. As Minister for Communications, I have consistently refused to discuss matters which relate to programming and news of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and it is not my intention to depart from that practice. In relation to the matter referred to by the honourable member for Prospect specifically, no such undertaking has been given, nor has it been sought. The reason that I have adopted the practice that I have in relation to programming-and programming includes news-is simply that the day that any government attempts to interfere in the editorial conduct and programming of the ABC, it is my view that this country ought no longer to have a national publicly funded broadcaster.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question raised more specifically by the honourable member for Prospect of whether the 2JJJ broadcast eroded the integrity of the exam paper, with consequent disruption to the exam timetable and students, I think it ought to be said that, as a matter of fact, the theft of the exam papers destroyed the integrity of the examinations. As a result of that theft, some had knowledge of the contents of the exams while others did not. Obviously, in those circumstances, the New South Wales authorities needed to take action to remedy the situation. The 2JJJ broadcast of itself did not breach the security of the exams, because that security had already been breached by the theft of the papers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AUSTRALIA : SUBSIDISATION OF HOME LOAN INTEREST

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Housing and Construction endorse the decision by the Premier of South Australia to subsidise, with taxpayers' money, building society home loan interest rates for six months, up to April 1986, to help him through the State election? If so, is the Federal Government proposing to provide similar subsidies to other Australians with building society loans? Or does the Minister accept that Mr Bannon's policy is just an election gimmick designed to direct the attention of South Australian voters away from the failures of the Federal Labor Government's high interest rate policies?

—Unlike the crowd opposite, the Premier of South Australia happens to have a very high degree of public support. I have no doubt that the South Australian Government will have no trouble in winning the State election in early December.
—That is interesting, but what about the question, mate?
—It is all very well for the Leader of the Opposition to talk, the famous dry leader of the Opposition who gets wetter by the hour, particularly with regard to his tax policies.
—The Bennelong blusterer.

—Yes; as the Prime Minister interjects, the Bennelong blusterer. We do not have any intention of subsidising building societies or savings banks, or trading banks for that matter, with regard to housing interest rates. As I said yesterday, the lending from savings bank early this year, and up into the first two months-for which I have records-has been particularly strong. For instance, lending by all significant lenders in the year to August was running at a record level of 336,000 housing loans. During August, the savings banks lent $622m.
—What about answering the question?

—I have already answered the question. We do not intend to subsidise savings banks or building societies, so get that right through your heads. What is more, we do not have any intention or see any necessity to subsidise building societies or savings banks loans. The commencements of housing units in Australia during 1984-85 just happen to be 153,000 in comparison to the miserable 105,000 commencements of three years ago. As far as the latest activity is concerned, in the September quarter of 1985, my early advice is that we will get 36,500 starts which is only moderately down on the 38,500 for the September quarter of 1984, the fundamental point being that the 153,000 starts that we achieved in 1984-85 was a 50 per cent increase on the miserable number that honourable members opposite achieved three years ago. The Indicative Planning Council, headed by Professor Fred Gruen, which advises me on these matters, says that we will get about 140,000 starts this year. In spite of the current level of interest rates, we expect that figure will still be achieved, as will the 36,500 starts that I am advised we will achieve for the September quarter in 1985, which shows that the yearly forecast is right on line.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that the Minister table the papers from which he was quoting.
—Was the Minister for Housing and Construction quoting from a document on public affairs?
—I was quoting from my own notes, Mr Speaker.
—Mr Speaker, the Minister has admitted that he was reading from his own notes. I request that in accordance-

—He was quoting from his own notes. If the right honourable Leader of the National Party of Australia examines the Standing Orders he will see that a request can be made only for the tabling of a document on public affairs. When a Minister is quoting from notes he is not required to table them. If the Leader of the National Party would care to read House of Representatives Practice he would understand the two-stage process that is followed in these matters.
—I present the annual report of the Australian Audit Office by the Auditor-General for 1984-85

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek to make a personal explanation.
—Does the right honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—I do, Mr Speaker, and terribly, by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young). The Minister, in his attempt to justify the reduced coastal surveillance effort in northern Australia, suggested during Question Time that I had stated that the Department of Defence should undertake the coastal surveillance effort in lieu of the Australian Federal Police. It should be recognised that a range of agencies is necessarily involved in coastal surveillance. As the Minister himself would comprehend, there is involvement by the Defence Department and by the Australian Federal Police. There is a role for chartered aircraft, a role for Norforce and a role for civilian participants. I have suggested -the Opposition parties will implement this in government-that the Defence Department should co-ordinate the coastal surveillance effort and act in a way that will bring together all those separate instrumentalities that have individual roles. We do not believe that the Australian Federal Police is properly equipped to undertake that co-ordinating function.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
