DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL INQUIRY INTO LOCAL GOVERNMENT FINANCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance which was presented to me on 25 October 1985 by Professor Peter Self, the Chairman of the inquiry. The inquiry has considered the financial position of local government within the federal system, the developing roles and responsibilities of local government, the objectives of general purpose financial assistance to local government from the Commonwealth and the processes according to which it is distributed to councils.

SPEECH.PARA: The report contains 50 recommendations. The overall finding of the inquiry is that the Commonwealth should maintain a program of general purpose support for local government, but that the character of the program should be changed in certain respects. The inquiry has found that there are considerable inequalities between local councils in respect of revenue raising capacity and basic expenditure needs and that a principal objective of general purpose assistance should be to strengthen Australian local government by targeting support to the most disadvantaged councils. The inquiry proposes that the basic amount of funds available to local government should be subject to the same real terms guarantee as applies to general revenue grants to the States. The grants would continue to be untied and would continue to be distributed by the State local government grants commissions.

The inquiry has recommended that councils be paid a minimum entitlement to be distributed on a weighted per capita basis up to a maximum of 30 per cent of total funds available. The balance would be distributed on an equalisation basis. Another important recommendation is that the Commonwealth Minister promulgate guidelines in respect of the general policies to be applied in determining grants for equalisation purposes, so that a certain degree of consistency can be attained across the States.

This report is, of course, important for both local government and the States. Because of this and the need to get consultations with those spheres of government under way as soon as possible it was released on 29 October. On that date it was circulated to all members of parliament and to State Premiers and the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory. It was subsequently sent to every local government in Australia. Before any decisions are taken by the Government on this report the views of the States and local government will be obtained and taken into account. Already arrangements are in hand for a meeting of the local government Minister's conference in early December at which it is intended to explore State and Northern Territory reactions to the report.

The annual conference of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations began its consideration of the report in Hobart this week. We will be working through that organisation in order to obtain local government views. Within the Commonwealth an interdepartmental committee has been established under the chairmanship of my Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. On the basis of that Committee's report and the reactions of State and local government I will be bringing forward to Cabinet a suggested response to the inquiry's report early in the new year. I would like to put on record my thanks to Professor Self and other members of the inquiry who worked with great energy and enthusiasm in producing such a comprehensive document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance which was presented to the Parliament today by the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) is indeed very comprehensive. It ranges over the whole area of the financing of local government in Australia and, because of that, brings into contention the relationship between the Federal Government, the State governments and local governments. The relationship is complex and one which I think is breaking a lot of new ground. It is understandable that since the last election the Minister has put the name of his Department of Local Government and Administrative Services up in lights. That has never occurred before and it indicates the degree of interest that the Federal Government is taking in local government which is created by State governments. Because of that we need to take particular notice of the political pitch of the Self Committee report as well as its financial angling.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted the Minister's comments that there are 50 recommendations in the report. It is certainly a very sizable report and I have read no more than the headings to it, but in that time I can see that no doubt State governments would have severe reservations about some of the recommendations. Indeed the Australian Council of Local Government Associations, which was addressed by the Minister on Monday, is addressing itself at some length to the propositions put forward by Professor Self. I know that Council is concerned about a number of aspects in the report because its recommendations would have an enormous impact at the grass roots level of local government. One of the recommendations referred to by the Minister in his speech today is that there be an upper limit of 30 per cent of total funds to be distributed to local government authorities according to their capacity. Therefore the remaining 70 per cent would be distributed in an equalising sense. That means it would be possible for there to be a number of local government authorities which would get nil.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not possible.
—Well, if they fall from the bottom someone moves to the top.
—There is a 30 per cent portion. Every council will get that portion.

—I am talking about the 70 per cent. It is possible that a lot will get nil. That is the point. Because of that possibility councils around the nation should be concerned. On top of that there is a considerable administrative thrust in the recommendation, which requires the Australian Council, which is based in Canberra, to be involved in a three yearly review of the base, which is taken as the current base established under the most recent Act. Every three years a review of that will take place. The Government is building up a bureaucracy, adding more to it and making judgments on it. These are things which will cost the local government associations here because they will have to bone up for it. In terms of accountability, the thrust will be to enter State politics. Here the recommendation is that State local government authorities be judged by a State Grants Commission. Some State grant commissions are equipped to do that and plainly some are not. Some have more political objectives than economic objectives, and that alone causes me apprehension.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also brings into question the method of the allocation of funds within States and the question of State government contributions to local governments which, in the past, have been variable. Some services have been offered by local governments for and on behalf of State governments, for which they have not had full cost recovery. The States have either put the weights on them and because of political circumstances they have given way, or the local governments have not followed the matter through.

The other three major concerns are these: Firstly, although the Self Committee report has recommended the abolition of rate pegging, it is highly unlikely to happen. Can honourable members see the New South Wales Government and other Labor governments walking away from rate pegging. It is one of their cardinal rules. They would never be in that; but they are proposing it. Secondly, it is proposed that the exemption to be granted to State and Federal Government property be waived. Can we see State and Federal governments coming at that? Probably the most important concern is, thirdly, that the report recommends the absorption of road grants within local government payments. This is an enormous change. In my view it will be resisted by a wide ranging number of local and State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely impracticable.

—Well, it would certainly take some working out, as the honourable member for Groom would know. Because of that the report raises a very considerable number of problems that will have to be addressed by the local government association and all the State governments in Australia. I hope that the response the Government gives to the report is practical and in the best interests of the local governments which function so well in their service to all Australians.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum``.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Halverson,Mr McArthur and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that ``States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women''.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promsicuity (The Australian 26/1/85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mrs Child,Mr Peter Fisher,Mr McGauran and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
(1) Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
(2) Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Connolly,Mr Downer,Mr Jacobi,Mrs Kelly and Mr Langmore.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the proposals contained in the Government's White Paper for the reform of the Australian Tax System in so far as they relate to the imposition of further Capital Gains and Wealth Taxes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to reject any proposal to increase the burden of Capital Gains and Wealth Taxes on the Australian people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr Ian Cameron.

PETITION.TITLE: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not `windfall gains', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business or farm to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell these assets to sustain them in retirement;
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Consumer Tax
Capital Gains Tax
Hidden Death Tax described as ``Capital Gains Tax after death''
Gift Tax
Increased Company Tax
Employer Taxes on Employees' employment benefits

All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation. They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
We ask that the increased tax proposals be rejected, in favour of lower taxes and small Government. We, your petitioners, will forever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, we the undersigned call upon all Members to pay due respect to all returned service personnel. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all changes to benefits for veterans, and conditions of service for military personnel, as announced in the May Economic Statement, be withdrawn as to allow sufficient time for sensible community debate before any veteran or service person can be unfairly disadvantaged.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Assistance Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of concerned people of Australia respectfully show their desire that your Honourable House (The Government) act immediately to raise the Tertiary Education Assistance allowance to the level of the Unemployment Benefit.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of State Arts Councils
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the current policies of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council are disadvantaging rural residents with regard to access to the Arts.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organisations to maintain access to performing and other arts activities in country areas, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
1. That the handing over of Ayers Rock and associated environs is damaging to our country, and will divide this country causing racial prejudice.

2. That to have His Excellency, the Governor-General officiate at the handing-over ceremony can be damaging to the office and position of Governor-General, and may leave His Excellency open to criticism.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:

The handing-over of Ayers Rock and associated environs to any Aboriginal community should be postponed, until a national referendum be held concerning the matter, and that His Excellency the Governor-General be asked not to officiate at the ceremony for fear of his position being damaged.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, the Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the recent cuts announced in the Mini-Budget to Day Care Services are a reversal of A.L.P. policy to make child care services available to all at an affordable cost. Further, that the fee rises arising from the cuts will cause great hardship to the majority of families using these services. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal funding to children's services in Australia, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
That pensions be adjusted fully to reflect the total increase in Consumer Price Index (CPI); and
That the ceiling for pensioners incomes be increased to provide for an adequate `living standard', before any consideration is given to the introduction of reduced pensions and the fall of benefits.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that action be taken by the Government to implement these proposals immediately and not Nov. 1986.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled.
The Petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the brumby declared a protected species.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House follow the example of President Nixon in the U.S.A. by declaring our wild horses protected from industry and discriminate slaughter.
And your petitioners, and in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlement prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic Communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Highfield Estate, Stanley, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth; that your petitioners submit that the Government take urgent action in the matter of the complete restoration of the Highfield Estate in Stanley, Tasmania, and that all necessary funds be allocated forthwith.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that these actions be taken in order to preserve for future generations of Australians, a major and nationally significant historic site.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 percent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Goulburn Post Office: Ramp
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is a great need for an access, in the form of a ramp, to be provided for the elderly, disabled and parents with young children, at the Goulburn Post Office, Auburn Street, Goulburn.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will ensure access, in the form of a ramp, is included in the restoration of the Goulburn Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has announced its intention to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, currently the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government has no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in this manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but is handing over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (ie, set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to prevent this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Cobb.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon its ill considered capital gains tax proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Sharp.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Entertainment Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Gilmore electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's total disallowance of tax deductibility for entertainment and hospitality expenses will unfairly penalise Australian business and cost thousands of jobs for young and unskilled people.;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Abandon its total ban on entertainment expenses and allow tax deductibility for legitimate and necessary expenses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Sharp and Mr Slipper.

PETITION.TITLE: Brewarrina Television Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain concerned citizens of Brewarrina in the State of New South Wales, respectfully showeth:
(i) The town of Brewarrina is in an isolated part of `Outback' Western New South Wales. It has a population of 1500 people with a substantial Aboriginal Population.

(ii) Currently, the town and district receive only A.B.C. Television from a ground station situated on Mt Oxley. The town and district does not receive any commercial television service either by way of Satellite or ground Station; and other communications are limited to one A.B.C. regional radio station and one limited Community Radio Broadcaster.

(iii) With Aussat to broadcast commercial television shortly, the surrounding towns of Bourke, Goodooga, Lightning Ridge and Walgett are to receive a repeater/receiver ground station provided at the expense of licensees broadcasting the commercial television. The town of Brewarrina has been completely left out, so it seems.

(iv) Information emanating from the Department of Communications (albeit conflicting information) also indicates the possibility of the present ground station situated on Mt Oxley relaying A.B.C. Television could be replaced by Aussat and thus a weaker signal, resulting in Brewarrina being completely deprived of any television.
(v) As Brewarrina is an isolated area of Australia, it is vital that it receives communications from the rest of Australia and thus television is an important part of communication within Australia.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House call upon the Government to:
(a) provide an Aussat receiving/retransmission dish to the town of Brewarrina and district thus providing a commercial television service to the town and district; and
(b) not reduce any current television service to Brewarrina and district.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the parents and friends of the students of Blackwood (S.A.) kindergarten, respectfully showeth that we deplore the proposed cut-back of funding for pre-schools and child care in the mini Budget. This proposal adversely affects young families, women's employment prospects and children's development in their most formative years.
We urge you to increase rather than cut funds to children's services.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Patients
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85% of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that doesn't exist.
We request that the Federal Government:

(1) alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care.
(2) restore the review of the benefits rates in November 1985.
(3) resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interest of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout the A.C.T. respectfully showeth that the Australian Government reconsider the cuts to funding of education in the Australian Capital Territory announced in the economic statement in May 1985. The proposed cuts are too severe to be sustained by an educational system that has had no increase in funding in real terms over the last ten years.
The undersigned deplore and oppose the announced cuts to funding and consider if reductions of expenditure are unavoidable these should be achieved in non-staffing areas.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right of Work on behalf of all Australians.
(2) That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
(3) That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
(4) That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
(5) That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
(6) That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test; That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas; That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian; That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And you petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Fisher respectfully showeth: That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains tax
Hidden Death tax described as ``Capital Gains tax after death''
Gift Tax
Increased Company tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits.
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
We ask that the tax proposals be rejected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth that:
The ban by the Hawke Socialist Government on negative gearing and restrictions on property depreciation will adversely affect thousands of disadvantaged people who rent their homes.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
End its ill-considered and discriminatory policy on rented property and allow depreciation on all buildings used to produce rental income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N. A. Brown) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Wages/Prices Accord and its effect on Australia's deteriorating economic performance.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever there were any doubt about the sickness in this economy and any doubt about the way in which the economy is presently being managed in this country, that doubt must surely have been dispelled yesterday when we got the balance of trade figures and the current account figures for October. As the House is well aware, those figures showed a current account deficit of $1.6 billion, an increase of $575m over the figures for the previous month, September. But it is worse than that. If one looks at the balance of trade figures for the previous four months, one sees that there was a decline of over $1.3 billion in the four months to October 1985. When we look at what those figures represent and what stands behind them, they make a number of things plain about the state of the economy. They make it plain to us in the first place that we are selling less overseas and producing less that the world is able to or wants to buy. We are importing more from overseas. As a result of the process under way the value of our dollar is falling and our interest rates are going through the roof.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the cause of this sickness in the economy that has now become all too apparent to all Australians? What is the reason for this maelstrom which has visited itself upon this country? We know that if we ever want any answers about the economy the Government tells us to look at what it calls the foundation of Australia's economic management. What is the foundation of Australia's economic management? It is the prices and incomes accord. When we ask questions about the economy, the Government tells us to look at the accord and we will see the marvellous achievements of that accord. If we want to know anything about the health of the economy or what has caused it, the Government tells us to look at the accord. The Government's case is that the wages and prices accord that it has negotiated with the Australian Council of Trade Unions constitutes, in its words, the foundation of Australia's economic management. That is the first point: We know where to look.

We have three points to make about the wages and prices accord and the effect that it is having on the Australian economy. The first point is that the successes claimed for the accord by the Government have been greatly exaggerated. The second point is that the accord is producing an economic disaster for this country. The third point is that the accord will go on producing an economic disaster for this country if it is not renegotiated and changed and if it remains as it is, as part of a crazy centralised wage fixing system which continues to force into our wage structure wage increases which individual industries and individual employers cannot afford to pay. If it is allowed to go on in that way, our balance of trade will become worse; our industries which have the final vestiges of any chance of competing overseas will continue to suffer and so will the entire nation. We say that it should now be beyond doubt and beyond argument, as seen in recent events over the last few weeks in this country, that what is needed at the very least is a change to the terms of the Government's wages and prices accord. What would be better would be to abandon the whole thing.

Those are the basic three points we wish to make. May I elaborate on each of them in turn. The first is that the successes that the Government claims for the accord have been greatly exaggerated. What does the Government say that the accord has produced? I will refer to a publication produced at government expense to tell us what the accord has produced. What do we find when we look at this government publication, illustrated with a Superman cartoon in the simplistic way that the Government uses to put these points across? What astounding proposition do we find set out as the result of the wages and prices accord? According to this publication- I quote its exact words-we have `an unparalleled economic revival'. That is what the book says. If it had said an unparalleled economic disaster, it may have come closer to the point. But the publication tells us in more detail and in extraordinary words what are the results of the accord and the processes that have flowed from the implementation of this accord. What are the results? The answer, according to the Government's claims in this publication, is:
This makes Australian goods more competitive, both overseas and at home, as they become relatively cheaper than foreign products.

Who could possibly maintain such an outlandish proposition at the time this publication was written? Who would have the gall not to recant from it in view of the latest figures that we saw yesterday? No one in his or her right mind could make such an absurd claim about the state of the Australian economy in the light of recent economic statistics, in the light of the interest rates that we see and in the light of the rising inflation rate. In the light of any of the economic statistics that we have had visited upon this country in recent months anyone who makes that sort of claim about the Australian economy is a complete fool; either that or a person who is making such a claim is endeavouring to mislead this Parliament and the Australian people. The plain fact which we have now seen from the figures and are aware of from our own knowledge is that our goods and industries are not becoming competitive. They are not becoming competitive so far as trade overseas is concerned and they are not competitive at home. How can that be when our inflation rate is twice that of the United States of America and three times that of Japan? It is a completely false assertion and, in our submission, it makes out, beyond any shadow of doubt, our proposition that the claims made by the Government for the success of this accord are grossly and deliberately exaggerated.

As if this were not enough, the Government goes on and says: `Let us do it again. Let us have another accord. Let us have accord mark 2'. In the course of mark 2 what did the Government say about that? Again I am reading from the actual document, the agreement between the two parties. Do honourable members know what the Government says the accord is producing? I ask them to listen to this. The document states that it is `producing reduced inflation'. I thought, when we looked at the figures, we would see that the inflation rate was going up, not down. Believe it or not, this document goes on to say that the accord has `produced improved international competitiveness'. How could such an extraordinary claim be made by anyone who could read the most obvious statistics? How could such a claim be made by anyone who is in communication with industry, trade unions or anyone else? The claim is outrageous, it is exaggerated and it is utterly false. The accord is not giving us improved competitiveness; it is giving us less competitiveness and our industries are suffering as a result.

The Government goes on to say that the accord has brought about employment improvement. It is true that in some fields there has been an increase in employment but it is about time that the Australian people looked at the detail of what is actually happening in employment growth in this country as a result of the Government's policies. In the export industries and in those industries where we make things which we should have some prospect of being able to sell overseas, employment is going down. In the 12 months to May 1985, the figures which I have access to, employment in the rural industries declined by 0.9 per cent. In the mining and export industries employment is down by 6.3 per cent, in manufacturing it is down by one per cent, in power generation it is down by 11 per cent and in transport it is down by 0.4 per cent. Those are the areas of the economy where things are produced, where we should have a prospect of being able to make things which the rest of the world wants to buy and is prepared to sell. In all those areas, without any exception, there has been a decline in employment. No doubt the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) will get up and say: `But there has been an increase in employment in recreation and in community services'. There has been an increase in employment in those areas where the Government either puts people on the payroll or pays for them. That is the trend which is emerging-a trend of employment diminishing and drying up in all those industries where we should have a chance to make things which the rest of the world is prepared to buy and be able to make them at prices that the rest of the world is prepared to pay. But there is a decline in employment in those areas and an increase in employment in those unproductive areas which do not produce things that the rest of the world wants to buy.

The Government has said that there is a decline in industrial disputation. It has said: `Look across the national landscape and you will see that we have a situation where strikes have almost gone to sleep', and it cited the statistics of the decline in man hours. I do not want to take up the time of the House for too long in dealing with individual statistics but I want to put to the House one statistic which is a basic proposition. Let us look at the situation in the 12 months before the accord came into operation, which I think is a fair test. There were 1,819 major industrial disputes in Australia in the 12 months before the accord. What about the first 12 months operation of the accord itself? There was an increase to 1,923 industrial disputes. So the number of industrial disputes in this country has increased and not reduced while the wages and prices accord has been in operation. That is what has been produced as a result of the accord.

When we put it altogether we see that we have a decline in what we produce and what we can sell overseas; we have prices that the rest of the world cannot afford to pay; we have enormous trade deficits and a falling dollar; and, as a result of the carry through of those policies, we have astronomical interest rates. We have, as I have just said, employment moving into those areas which are not the productive areas that we should be looking to. All this is fuelled by what the Government calls the foundation of Australian economic management-its wages and prices accord. We say that it is time the Government has another look at it. It is time that it either abandons or renegotiates the accord to put some more realism into its terms.

Our third point is that the Government will continue to produce a disaster while the accord remains with its present terms and conditions. The Government will continue to produce a disaster while there is anything less than full discounting for depreciation of the currency. It will continue to produce a disaster while it stands by and lets the union movement drive a coach and horses through the terms of the accord and bludgeons compulsory superannuation agreements out of employers and out of this economy in complete breach of the terms of the accord. Let there be no doubt whatsoever that that pursuit of union-controlled and employer-financed superannuation schemes is a direct breach of the wages and prices accord.

Our complaint is that the Government will do nothing about this. We say that it is not too late for the Government to act. Even at this late stage it can take steps to go to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and say: `There are industries which simply cannot afford to have forced into their wage cost structure the 3.8 per cent increase'. It may well apply to all industries, but at least there are some that still have a vestige of competing internationally and that should be given a chance of producing goods and services that the rest of the world wants to buy and will buy if the price is right and if we get our cost structure under control.

We say to the Government that that is what it should do. But, above all, the Government should have the productivity case deferred because that cannot help but exacerbate and make much worse the very situation we are complaining of today. The Government should renegotiate the award with the Australian Council of Trade Unions if it wants to continue with the accord to provide for the very thing that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) promised in his Budget Speech-full discounting as a result of the de- valuation of the dollar.

Above all, we want several things which are even more important than that. This country needs a wage fixing system that takes account of the prices of what we produce; one that does not impose wage costs on industries that industries cannot afford; one that does not impose on employers and also employees-let us not forget the employees who work for those employers-wage costs which those employers and those businesses cannot afford to bear; one that is more sensitive to the world of reality; and one that does not impose wage costs on all industry across the board irrespective of whether an industry can afford it. We want more realism, more flexibility and more reality in our wages pricing system so that this country can compete again and, before it is too late, be given a chance to survive. But, above all, this country needs a new government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Every time we hear any economic statement from members of the Opposition these days it demonstrates once again what economic cretins they really are and how they have learned nothing from their experience in government and from the period that they have been in opposition. Rather than having, in the terms of the matter of public importance, a deteriorating economic performance, this country has been experiencing extremely strong economic growth and indeed has been performing in a way which was described by the Secretary-General of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development only a few weeks ago in this country as brilliant. Those circumstances hardly accord with the situation of a deteriorating economy.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a list of successes for this Government in respect of all the major areas of economic indices which the previous Government would have given its eye teeth to have had. Never in its whole seven and a quarter years in government was it able to achieve anything remotely resembling what this Government has achieved in its period in office. The previous Government, in its seven and a quarter years in office, had an average rate of growth of 2.3 per cent. This Government has had two years of growth of 5 per cent and will have another year of about 5 per cent of growth with the way the economy is going at present. In the employment area, we have had an increase of 460,000 jobs in 2 1/2 years. Employment in Australia is currently growing at the fastest rate of any country in the Western world. Is this an economy with a deteriorating economic performance? It is quite obvious that members of the Opposition are so bereft of economic policy that they have resorted to absolute make believe. They are out there in their own little world pretending that things are totally different from what they are. We just saw that in respect of the employment figures. They are just making absurd statements about employment.

Faced with the fastest rate of growth of employment of any country in the Western world, they are now trying to say that it is not really occurring in all sectors. They particularly went to some sectors and said: `There has not been employment growth here'. In fact they are not even right about that. Let us look at some of those sectors. The latest figures we have on an industry basis are for August 1985. In the last 12 months in agriculture there was growth in employment of 3 1/2 per cent; in the mining sector, another sector referred to by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), there was growth of 9.9 per cent; in transport and storage, another sector which the honourable member pointed to as showing a reduction, there was growth of 5.9 per cent. The figures that members of the Opposition are producing are just out of their own make believe world; they are just not true. I have not had a chance to check them all, but I can say that all of those figures are quite wrong. The bottom line is that we have had growth in employment over the last 12 months to August of 2.8 per cent. We have had an increase of 462,000 jobs in 2 1/2 years and that dwarfs the amount of employment growth under the previous Government of about 340,000 jobs in seven and a quarter years. Yet members of the Opposition tell us that we have a deteriorating economic performance. It is just absolutely absurd. Unemployment has come down from 10.2 per cent when we took office to 7.8 per cent now.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition made a lot of noise about competitiveness and referred to wages and other factors. Let me just say a few things about that. The rate of wage growth under this Government has been historically rather low. Under the accord, in the 1984-85 year we had the lowest rate of growth in average weekly earnings since 1967-68. The year period June to June had the lowest rate of growth, 3 1/2 per cent, that this country has seen since 1962-63. Yet members of the Opposition tell us that we have got an accord which is producing too high wage increases. What absurd nonsense it all is. It is absolute make believe out of their own tiny minds in some sort of make believe world which has no relation to the realities facing this country at all.

We have seen a tremendous reduction in real unit labour costs. An index has been published by Treasury. That index, which reached 108.9 in 1977-78, was 107.2 in 1982-83, with the base of 100 being the late 1960s and early 1970s. That has now fallen to 97.8 in the June quarter, which is a tremendous reduction below the level it was in the period of normality picked by Treasury-the late 1960s and early 1970s. We have had a reduction from 108.9 in 1977-78 to 97.8, below the 100 per cent base line for the late 1960s and early 1970s. So real unit labour costs have been dramatically reduced. The flip side of that is that profitability of industry has considerably increased and is back at levels which are higher than at any time under the previous Government's period of office. That is providing the basis upon which we can get increased investment and increased recovery of the economy.

We have been told time and again by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that there was a terrible loss of international competitiveness under this Government and that we were totally unable to compete. He was using the balance of payments figures for that purpose. I say to the honourable member for Menzies that the Treasury publishes-he would have no knowledge of this of course, but I will tell him for his own edification; I see him trying hard not to listen-three indexes of international competitiveness. They are indexes of wage and price changes compared with those of our trading partners, adjusted for exchange rate movements. If the honourable member would like to know where to find them, he can look at page 28 of the October 1985 Round-up economic report of the Treasury where he will see those indices. They all show a dramatic increase in the international competitiveness of this country. If honourable members look at the figures, which are based on the gross domestic product deflator, they will see that that has come back from a high of 112.8 in 1981-82 to an index of 100 in March of this year. It would have improved considerably since that time with the further devaluation.

The unit labour cost index of competitiveness had its peak of 118.7 in 1981-82. It was back to 108 in March this year and would have fallen considerably since then. The consumer price index deflator was 107.8 in 1981-82 and was back to 93.3 in March 1985. So looking at two price indices and a wage index on an internationally comparable basis, adjusted for the exchange rate variations, and looking at our trading partners, our international competitiveness has dramatically increased. It is just nonsense and absolute make believe for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to be parading around the argument that there has been a massive deterioration in our international competitiveness. It is a total distortion of the truth and he knows it. If he does not know it, he ought to. I say to the House that this Opposition has not only got bad economics, but also shows an absolute disregard for the facts. This is becoming increasingly reprehensible in my view because it happens so often it cannot be an accident. Members of the Opposition completely make up figures or use false figures to distort the realities. I believe that they are losing credibility massively by doing that, not only because of the idiocy of the things they are saying, but because of the falseness of the things they keep saying.

The inflation rate came back from over 11 per cent when we came into office to just over 5 per cent. The inflation rate has increased again because of the devaluation effects but it will come down again as the appropriate adjustment to wages policy is made, as it will be, which will get us back to an inflation rate of 5 per cent by 1987-88. Honourable members can look at the deteriorating index in relation to the balance of payments. They will see that there is concern there.

Let me say a couple of things quickly about that matter. Firstly, obviously our international balance of payments figures have been affected by very bad terms of trade. That is why our farmers are facing deteriorating real incomes and export prices are bad for rural and mining commodities. That is not a fault of this Government; it is just something that reflects the international prices and cannot be laid at our feet. As a result of the increased growth of this economy, the fastest growth of any economy anywhere in the Western world, we have had some increase in imports, which has exposed and added to the balance of payments weakness that was being hidden by the recession. With growth, it has now become obvious that there was this weakness in the balance of payments and the devaluation was therefore forced upon us. With that devaluation there is then a capacity for that balance of payments problem to be overcome, so long as the appropriate adjustment is made to wages policy to ensure that the inflation effects of that devaluation are not built in. In our view the Australian Council of Trade Unions-Government wages agreement gives us the appropriate adjustment to wages policy by ensuring that we have 2 per cent off the next indexation case, the postponement of the implementation of the productivity case and a very extended implementation of its outcome.

Let me say that in all discussion on this matter the Government believes that it has made the quite appropriate adjustment to its wages policy, but it believes that this nation also needs to consider very strongly the alternatives that would be facing it without the prices and incomes accord. What would we be doing now if we did not have the prices and incomes accord to overcome the price effects of the devaluation? I say to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that we would be indulging in policies which would be gravely damaging to the economic welfare of the Australian people, because there would be no alternative but to deflate the Australian economy very considerably. That, of course, is what the recession-oriented Opposition wants us to do. The Opposition does not go around saying that, but that is really its underlying policy. It is an Opposition of recession. Its policies are based on recession. It controls unions by creating economic recession. It controls inflation by creating economic recession. It corrects its balance of payments by creating economic recession. It does everything on that basis.

The coalition when in government went around the country implying that we had a beaut economy because we had soaring unemployment and declining employment and it seemed to think that that was terrific. It showed time and again in its period in office that it had no alternative policies to its policy of whacking the economy every time inflation reared its head, forcing more unemployment, creating more economic recession and bludgeoning the economy back to some lower inflation level, but at enormous economic and social costs. The accord gives us the capacity to avoid that.

The Opposition is now saying that we should simply go to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and demand full offsets for inflation. We say that we have full offsets in the sense of the combination of the discounting and the productivity case adjustment. If the Opposition were to go to the Arbitration Commission and say `We want to have full discounting' and if the Commission were to accede to that request, how would it then stop wage increases from occurring out in the field? There would be no accord and there would be only one way to stop it and that would be to bludgeon the economy down, to increase taxes, to have much higher interest rates, to force more unemployment and to control wage increases and outcomes. That is what the Opposition would do.

This morning the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) talked about how he would perhaps even contemplate another wage freeze. That is an incredible proposition to come from him. He has told us time and again since he came to office that the No. 1 thing that the Opposition would do would be to deregulate the wages system in this country, because that was the absolutely basic thing that had to be done to get the economy back on a proper footing, as the Leader of the Opposition puts it. Yet now the proposition has been floated that instead of a deregulated system we should have the ultimate centralised system-a total wage freeze. That is the absolute and total antithesis to a deregulated system.

We have the absurd situation that just a few months ago a Liberal leader was elected who proclaimed to the nation that the first and most important thing he stood for was a deregulated wages system, and yet a couple of months later he has walked away from that. He is now talking about the most totally centralised system that this country could possibly have-an absolute wage freeze. So the Opposition is in total chaos on the issue of wages policy as it is on every other aspect of policy. It has no idea where it is going. Not only is there an absurdity in the sense of there being no consistency but also there is an incredible credibility gap. How would the Opposition enforce a wage freeze? How could we have a wage freeze without the economic conditions of 1982-83? Do honourable members opposite really think that we could have a wages freeze in 1985-86 with the economy going the way it is? Do they think that they could go the Arbitration Commission and say `Do not award any wage increases' and nothing would happen in the field? Of course that would not be the case. That would be an absurdity. There would be no possibility of having a wage freeze in the circumstances of strong growth.

We now have strong growth and historically low levels of wage increases given the present economic conditions. That is something that the Opposition could not possibly achieve. So we have the absurd situation where there is total confusion in the Opposition with regard to policy. It is propounding a policy that it could not possibly deliver unless it recreated the conditions in 1982-83 when we had the worst recession in 55 years. That is what the Opposition's policies imply it would do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever a cruel deception has been perpetrated on this country, it is the awakening monster we call the prices and incomes accord. In some ways what is going on now is worse than what went on in Australia between 1972 and 1975. Honourable members will remember that those were the years when we saw the recklessness of the Whitlam Government ravish and rape our economy. Inflation rocketed from low levels, the deficit blew out and, saddest of all, unemployment in this country took a quantum leap from tens of thousands to hundreds of thousands, and we have yet to recover from that madness.

SPEECH.PARA: What some people do not realise is that a similar debauchery is going on in Australia today. The magnitude of mismanagement is only marginally below that of the Whitlam wildness. It is merely papered over by a veneer of Orwellian newspeak, whereby certain words have been kidnapped from the English language and their meaning has been altered or reversed. For example, I refer to the word `consensus', which, as we know, is all con and no sense. The Government uses other expressions such as economic growth when it speaks of the so-called 410,000 jobs it has created. That has been done on borrowed money, with the highest per cent of those employed going into the Public Service. Every government that has ever existed since Federation, with the possible exception of the Whitlam Government, has created that number of jobs. The last coalition Government created-if that is the word-well over 500,000 jobs.

We have heard other expressions such as `economic curves'. When the economy was taking a dip at the beginning of the year, we heard about the V curve, meaning that the economy would bounce straight back up. When the dip was prolonged, the curve blew out into the U curve. In the last fortnight we have been told about the J curve. Undoubtedly, next month we will have the L curve, when the economy collapses and stays flat. Probably at the beginning of next year, we will have the I curve, when the economy will plunge inexorably into a Third World oblivion.

Another Orwellian word is `summit'. At a summit policy is put to the Australian people and it goes flat. The most insidious of all is the accord. Under the accord union members are fully compensated for the effects of the deteriorating economy while everyone else, including and especially the unemployed, has to pay for it. It locks us into a wage price spiral.

We now have the highest spending government that this country has ever seen and the highest deficits. The last three deficits under this Government are the three highest in this country's history. Those three alone add up to over $20 billion. Interest being paid out is approaching $1 billion a month. We are rolling over our loans at higher and higher interest rates for shorter and shorter terms-terms of months instead of years. We have now entered the league of Brazil, Argentinia and Mexico. It is appropriate that I mention Mexico because the Mexican Treasurer was the last person to get the medal for the world's greatest Treasurer before our Treasurer-our Chinese Treasurer, Mr Keating- did.

Given that mess, what did this Government do? What was its answer and solution? It abolished the wages pause and replaced it with the accord. It told us in further Orwellian newspeak that this move would restrict and moderate wage increases. In practice, what has that meant? It has meant three things: Full, or near full wage indexation; the continuation of pushes for increases in several of the wage on-costs outside the accord, such as the redundancy agreements, fewer hours, superannuation claims, et cetera; and wage rises for things such as productivity. So, under the accord, when the consumer price index goes up, wage rises will follow. This pushes the CPI up again and we get more wage rises. So what choice do employers have other than to shed labour and install more machinery? This pushes up their productivity and so there is a push for even more wage increases for productivity increases. How crazy that is! However, while all this is going on others overseas are passing judgment on our dollar, which has been falling. When our dollar falls imports become dearer, the CPI goes up again and then, guess what happens? Messrs Kelty and Crean-that is a good title for them because they are messers-ask for wage rises to compensate for those events. To avoid this nasty the Government has artificially jacked up interest rates so that the unions will not put pressure on the accord by asking for those compensatory rises.

The trouble is that the Government has so much of its credibility invested in the accord that, even though every economist in this country worth his salt realises that the accord is stillborn, the Government still will not take the necessary action, reach for the scissors and cut the umbilical cord of its baby. To avoid the temporary embarrassment of this nasty, the Government has pushed up interest rates to over 20 per cent. This attracts overseas money into Australia and stops our dollar falling even faster than it otherwise would. However, one would think that the Government could see that it is creating an even bigger monster further down the track by following this course. Real interest rates are at the highest level this country has seen for over 50 years. Madam Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing interest rates from the year of Federation which clearly demonstrates my point.
