TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Businesses which have money borrowed now are using their whole cash flow just to service these high interest rates. Investment in this country is drying up rapidly. Labour is starting to be shed again in numbers reminiscent of the Whitlam regime. All this is happening largely because of the accord. If the Government does not reverse this policy soon, Australians will end up being better off living in South America. The international judgment that overseas investors are making of the Australian economy is horrific. The value of our dollar has come down from parity with the United States dollar to about 66c in the last year. This is giving only marginal help to our exporters because overseas prices are depressed and our costs due to imports are rising. The net effect is negative.
—What would you do?

—We would use sound economic management. The value of our currency has fallen by 33 per cent against the Japanese yen, and Japan is a country blessed with no natural resources, such as Australia has. Our trade weighted index has slipped below 60, and our Treasurer tells us that we are doing well. I do not know what he would say if we were doing badly. Our inflation rate is twice that of our trading partners. We are working less hours than they are. We are working a 38-hour week which is decreasing to 35 hours. One should compare our situation with that of Switzerland and Japan whose working hours are now rising to 42, 44 and 45 a week. Our on-costs are horrific. We have the highest penalty rates in the world. We have the most leave in the world-four weeks. We are the only country in the world which has a 17 1/2 per cent leave loading. We have two weeks of sickies, the best long service leave in the world, the highest redundancy pay, which has just been introduced, and generous superannuation. The list goes on. We should be winding back these on-costs, not entrenching them via such policies as the accord.

SPEECH.PARA: Who masterminded this madness? It was none other than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). One should look at his record. He had a go at Bourke's Store and it went broke. He went over to Solo petrol and it went broke. He went to ACTU travel and it went broke. He is now trying to run Australia and it is going broke. I say to the Government: Stop being the spineless, parliamentary puppets of the Australian Council of Trade Unions who are interested only in those with jobs. What about the jobless in this country? What about the employers? The ACTU even sets the Government's foreign policy. One cannot even send a letter to South Africa! I found out only the other day why we pay 33c for a stamp. We pay 3c for delivery and the other 30c for storage.

The accord has failed the exporters of this country. It has failed the jobless. It has failed the importers. Let us have no more of this Kelty cop-out. Let us stop playing this dangerous game of `Simon says'. Let us wake up to blow-wave Bob and the turbo-tongue nonsense he pours out to the media every day. Let us look behind the voodoo economics of the accord and see it for what it is. It is becoming more and more apparent that the accord is nothing more than a cord around our necks, strangling the initiative of free enterprise in this country today. Let us tell the people of Australia that the accord is a fraud. Let us blow the whistle on this nonsense and work to have it rejected from the economic policy of Australia forever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —After having listened to the drivel of the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), I am inclined to respond in equal terms, but I shall not embrace the temptation. However, let me make just a couple of quick points on the way through. The honourable member for Parkes indicated his absolute lack of economic knowledge when he compared the last three Budgets with their predecessors in terms of their being the largest deficits in the history of the nation. Anyone with any degree of political expertise or knowledge would fully understand that the only way one can gauge the comparative level of deficits is to embrace the approach of describing them in real terms, certainly not in nominal terms. It is an absurdity to do so and another indicator of the lack of economic expertise on the Opposition back benches which is approaching the situation on the Opposition front benches.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) indicated earlier the fundamental conflict between the call of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for a wage freeze in certain circumstances and the Opposition's alleged policy of the deregulation of the labour market, that is, attacking the soft end of union power. Ever since the Leader of the Opposition began articulating that approach, mainly as a stalking horse to provide himself with a forum in which to bring down his Leader, and ever since he achieved the mantle of Leader of the Opposition, we have had not only a stepping back from that policy approach but also a hiding from it. The Leader of the Opposition has not articulated that approach anywhere in the community with the same degree of vigour that he held previously. Why would he not do so? The reality is that out in the Australian community people are not prepared to adopt a system that overturns the Government's industrial relations policies with all their problems from time to time, for the politics and economics of voodoo-land.

The two positions on this issue-a freeze of wages or a deregulated labour market-are fundamentally opposed. They are philosophically opposed. The dries can argue that they want a deregulated wages system, but it seems to me to be an absurdity to do so when the Leader of the Opposition is pontificating on the possible use of a wages freeze. That is an institutionalised policy mechanism. It is the last suggestion that one would ever expect to come from a so-called dry. It is the absolute antithesis of the whole philosophical approach the Opposition has put forward to date.

It is not only on wages policy that the Opposition indicates a degree of confusion. As was articulated today in Question Time by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Opposition has changed its approach to our taxation reform package. Initially, the Leader of the Opposition was going to await the legislation, to weigh carefully what it comprised and to adopt an approach accordingly. But, of course, he was rolled. The strong Leader was rolled. So much for the lack of leadership prior to his ascendency. Again, in all the other major economic policy areas, the Opposition stands alone in its absolute confusion about the Australian dollar. Its members come into this House embracing economic treachery and appeal to international money market operators to attack the Australian dollar just as they did in the lead up to the 1983 election when the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), adopted the same approach of attacking Australia's economy. It seems to me to be an approach based on a great lack of respect for one's own country to positively invite people to attack its currency with all the associated corollaries, that is, increased unemployment and so on.

The situation which applied during October was unusual. It was atypical because a number of factors came together during October that made the current account deficit greater than it would otherwise have been. Because of my limited time I witness only the expatriation of our foreign aid donations during that month. It is an atypical month. I think everyone would agree with that. There is no doubt.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about September? What is the excuse for September?

—If the Opposition has a view about the current account deficit, again it will have to approach some fairly fundamental philosophical positions. For example, do Opposition members support the float? If there is a float do they support the Reserve Bank's smoothing operations? Is that too much intervention? Do they want a dirty float? Do they want a fixed exchange rate? No, there is too much confusion there and they cannot attack it, so they go to the other side of the coin and embrace the old stock-in-trade-that is, attack the trade union movement. In my view the trade union movement is much more economically literate than the Opposition at the moment. In co-operation with the Government it has made the only consensual incomes policy agreement ever and the only one that is not established on a fiscal or statutory basis or on a number of other bases, such as the deregulated model. All those models have failed. The Australian model is unique. On Monday this week, in discussions with a number of politicians from the United States, I found that they were positively encouraged by the prices and incomes accord. These politicians were both Republicans and Democrats. They believed it was a very useful model from which their own country could learn many great lessons. Having regard to the way in which the American economy is moving, they may not be all that wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: The accord has been renegotiated for another two years. Within the wording of it there is provision for consultation from time to time if economic circumstances change. If that becomes necessary, I have every confidence that the Government will embrace that approach. What is the record of the prices and incomes accord? It is worth going through it, although I know honourable members opposite get sick of hearing it. Unemployment was 10.4 per cent when we achieved office and it is now 7.8 per cent. A total of 460,000 new jobs have been created and I believe that we will shortly exceed our 500,000 target. That is a record for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Inflation has been halved.

TALK.START.PARA: —A brilliant record!

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is a great one for interjecting, but he comes to this argument with dirty hands. He was part of the Government which, in its last year of office, sent more than 200,000 people to the dole queues with increasing inflation, increasing interest rates and so on. It is no good the honourable member for Menzies just sitting there and making benign interjections. He will really have to do much better than lie to the House as he did earlier today--
—Order! The honourable member has used unparliamentary language. I ask him to withdraw.

—I withdraw that, Mr Deputy Speaker. Let me say that the honourable member for Menzies, in his total ignorance, indicated to this House a number of statistics relating to employment levels across a broad range of industry sectors. He was subsequently corrected by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and I hope that he has the decency at the conclusion of this debate to indicate to the House how he got it wrong. The way in which he got it wrong is very similar to the way in which he has been getting it wrong for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying, profit levels have been restored, real unit labour costs are at their 1960s level, and surely there is no debate about that. The accord has inbuilt flexibilities, as I have indicated; there is discounting of the consumer price index and there may be more if and when that is appropriate. The deficit has been cut, the public sector borrowing requirement has been cut and the Government currently has in place a tight monetary policy. An easing of demand would be consistent with Budget projections and with the approach of this Government under the prices and incomes accord. The Opposition's freeze or deregulation, inconsistencies aside, would mean in reality a wages blowout as we had on consecutive occasions under its stewardship. We would have rising inflation, again as under its stewardship right through the latter part of the 1970s, and we would have massively increasing unemployment. All those things are a prescription for a massive collapse of the Australian dollar and there is no way in which one could get around that. If the Opposition argues for a particular economic prescription, it will have to do much better than come to the House with two economically and philosophically opposed positions for wages policy. This is an absurdity and Opposition members would not pass a Higher School Certificate exam by suggesting either of those approaches--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the report of the Committee entitled `Who Calls Australia Home', a review of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit on the control of prohibited immigration by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, together with the minutes of proceedings, the transcript of evidence and documents authorised for publication.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The efficiency audit report of the Auditor-General on the control of prohibited immigration by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is the fourth such report that the Expenditure Committee has examined. The objectives of the Committee in carrying out its review were to assess the substantive content of the audit exercise and the quality of the efficiency audit report and also to examine the response of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The control function actually comprises a number of complex administrative procedures ranging from the issuance of visitors' visas at overseas posts to clearing of passengers at ports of entry, to apprehending, detaining and prosecuting prohibited non-citizens and finally, in some cases, deporting them. These procedures involve the use of sophisticated computer systems and the co-operation of other Commonwealth authorities, including the Australian Customs Service and the Australian Protection Service, as well as the Australian Federal Police.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee found the efficiency audit report a useful document in terms of assessing the administrative efficiency of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in its control of prohibited immigration. To a large extent the Department has accepted the Audit Office's recommendations and has proceeded to implement them. However, the greatest weaknesses of the efficiency audit report was its failure to address the issues of the effectiveness of administration by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. This is despite the claim in the report's introduction that the audit was concerned with efficiency and effectiveness. Little analysis seemed to have been carried out regarding the effectiveness of the Department's practice in meeting its objectives. Nor do any of the Audit Office's recommendations suggest that perhaps the objectives could be met more efficiently by using other means. The Committee has attempted to redress this weakness to some extent by making its own recommendations in its report. The committee's recommendations also result from the realisation in the course of the review that more general questions needed to be addressed, such as the extent to which prohibited non-citizens were able to obtain financial assistance and other benefits from Commonwealth sources. The Committee was disturbed to learn that prohibited non-citizens-that is, people who are illegal immigrants in Australia-are able to apply for legal aid. Some of them have Medicare cards and are being paid social security benefits. Many are working illegally, perhaps having obtained their jobs through the Commonwealth Employment Service.

The Committee believes that as a matter of principle people who are in Australia unlawfully should not be entitled to the same forms of assistance or benefits given to those who have legal status in this country, be they temporary entry permit holders, permanent residents or citizens. The Committee's recommendations are designed to close loopholes of access to benefits where these exist and, more importantly, to suggest that legislation be amended in some instances to prevent prohibited non-citizens from using certain community services. The most glaring example which came before the Committee was the situation in which prohibited non-citizens could obtain Commonwealth-funded legal aid to appeal against decisions to deport them made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). The Committee was advised that some of these cases, which have reached the High Court of Australia, could have run up costs in the vicinity of $250,000.

Another aspect of the Committee's report is its recommendation for two other significant legislative amendments. The first is to the Migration Act 1958. The essence of the recommendation is that visitors to this country who are here for six months or less should not be permitted to apply for permanent resident status while they are here. The second amendment is to the Citizenship Act 1948 to prevent children born to people who are not in Australia permanently or legally from acquiring citizenship status. Both amendments are intended to stop what is called `queue jumping'. In other words, we want all people who come to Australia intending to live here permanently to go through the proper application processes overseas. However, there is no suggestion that the immigration program should be reduced. On the contrary, we have specifically suggested in the report that any decrease in the numbers who obtain change of status should be added to the family reunion program.

From my comments, honourable members will no doubt appreciate that the review has ranged over areas which are much broader than those covered by the efficiency audit. I think that this is only right and proper. Parliamentary committees have a duty to draw together the various strands of government administration and come up at the end with something which is in the best interests of the Australian community.

I would also like to thank those members of the Committee who participated in the review, and I would like to thank the Committee secretariat who assisted in the preparation of the report. I would particularly like to thank Ruth Holzman, Peter Ratas and Penny Maher from the Committee secretariat. Ruth Holzman, who was on secondment to the Committee from the executive development scheme, had a large hand in the drafting of the report and in the conducting of the review. For an officer who came to the Committee from the Department of Communciations with no prior knowledge of the operations of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Miss Holzman's assistance to the Committee was invaluable and her standard of work was of a high order, and I think that it is proper that she be congratulated for the work that she did with the Committee on her secondment. I thank the House for the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I think that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure has done a good job in examining this efficiency audit by the Auditor-General. Whilst I have not had the opportunity to read the report, I have read the evidence provided to the Committee. There are some matters that the Committee has investigated that cause me some concern. In paragraph 61 of the report, the figure given for the number of prohibited non-citizens entering Australia each year is 6,000 to 10,000. However, in an Estimates committee of the Senate, departmental officials indicated that the figure they were working on was somewhere around 15,000 or 16,000-considerably more than the figure given to the Expenditure Committee of the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I also commend the Committee for dealing with the difficulties of payments by departments of benefits and privileges which are normally attributable to Australian residents or citizens. It has tackled this matter in a comprehensive and thoughtful way. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has consistently maintained that there are 50,000 illegal immigrants in Australia. From the Committee's work it is possible to indicate that a considerable number of those may be in receipt of benefits. As far as Medicare is concerned, in paragraph 79 of the report the Committee has identified-on a very small sample, admittedly-that perhaps 22 per cent of those examined were in receipt of Medicare cards even though they were illegal immigrants. If one extrapolates the figures-and I know that this is a dangerous thing to do, but we have no information, unfortunately, and the Department cannot provide it; nor do other departments provide it -and says that of the 50,000 so-called illegals in Australia, 22 per cent may be in receipt of benefits, one comes up with a staggering figure of $52m being paid out annually to people who are here illegally.

Nobody can prove or disprove those figures, and I think it is a shame that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has not tighter control of the processes of entry to and exit from Australia. It does not have control of cards in Sydney so it does not really know what is happening. Also, I do not believe that its computer systems are up to scratch so that it knows who is here illegally and who is not. Frankly, I doubt whether there are 50,000 illegal immigrants in Australia, but the Department has stuck with that figure and, having been stuck with that figure, it has to wear the ramifications of whether benefits are being paid out in Medicare, legal aid, social security benefits and unemployment benefits to a big number of people who are here illegally.

My closing comments are that I question not only the figures but also the controls. I wish to point out to members of the Government that its recent action in regard to illegal immigrants hinges on the identification card system. Every measure announced by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) and control of illegal immigrants hinges on the ID card, and yet we have the Victorian State Conference saying: `We will not wear the introduction of ID cards'. The interchange of information between departments is critical. The Committee looked at that matter and it did not come forward with a proper conclusion. But I believe that departments could co-operate. The Department of Social Security should be informed accurately of who are illegal immigrants and that Department, likewise, should inform the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs of the whereabouts of illegal immigrants. That applies to other departments, too. It is too risky a thing to depend on ID cards to control illegal immigrants in Australia.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill and the accompanying Australia (Request and Consent) Bill 1985 have been introduced at the request of the parliaments of all the States and in accordance with the established policy of successive Commonwealth governments. All the States have recently enacted legislation which requested this Parliament to enact legislation in the terms of each of the two Bills. The Bills will give effect to the agreement between the Commonwealth Government and all State governments to seek the removal of the outmoded residual constitutional links that still exist between Australia and the United Kingdom Parliament, Government and judicial system, and to substitute new constitutional provisions and procedural arrangements. This agreement has been reached following extensive consultations between the Commonwealth and State governments, dating from the 1982 Premiers Conference under our predecessors.

At the outset, I emphasise that nothing in the legislation will impair the position of the Queen as Queen of Australia. In fact, the Queen, instead of being formally advised on State matters by United Kingdom Ministers, will now be advised direct by State Premiers in her exercise of the power concerned.

The Australia Bill 1986, if enacted, will be an exercise of the power under section 51 (xxxviii) of the Constitution-the power to make laws with respect to the `exercise within the Commonwealth, at the request or with the concurrence of the Parliaments of all the States directly concerned, of any power which can at the establishment of this Constitution be exercised only by the Parliament of the United Kingdom or by the Federal Council of Australasia'. The Australia Bill bears the date `1986', and provides for the Act to be cited as the `Australia Act 1986', because it is desirable for the Act to have the same title as the corresponding Act to be enacted by the United Kingdom Parliament; this matter is dealt with in the accompanying Bill.

In brief, the proposed legislation will terminate any powers that might still remain in the United Kingdom Parliament to make laws having effect as part of Australian law. It will remove existing fetters and limitations upon the legislative powers of the State parliaments except in respect of the conduct of foreign affairs. In particular, the Colonial Laws Validity Act 1865 will be repealed in relation to the States. As well, residual executive powers of the United Kingdom Government with respect to the States will be terminated. The legislation will also remove the remaining avenues of appeal from Australian courts to the Privy Council, thus making the High Court of Australia the final court of appeal for all Australian courts. This will end the anomalous situation in the area of legal precedent, where a State supreme court could find itself faced with two binding, yet conflicting authorities.

Among other important provisions in the Bills are those concerning the State Governors. They are to be vested with all of the Queen's existing powers and functions in respect of the States except those in relation to appointments of State Governors and the termination of their appointments, and in relation to awards of imperial honours. On these matters, the legislation will put an end to the present position under which the Queen is advised by United Kingdom Ministers-following recommendations by the State Premiers to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office of the United Kingdom Government. Instead, the Queen will be advised directly in each case by the Premier of the State concerned.

Furthermore, when the Queen is personally present in a State, she will be able to exercise a power or function in relation to a State but will do so on any occasion only if there has been mutual and prior agreement between the Queen and the Premier that it would be appropriate for her to do so. All State Premiers have confirmed their acceptance that such mutual and prior agreement is an essential ingredient of the proposed arrangements.

In order to cater for those few States who may still wish to issue them, arrangements have been made for imperial honours to be awarded by the Queen upon the advice of the Premier of the State concerned. These arrangements do not need to be included in the legislation and have not been included. Procedures acceptable to the Commonwealth and State governments, the Queen and the United Kingdom Government have been formulated and will be given effect by amendments to the prerogative instruments in the United Kingdom constituting the various orders and awards.

I turn now to the detailed provisions of the Bill. The Australia Bill departs from the usual form of Commonwealth Bills in that the provisions for its short title, commencement and interpretation are placed at the end so as to parallel the Act to be sought from the United Kingdom Parliament. This has been done so that the clause numbers of the two Bills fully correspond. Clause 1 of the Australia Bill terminates the power of the Parliament of the United Kingdom to make laws having effect as part of Australian law, whether as law of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory. Clause 2, which must be read subject to clauses 5 and 6 mentioned below, declares and enacts in sub-clause (1) that the powers of each State parliament include power to legislate extra-territorially. Sub-clause (2) removes any other limitations on the legislative powers of the States that might exist by reason of their former colonial status. However, sub-clause 2 (2) expressly provides that it does not confer upon any State any capacity that the State did not have immediately before the commencement of the Australia Act to engage in relations with countries outside Australia. Sub-clause 3 (1) removes the fetters imposed upon the States by the Colonial Laws Validity Act 1865. Sub-clause 3 (2), which will operate subject to clauses 5 and 6, makes it clear that the States will be able to enact legislation repugnant to the laws of England or to United Kingdom Acts, and that those Acts may be repealed or amended by a State parliament insofar as they are part of the law of the State. Clause 4 expressly repeals sections 735 and 736 of the Imperial Merchant Shipping Act 1894 insofar as they are still part of the law of a State.

Clause 5 qualifies clause 2 and sub-clause 3 (2) by making them subject to the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act and the Commonwealth Constitution. Clause 5 goes on to provide that they do not operate so as to give effect to any provision of a State Act that would repeal, amend or be repugnant to the Australia Act itself, the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act, the Commonwealth Constitution or the Statute of Westminster, as amended and in force from time to time. Clause 6 provides that, notwithstanding clauses 2 and sub-clause 3 (2), a law of a State made after the commencement of the Australia Acts respecting the constitution, powers or procedure of the Parliament of that State shall be of no force or effect unless made in the manner and form, if any, required by a law made by that Parliament, whether before or after the commencement of the Australia Act. It thus preserves the entrenched provisions of State Constitutions subject to any changes made in accordance with State law. Clause 7 contains the provisions relating to the vesting of the Queen's powers in State Governors, except in regard to appointments of Governors, recommendations for imperial honours, and the exercise of the Queen's powers when she is personally present in the State. I mention again the understanding that the Queen, when personally present in a State, would only exercise a power or function following mutual and prior agreement between the Queen and the Premier. Clause 8 will put an end to existing powers of the Queen to disallow State laws, and will prevent any requirement for the operation of State laws to be suspended pending signification of the Queen's pleasure. Sub-clause 9 (1) will prevent any law or instrument from requiring the Governor of a State to withhold assent from any Bill that has been passed in the manner and form, if any, required by a law of that State, and sub-clause 9 (2) will preclude any law or instrument from requiring the reservation of any Bill for a State Act for the signification of Her Majesty's pleasure.

Clause 10 provides that, after the commencement of the Act, the United Kingdom Government will have no responsibility for the government of any State. Clause 11 will terminate appeals to the Privy Council from Australian courts. However, it will not affect an appeal instituted before the commencement of this legislation, or an appeal instituted after that commencement pursuant to leave granted on an appropriate application or petition presented before the commencement. Clause 12, which supplements clause 1, expressly repeals section 4, sub-sections 9 (2) and (3), and sub-section 10 (2) of the Statute of Westminster, relating to the powers of the United Kingdom Parliament to make laws with respect to the Commonwealth and the States of Australia, insofar as they are part of Australian law. Clauses 13 and 14 contain special provisions concerning the Constitution Acts of Queensland and Western Australia. These provisions are consequential upon the termination of the powers and responsibilities of United Kingdom Ministers in respect of the States. Clause 15 provides that the proposed legislation and the Statute of Westminster, as amended and in force from time to time, insofar as it is part of the law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, can be repealed or amended only by the Commonwealth Parliament at the request, or with the concurrence, of the parliaments of all the States. An exception is made in respect of Commonwealth legislation enacted pursuant to any constitutional alteration made, in accordance with section 128 of the Constitution, after the commencement of the Australia Act. Clauses 16 and 17 provide for matters of interpretation, short title and commencement. It has been agreed between the Commonwealth and State governments that the Australia Acts to be enacted by the Commonwealth and United Kingdom Parliaments will be proclaimed to come into operation at the same time.

Passage of this long overdue legislation will complete the process of constitutional development commenced at the beginning of this century. It will eliminate those laws and procedures which are anachronistic and substitute new arrangements which reflect Australia's status as an independent and sovereign nation. It will also ensure the capacity of the States to exercise fully the powers that are appropriate to their position in our Federation, freed at last from the legal fetters and limitations derived from their earlier status as British colonies. I commend the Bill to the House.

This Bill flows from the Australia Bill 1986. DEBATE.TITLE: JUDICIAL AND STATUTORY OFFICERS (REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Young, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In September the Government accepted the findings of the Remuneration Tribunal's 1985 review of the remuneration and allowances payable to the holders of all offices within its jurisdiction. I presented a copy of the Tribunal's review to the Parliament on 19 September. Honourable members will be aware that the Tribunal has again had regard to the wage fixing principles and has concluded that, apart from individual work value changes, it should continue to apply only national wage case increases to the offices within its jurisdiction.

Allowances intended to reimburse outgoings-that is, travelling allowance, expense of office allowance, electorate allowance and charter allowance-have been increased in accordance with increases in costs as measured by the consumer price index or surveys of actual costs. The purpose of this Bill is to implement the Tribunal's recommendations in respect of holders of judicial office and the President and members of the Inter-State Commission. The Constitution provides that remuneration for these offices shall be such as the Parliament may fix.

Clause 3 of the Bill provides for the principal Act to be amended to reflect the current salary payable in respect of the offices as reported upon by the Remuneration Tribunal, and adjusted by the most recent national wage case decision. Other parts of clause 3 deal with increases in expense of office allowances as well as the salaries and allowances of the members of the Inter-State Commission. Clause 4 deals with rates of travelling allowance payable to justices of the High Court of Australia by providing for an increase and a new entitlement whereby an additional travelling allowance is paid in respect of an accompanying spouse whose travel costs are met by the Government. Clause 5 provides an increase to the additional allowance payable to justices of the High Court who are not resident in Canberra.

Clause 6 provides an increase in travelling allowance payable to other judicial officeholders, including the President and members of the Inter-State Commission, and provides for a new travelling allowance entitlement, as for the High Court, in respect of an accompanying spouse. Clause 7 provides for a new section which fixes the rate of travelling allowances payable to the President and members of the Inter-State Commission. Clause 8 provides an increase to the additional allowance payable to the Solicitor-General where the holder of that office is required to establish a principal place of residence in the Australian Capital Territory.

The cost of implementing the Tribunal's recommendations in respect of judges and the Inter-State Commission will be in the order of $99,000 in 1985-86, before allowance is made for the most recent national wage case. Further information on the clauses of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH TERTIARY EDUCATION COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Amendment Bill is to amend the legislation governing the operations of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to give effect to Government decisions taken following consideration of the report by the CTEC Chairman on the structure of the Commission and arrangements for co-ordination and consultation with States and institutions. As indicated in the supplementary guidelines to CTEC the report has received broad based support for its general objective of more co-ordinated consideration of State and national needs in tertiary education. The Government has largely endorsed the report's recommendations which will have the effect of reducing the costs and complexities of existing arrangements while supporting a more efficient and effective process of advising the Government on the development of tertiary education.

Many of the recommendations of the report do not require legislation. Action has already been taken to reorganise the CTEC secretariat along functional lines and to improve arrangements for the formal consultation processes between the Commission and the States and institutions, for the triennial planning processes. The changes embodied in this Bill will extend the charter of the Commission to include in its functions the promotion of developments across the various sectors of tertiary education. The report concluded that the present structure impedes the promotion of the Government's participation and equity objectives as it acts as a barrier to cross-sectoral developments. The amended Act will include `institutes of tertiary education' in the types of tertiary institution on which the Commission can provide advice and will include provision for the Minister to declare a specified institution or authority to be an institute of tertiary education for the purposes of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Act.

It will also redesignate the sectoral councils as advisory councils with the function of advising the Commission on needs and new policies in their respective sectors. The report concluded that the existing system of sectoral councils advising the Minister, with the Commission in turn developing its advice to government, results in excessive report writing, considerable duplication and leads to unrealistic resource bids. Each advisory council will publish a triennial report on the state of its sector, its problems and priorities for future development but will no longer develop detailed financial recommendations for Commonwealth grants. It will also reduce the part time membership from eight to six in the case of the universities and advanced education councils and from eight to seven in the case of the Technical and Further Education Council. In addition, a part time member of each council will be appointed to membership of the Commission-in addition to the full time council chairpersons-to provide expertise in sectoral matters. Part time membership of the Commission will be increased from five to six.

Savings of approximately $100,000 per annum will result from the changes arising from this legislation, in particular the reduction from 29 to 22 in the part time membership of the Commission and the councils. The Bill also provides for the insertion of non-sexist terminology in the legislation in place of existing sexist language such as `Chairman', et cetera. In addition a replacement listing of recognised colleges of advanced education is provided, reflecting name changes in a number of institutions and the establishment of the new Gold Coast College of Advanced Education. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS (OVERSEAS STUDENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Commonwealth Education Institutions (Overseas Students) Amendment Bill 1985 is to amend the Australian National University Act 1946 and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Act 1967 to empower the charging of fees for overseas students. In both Acts, the amendment will enable these institutions to charge course fees for overseas students in accordance with guidelines determined by the Minister. This action is being taken in respect of Commonwealth higher education institutions as a counterpart of similar provisions being introduced into the States Grants (Tertiary Eduction Assistance) Act 1984 for State institutions. The same procedures will be followed for both State and Commonwealth institutions.

Revenue from fees will be retained by institutions on the basis that after direct costs are met any surplus is applied to the education activities of the institution in accordance with the relevant conditions as set out in the guidelines for full fee overseas students in courses provided by Commonwealth-funded higher education institutions.

The Maritime College Act does not need to be amended because there is already a power in the Act to impose fees and the exercise of this power is already subject to the Minister's approval. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the State Grants (Education Assistance Participation and Equity) Act 1983 to: Firstly, supplement for cost increases the grants available to goverment and non-government education authorities in the States and the Northern Territory to conduct projects and programs under the participation and equity program in the years 1985 and 1986; and, secondly, to put into effect the Government's decision to extend the program to 1987 and to spread the funds currently provided for 1986 evenly over 1986 and 1987. The present Act as amended provides funds for PEP activities for 1984, 1985 and 1986. The cost supplementation proposed is in accord with the Government's undertaking to provide retrospective cost supplementation for this program. The adjustments are consistent with those being made to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) and States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bills which are also before the House today.

The Government's decison to spread funds currently available for 1986 evently over 1986 and 1987 was announced in May as part of the initial expenditure savings measures. The amounts to be provided in each of 1986 and 1987 are sufficient to allow the program to proceed and achieve positive results. The financial impact of this Bill will be to provide an additional $0.624m in 1985, to reduce the amount currently legislated for 1986 by $38.462m and to provide an additional $42.423m for 1987. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill follows last year's historic legislation which set out policies for the implementation of a comprehensive long term scheme for the general recurrent funding of government and non-government schools in Australia. This Bill implements the Government's decisions on specific purpose and capital programs for schools in 1986 which I announced when tabling the Commonwealth Schools Commission's report for 1986 on 15 October 1985.

The capital grants program will entail a greater emphasis on upgrading and refurbishment of facilities in existing schools, particularly those serving students characterised by low socio-economic circumstances, the construction of new facilities in accordance with overall educational planning, the provision of facilities to assist schools to encourage and cater for increased student participation at years 11 and 12, and the provision of facilities to encourage equal participation by girls and boys in all areas of the curriculum and to assist in widening career options for girls.

The Bill reflects the Government's decision that in 1986 there will be a single general capital element in place of the five elements operating in 1985. There will also be two national elements: Continuation of the existing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander element and a new element for the provision of facilities for children with intellectual and/or physical disabilities. This follows from the transfer from the Department of Community Services of the administration of capital grants to non-government institutions providing for disabled children.

Within the general capital element, the Government's decision to direct a higher proportion of Commonwealth capital funds to upgrading and refurbishment of existing schools will be a matter for administrative implementation and will take account of forward commitment obligations already entered into. The Bill appropriates an estimated $1,495m for schools programs in the States and the Northern Territory for calendar year 1986, and also appropriates a further $14m for 1985 programs in line with the Government's policy of providing retrospective cost supplementation for the Commonwealth's school programs.

In this legislation, the Government is implementing its policy on the funding of new non-government schools which was announced in March this year following the Government's acceptance of the report by a panel of Commonwealth schools commissioners on `Planning and Funding Policies for New Non-Government Schools'. This policy was the result of extensive consultations with government and non-government education authorities and will benefit all Australian children, in government and non-government schools. The main features of the policy that have been incorporated in the legislation are:
Changes to the definition of new non-government school to include existing schools undertaking a change in character only when it results in a significantly increased and/or different clientele;

general recurrent grants for approved new non-government schools and those undertaking a change in character which does not involve a significantly increased and/or different clientele, to be based on the general enrolment plan put forward by schools at the time of their approval;
modification of the existing criteria for determining eligibility for Commonwealth funding;

decisions on eligibility for funding also to take account of plans, including the plans of the relevant government and non-government education authorities, for the provision of education in the States and in the locality, the past, current and projected characteristics of the locality so far as the provision of education is concerned, and the priority the school should, in the opinion of the Minister, be accorded for funding from the Commonwealth.

This policy is an important element in the Commonwealth's overall approach to the provision of a firm basis for proper educational planning, and will promote the most effective and most equitable use of Commonwealth financial assistance. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On 5 November 1985 Volume 3 of the report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the 1985-87 triennium was tabled in the Parliament. This volume of the report responded to the Government's supplementary guidelines announced on 20 August 1985, and made recommendations on the distribution of additional funds for universities and colleges of advanced education for 1986 and 1987, and the Commonwealth's contribution to the technical and further education systems for 1986.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act l984 to complete the Government's 1986 tertiary education program in the States and Northern Territory, provide additional grants for higher education for 1987 for enrolment growth flowing from increased intakes in 1986 and to provide cost supplementation for existing legislated grants. The Government has decided to support a further increase in intakes for higher education in 1987. Funding for 1987 for this increase will be determined in the 1986-87 Budget context after consideration of a report from CTEC on efficiency and effectiveness in higher education, the terms of which were announced on 17 October 1985. At the same time the Government will determine the level of Commonwealth support for TAFE systems for 1987, following its consideration of another review being undertaken by CTEC of the supplementary role of the Commonwealth in the TAFE sector.

The financial impact of this Bill will be the appropriation of an additional $509.6m. The Bill provides for an increase in higher education funding of $45.2m for 1986 and 1987, and a total of $280.5m for the TAFE sector for 1986. An amount of $183.9m will be provided as adjustments for cost increases to existing grants for all sectors. Grants for all years of the triennium will be further adjusted for cost increases from time to time in subsequent amending legislation in accordance with the Government's policy of retrospective cost supplementation for education grants. Under this policy, wage and salary increases occurring during the program year are met while increases in non-salary, equipment and capital costs are adjusted to the levels applying at the beginning of the program year.

The distribution of the additional higher education grants for 1986 and 1987 is as recommended by the Commission. The key features of the revised triennial program for the States and Northern Territory for higher education are:

Recurrent funds for 1987 will amount to $1,992.7m. This is 5.5 per cent higher in real terms than the 1984 level. Additional funds necessary to support a further increase in intakes of some 2,000 in 1987 will be determined in the 1986-87 Budget context. In total, an additional 20,500 higher education places will have been created over the triennium.

Capital funding for 1985-87 will be $209.7m. This represents an increase on the corresponding figure for the 1982-84 triennium of $59.4m or 39 per cent in real terms. The supplementary program for 1986 and 1987 will enable the commencement of several new projects aimed largely at accommodating the extra students who will be provided for in higher education institutions as part of the Government's strategy for young people.
Increased equipment funds will be provided to those institutions where enrolments are growing.

In the TAFE program for 1986 increased funding will be provided for fees reimbursement grants while designated grants for special course provision and equipment grants will be maintained at the same real levels as in 1985. The States will also receive $130.2m in grants in 1986 for new and continuing capital works projects in TAFE colleges. The Commission's recommended distribution of these funds among specific projects was accepted by the Government and is reflected in Schedule 20 of the Bill.

This Bill also gives effect to the Government's decision, announced earlier this year, to permit higher education institutions to charge full cost fees for courses for overseas students, in accordance with the Government's guidelines on full fee courses.

Under the guidelines, universities and colleges of advanced education funded by the Commonwealth will be able to offer full fee courses for overseas students, either in Australia or overseas, over and above those subsidised overseas students who are subject to the overseas student charge. The Bill provides for the exclusion of such full fee courses from the condition generally applying to recurrent grants provided under the legislation that institutions are not to charge tuition fees. Consequential changes in respect of Commonwealth institutions are being made in other Bills being introduced today.

The Bill also provides for the payment of grants to be made in other than the traditional context of university, advanced education or TAFE. In particular, provision is included for grants to be made in relation to approved `institutes of tertiary education'. The supplementary capital program for higher education for 1986 and 1987 includes a contribution to the planning phase of the Western Melbourne Institute of Post-Secondary Education, a new multi-sector institution which will serve an area of Melbourne which has been severely disadvantaged in terms of access to tertiary education, a point which has been made repeatedly by the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) over years. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish the Federal Airports Corporation. For many years the Commonwealth-owned airports have been administered by a department of state-most recently the Department of Aviation. When the Government came to office in 1983 it had as part of its platform a policy for improved administration of major airports. We believed that placing this responsibility with a largely independent statutory authority would offer significant advantages to the travelling public, taxpayers, the aviation industry and airport administrators. Subsequent analysis has clearly confirmed that view.

I hasten to say that this view is not a reflection upon the Department of Aviation and its predecessors, but a recognition that the commercial operation of airports would be better managed by a Commonwealth business enterprise. Departments of state are of necessity bound by the Government processes which inhibit commercial flexibility and responsiveness. The aviation industry has been critical of this fact and of the inability of the current administrative processes to make changes in a timely manner to meet the requirements of a dynamic market. Additionally, governments in the past have unduly influenced the priorities for aviation infrastructure development for reasons unrelated to economics or efficiency. Indeed many of the decisions taken in the past have inhibited economy and efficiency in the industry.

This legislation will go a long way towards rectifying these problems and will enable the Corporation to act more readily to meet the changing needs of the travelling public and the aviation industry. The Federal Airports Corporation is an important part of the Government's overall strategy to improve the efficiency of the aviation industry and the levels of services to the consumer. This strategy includes the two reviews which have already been undertaken, that is, the Bosch Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery and the Butcher-Scully Review of International Air Freight. This Government has made substantial changes to Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd to allow them to operate more commercially. Consequently both have achieved record profits in the past year. We have been steadily improving departmental efficiency and have moved to separate airport and airways charges so as to promote further efficiency in the aviation industry. Honourable members will be aware that we currently have a review under way of the Opposition's 1981 two-airline agreement.

In framing the legislation the Government has had to face the task of balancing the need for autonomy and entrepreneurial management with the need for public accountability to maximise public benefit. This approach fits in with the Government's policy of public enterprise-efficiency, consumer responsiveness and successful management. I believe that we have achieved that balance.

While the Corporation will be the sole provider of airport facilities in most areas where it will operate, it will provide an important part of the infrastructure for a competitive aviation industry. Within that context it will in all of its activities be subject to close scrutiny by aviation users and the aviation industry. This scrutiny will be enhanced through requirements in the legislation for consultation, disclosure of results and for the publication of indicators which year by year will show the performance of the Corporation across the range of its activities and on an airport by airport basis.

The Government has set objectives for the Corporation covering social, financial, management and efficiency aspects. The Corporation will be required to take these objectives into account in its planning and operations. Additionally, the Corporation will be required to put forward to the Minister for Aviation each year a three-year forward program including its budget for the following year and details of its corporate plans. These requirements will be exercised at a strategic level, leaving the Corporation free in its day to day management and exercise of its commercial judgment.

To enable the Corporation to operate as autonomously as possible, it will be freed from the requirements of staffing under Public Service conditions, the requirement that it utilise the Department of Housing and Construction for its capital works-although it will be expected to provide the opportunity for that Department to compete for such work on a commercial basis-and the need for its day to day land dealings to be administered through the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services.

This legislation will provide a framework for the operation of airports more efficiently, more commercially and in a manner in which the Corporation's performance will be able to be judged by its owners, the people of Australia. Given the potential for greater efficiency resulting from setting up the Corporation, the Government will require it, and the Department of Aviation, to ensure that there is no net increase in staff over the two organisations at the time of the establishment of the Corporation. The rights and interests of employees transferring from the Department of Aviation to the Corporation will be protected. To ensure that their employment is not jeopardised, the Government will require as a matter of policy that the Corporation offer positions to all staff whose functions are transferred. While the Corporation will have power to set conditions of employment for its staff, it will also be required to provide, at the time of the transfer, offers of conditions of employment to transferring staff at least equivalent to those which they currently enjoy in the Australian Public Service.

I turn now to the more significant detail of the legislation. The functions prescribed for the Corporation will enable it to own, develop and operate its airports in an efficient and cost-effective way. It will, however, have overriding requirements to operate its airports safely and in a manner which accords with the public interest. The Department of Aviation will retain responsibility for the setting of safety and security standards for airports. The Corporation will be bound to abide by those standards. The Department will also retain responsibility for overall national airport planning issues. The legislation makes it clear that the Department of Aviation, through the existing integrated air traffic control system, will retain responsibility for the safe operation of aircraft.

The Corporation will be constituted in much the same way as other Commonwealth transport business undertakings with seven members including a chairperson and a deputy chairperson appointed for periods not exceeding five years. The usual provisions for such matters as remuneration, leave of absence, termination of appointment and disclosure of interests will apply.

The legislation provides for the specification of certain airports to be the responsibility of the Corporation, with ministerial approval being required for the Corporation to accept responsibility for others or for the Corporation to close an airport. The Corporation will, at the outset, take responsibility for all State capital city airports including the general aviation airports and will also be responsible for Coolangatta and Launceston airports. Although there has been some public debate about the inclusion of the general aviation airports in the Corporation, it is the Government's considered view that to exclude them would deny those airports the expertise and flexibility of management which will reside in the Corporation.

This is of particular significance in Sydney where the operation of Bankstown is a matter of concern and sensitivity to the people in nearby areas. There is no question that Sydney will be the city in which the new Corporation will face its major challenges and will have its major responsibilities even before considering a second Sydney airport. The Government has therefore decided that the head office of the Corporation should be located in Sydney.

An important aspect of the legislation is the requirement that the Corporation provide the Minister annually with an up-dated corporate plan including its budget and financial targets for the forthcoming year. It is largely through this mechanism and through its reporting procedures, including its annual report, that the Corporation will be kept aware of government requirements. Similarly, the responsible Minister will be able at the strategic level to monitor the Corporation. The successful use of this mechanism will be the major factor in enabling the Corporation to be freed from ministerial involvement in day to day management issues.

The legislation provides for the capital structure for the Corporation to be determined ministerially before the Corporation takes over its airports. The appropriate gearing ratio obviously depends on such matters as the value of assets being vested in the Corporation, its future investment program, levels of working capital required and the level of financial flexibility necessary for proper management. I will be consulting with my colleague the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) before determining an initial capital structure for the Corporation. It will also be useful to have the views of the Corporation's board on this issue before a particular commencing debt-equity ratio is fixed.

It must be recognised that airport operations are highly capital intensive, requiring long term investment planning decisions. In setting the capital structure for the Corporation, we will therefore need to give particular attention to the balance to be struck between the long term viability and needs for future investment of the Corporation, and the reasonable expectation of the Government for a proper return on the substantial public investment in airports. Provision is also made for a specific power of direction, which in particular circumstances would incur reimbursement where such a direction results in financial detriment to the Corporation. A general power of direction will also be utilised at the inception of the Corporation to enable the Minister to convey to the Chairman and members the Government's requirements on a variety of issues which will not be subject to recovery. Included amongst these will be, for example, the payment of ex gratia payments to local government in lieu of rates and the requirement that the Corporation offer employment to Department of Aviation employees whose functions transfer to the Corporation.

The Government has decided that the Corporation should not be subject to Commonwealth, State and local government taxes. In this respect the Corporation will be in a similar position to other public transport enterprises. If, however, the Corporation engages in activities in competition with private enterprise it will be required to do so through a subsidiary and thereby in respect of those activities be liable to taxation. This decision will continue the existing arrangements for Commonwealth airports and will ensure that taxation does not impose a new and substantial cost on the users of airports.

The Corporation will be required to operate in a manner which will enable it to produce a reasonable rate of return upon the assets which it employs. Provision is made for it to be able to levy charges for the use of its airports, to lease property on airports and to let business concessions. Arrangements existing at the time of transfer by way of lease or contract will, of course, transfer to the Corporation and will continue to bind the Corporation.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the establishment of the Corporation is a significant step forward in ensuring that the provision and operation of costly airport infrastructure is based on efficiency and investment undertaken only when there is financial and economic justification. In moving to establish the Federal Airports Corporation to operate our airports we are bringing Australia into line with general practice internationally. For the first time in Australia the financial performance of airports will be measured and results made available to airport users. One of the objectives set by the Government is that the Corporation be a good neighbour to the communities it serves. Within this responsibility the Corporation will be responsive to the needs of the travelling public and to those living in close proximity to airports.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I believe that this Bill represents a major step forward in aviation in Australia. It will assist the airport user. It will provide the basis for rational development and operation of airports. And it will reduce the call on the taxpayer for airport infrastructure costs. I commend the Federal Airports Corporation Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is related to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985. It proposes several technical and formal amendments to the Customs Undertakings (Penalties) Act 1981 as a consequence of the changes made to the tender quota arrangements in the Customs Act by the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1985 passed earlier this year. The Customs Undertakings (Penalties) Act 1981 provides for the imposition of penalties for breaches of undertakings required to be given for the purposes of the tender quota arrangements of Part 15 of the Customs Act 1901.
Part 15 of the Customs Act was altered this year to-
(1) enable the Minister administering the Customs Act to determine the periods of validity for which tender quota schemes are to run;

(2) change the requirements of the tender quota undertaking so that tenderers need only undertake to enter the relevant goods for home consumption and not also undertake to import the goods; and, consequently,
(3) change the importation requirement of quota instruments to a requirement that the goods be entered for home consumption.
Financial Impact Statement
The provisions of this Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes amendments to customs and excise laws. The most important measures are the amendments required to facilitate the introduction of inwards duty free shopping and the amendments required to enable a full rebate of the excise on diesel fuel to be paid to eligible primary producers. The other provisions of the Bill are of a technical or administrative nature and I will provide brief details of these later. The amendments related to inwards duty free shopping are part of a legislative package necessary to introduce this duty free and sales tax free facility at international airports in Australia. My colleague the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will bring forward the complementary changes to the sales tax laws. The necessary changes to the customs and excise tariffs and regulations will be undertaken separately.

In September 1984 the Government announced that it had approved the introduction of limited inwards duty free shopping at international airports. The shops are to be located in airports at a point somewhere between the disembarkation area and the Customs barrier so as to enable the goods that are sold to incoming overseas passengers to be taken direct to the Customs barrier for clearance. The only goods to be sold duty free at the shops will be spirituous liquor, tobacco products and perfume.

Introduction of restricted inwards duty-free shopping will not, however, alter the duty-free concessions available to a passenger, which currently are limited to one litre of spirituous liquor and 250 grams of tobacco products. There is no specific limit on the amount of perfume which may be brought in duty-free by a passenger, providing that the amount does not represent a commercial quantity. It might be noted that the Industries Assistance Commission has reviewed the passenger concessions recently and its report is being studied.

I should make it clear that the facility to purchase inwards duty-free goods will be confined to international airports. As is the case with outwards duty-free shops the on-airport inwards duty-free shops will be required to be licensed as warehouses for the purposes of the Customs Act. The inwards duty-free shop provisions in the Bill are to come into force by proclamation after the necessary regulations have been made.

The second important measure in this Bill is the provision to enable a full rebate on diesel fuel to be paid to primary producers. This was one of the initiatives to assist the rural sector announced by the Treasurer in the 1985-86 Budget Speech. The full rebate on the fuel used by primary producers will operate from 1 November 1985. It will result in a reduction in the price of diesel used by farmers, fishermen and other primary producers of approximately 2.4c per litre.

The Government also announced in the context of the taxation reform package that in the case of the rebate for fuel used in mining operations, that rebate will be increased to offset any further increases in excise resulting from excise indexation arrangements between now and the 1986-87 Budget. The rebate will be further reviewed in the context of that Budget. Because of the number of rates now required as a result of the changes made to the rebate in the last year it has now been decided to replace the automatic indexation provisions with a system of ministerial declarations. Consumer price index increases will, however, continue to be made. The provisions of clauses 9 and 19 of the Bill therefore provide for ministerial declarations to make immediate changes to the diesel fuel rebate whenever they occur for policy or other reasons, such as a change in the CPI index. The ministerial declarations are of course subject to the usual disallowance procedures.

I now turn to the technical and administrative amendments contained in this Bill. I know that the House would be deeply disappointed if I did not deal with these measures in full. Clause 8 of the Bill introduces revised rules of origin for goods produced in South Pacific Forum island countries. These new rules stem from the July 1984 meeting of the Regional Committee on Trade held in Kiribati. At that meeting Forum island countries asked Australia and New Zealand to include either or both countries' inputs in the calculation of Forum island content of goods for the determination of eligibility for preferential tariff treatment. All parties have now agreed that the rules should be extended to provide for a minimum Forum island countries content of 25 per cent of the factory cost of goods where there is sufficient additional Australian or relevant New Zealand content to comply with the minimum 50 per cent factory cost rule for preferential tariff purposes.

The amendments to the working days and hours provisions of the Customs Act, contained in clause 5 of the Bill, provide for the Comptroller-General of Customs to determine the fees for the services of officers during normal working hours but at places where such services are not normally provided free of charge. The Comptroller-General already has the power to determine the fees for officers' services outside normal working hours and the proposed amendment is designed to provide uniformity in the manner of determining fees for officers' services. Provision is made in clause 13 for the determinations of the Comptroller-General to be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The opportunity has been taken also to include a provision for the review of determinations made under the existing Act.

Clause 11 of the Bill proposes several minor changes to the powers to search persons suspected of carrying prohibited imports or prohibited exports. The changes, which are proposed as a consequence of complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman, will permit the Comptroller-General of Customs to limit the classes of Customs officers who are to be empowered to direct a body search. The changes will also remove the present impediment which requires that the same officer who established a reasonable cause for the search should also conduct the search. As honourable members would recall, the former member for Hunter was very much concerned with this matter.

The first amendment is aimed at providing a legal basis for guidelines to prescribe only senior and experienced officers to establish the reasonable cause for a search. The second amendment is similar to an amendment made to section 196 of the Act by the Parliament in 1979 but it was not proclaimed pending further review of the search provisions. When proposing similar amendments to section 196 of the Customs Act the then Minister said:

This amendment will allow a person to be detained and searched by an officer other than the officer who has established a reasonable cause for the search. It is clear that in certain instances it would not be practicable for the latter officer to be continuously available at the location at which the person was detained or apprehended.

The Government proposes the amendment in this Bill for the same reasons. The Commonwealth Ombudsman concurs with the proposed changes designed to rectify deficiencies in the existing search procedures. The opportunity is also being taken to make a drafting correction to the provisions which relate to the sex of the persons who are to conduct a search.
Financial Impact Statement

The introduction of inwards duty-free shops is expected to benefit airport concessions revenues by about $5m in a full year. Other revenue effects of the shops are not quantifiable at this stage, nor are the administrative costs. The rebate of duty on diesel fuel at the full rate of the excise duty payable is expected to cost about $35.5m in a full year and $24m in 1985-86. Changes to the rebate for fuel used in mining operations is expected to cost approximately $350,000. The other provisions of the Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 which is now before the House covers a wide range of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. In summary, the Bill includes three clauses relating to sections of the principal Act and eight clauses which correspond to schedules which incorporate changes: Firstly, changes initially introduced by Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notice and subsequently proposed in this House as Customs tariff proposals; secondly, changes introduced directly by Customs tariff proposals; or, thirdly, changes which are being introduced in this Bill.

Clauses 3 and 4 of the Bill contain amendments to sections 15 and 21 of the principal Act that are complementary to the insertion of new sub-section 151(5A) in the Customs Act, which is contained in the Customs and Excise Legislation Bill (No. 2) 1985. The Customs Tariff Act amendments keep the complementary provisions determining the duty rates applicable to goods from preferential sources in line with the relevant rules of origin provisions in the Customs Act. These amendments will come into effect at the same time as the relevant amendment to the Customs Act.

Clause 5 of the Bill will repeal section 30 of the principal Act on and from 18 October 1984. That date coincides with the operative date of changes made to the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 which, among other matters, abolished the Temporary Assistance Authority and changed other provisions relating to temporary assistance. This action has removed the need to retain section 30 of the Customs Tariff Act, which deals with temporary rates of duty.

Schedule 1 to the Bill is operative on and from 1 January 1985 and provides for the duty-free entry under quota of new woven polypropylene bags of South Pacific Forum island origin.
