This concession follows the Government's agreement to a request by the Forum island countries for increased access for these goods under the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement.

Schedule 2 to the Bill, operative on and from 9 February 1985, reduces the rate of duty applying to certain engine-powered lawnmowers of New Zealand origin from 7 per cent to 5 per cent. This reduction follows a review of a compensating charge applied to certain New Zealand lawnmowers which had been in place since the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement came into effect. The charge resulted from the different duty treatment accorded lawnmower engines when imported into New Zealand or Australia. Following the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission report on lawnmowers, certain engines and parts, the general tariff rate on certain lawnmower engines was lowered to 25 per cent and a bounty of $6 per engine introduced. These arrangements led to a review of the compensating charge applied to New Zealand lawnmowers. A further review of the New Zealand rate will be undertaken before 31 December 1986.

The change contained in Schedule 3 is operative on and from 23 May 1985 and amends the Customs tariff description of imported rum. This change is complementary to an excise tariff change and is done to reflect the revised standard for rum in accordance with the Government's decision on the National Health and Medical Research Council review of wines and spirits legislation. Duty rates are not altered by this change.
Schedule 4 to the Bill is operative on and from 1 July 1985 and contains changes which-
(I) correctly reflect the official titles of countries and places specified in Schedule 1 to the principal Act. Duty rates are not affected by these amendments;

(II) amend various provisions of the principal Act by removing redundant phasing rates of duty and amalgamating certain tariff classifications where removal of phasing rates has made this action possible;

(III) implement new arrangements to increase access for certain furniture and furniture components of New Zealand origin following consultations and agreement under the ANZCERTA to provide liberalised arrangements for these goods;

(IV) amend item 56 in Part I of Schedule 4 to the principal Act. This change extends to prescribed shipbuilders concessional entry of goods used in the construction or modification of bountiable vessels following an amendment to the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 which enabled these shipbuilders to be registered for bounty purposes.

Schedule 4 to this Bill also includes a number of changes which continue implementation of the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission report on the commercial by-law system. That decision provided for the introduction of a commercial tariff concession system which came into operation on 1 July 1983 but provided a two-year transitional period during which concessions under the commercial by-law system were to be phased out. Accordingly, those items or parts of items in Part I of Schedule 4 to the principal Act, which included a reference to commercial by-law system criteria, are omitted from 1 July 1985.

The decision to implement the commercial tariff concession system and subsequent decisions made by the Government in respect of particular goods do, however, require the continuation of certain concessional arrangements that would have otherwise lapsed on 1 July 1985. Accordingly, changes to Customs Tariff Act are being made to maintain concessional entry of certain goods, as follows:
(1) Goods entered under end-use under security provisions;
(2) goods imported to meet shortfall and fall- short situations;
(3) goods imported to enable the testing and evaluation of motor vehicles or motor vehicle components under the plan known as the passenger motor vehicle manufacturing plan;
(4) goods imported for use as prototypes for the manufacture of similar goods in Australia; and
(5) goods imported for use in petroleum exploration and development.

Concessional treatement for these goods is being maintained by providing new items 57 to 62 in Part I of Schedule 4 to the principal Act. The concession in respect of goods entered under end-use under security provisions is, however, of an interim nature as these goods are currently the subject of inquiries by the IAC. Similarly, the long term future of the concession for goods imported to meet shortfall or fallshort situations is to be determined by the Government following reviews by the IAC. In this respect some of these goods are already under reference to the Commission.

Finally, Schedule 4 to the Bill contains changes which introduce part of the new assistance arrangements for metal working machine tools and robots. The Government's decision on these arrangements was publicly announced by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on 30 May 1985.

Measures related to the bountry aspects of the arrangements were included in the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Bill 1985 which was introduced earlier in this sitting. That Bill proposes that the basis on which bounty is calculated be changed from Australian content to a value added principle. The new bounty scheme incorporates different rates of bounty for high and low technology machines and extends coverage of the scheme to include robots and machines such as flame and laser cutting machines and flexible manufacturing cells and systems. The bounty also extends to parts and accessories for these goods and parts and accessories for use as original equipment in the production of all bountiable metal working machine tools.
To complement the bounty arrangements, this Schedule contains those Customs tariff changes where duties are being lowered, as follows:

The insertion of new provisions at minimum rates for gas-operated appliances and laser or electric-operated metal working machines or apparatus when incorporating a computer control. These amendments have also resulted in new legal notes to define the term `computer control'; and
A new item in Part I of Schedule 4 to the principal Act to enable concessional entry of certain robots, and parts and accessories of a kind used solely or principally therewith.

Schedule 5 to the Bill is operative from 8 p.m. on Budget night, 20 August 1985. This Schedule contains certain tariff changes which increase the customs duty on imported manufactured tobacco by $5 per kilogram. These changes are complementary to changes proposed to the Excise Tariff Act which increase excise duty on locally produced manufactured tobacco by the same amount.

Schedule 6 of the Bill is operative on and from a date seven days after the date of royal assent. This Schedule incorporates further changes arising from the Government's decision on assistance arrangements for metal working machine tools and robots. Some of the goods covered by that decision are not subject to the bounty assistance arrangements to which I have already referred. As these changes involve an increase in the rate of duty applying to certain metal working machine tools and parts and accessories, the increased rates are not being brought into effect until seven days after the date of royal assent.

Schedule 6 also contains a minor change in the demarcation point between dutiable and duty free tractors following a Government decision on assistance arrangements to apply to agricultural wheeled tractors and certain parts. Other amendments contained in Schedule 6 ensure that the Customs Tariff Act uses correct spelling, grammatical and drafting forms. The need for these changes was identified during the ongoing review of the principal Act and they are not directed towards questions of industries assistance.

A further change relates to the rate of duty applying to chenille fabrics. These goods were under reference in the IAC's 1981 report on miscellaneous textile products. At that time the IAC recommended that chenille fabrics continue to be dutiable at minimum rates but drew attention to the possibility that imports of fabrics containing chenille yarn might erode the assistance provided to other fabrics. Accordingly, the IAC suggested that imports of chenille fabrics be monitored. The Government agreed with this approach. As a result of this monitoring, evidence of increasing imports of chenille fabrics was considered by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee. The Committee concluded, in its May 1985 report, that imports of fabrics containing chenille yarn were, in fact, eroding, and had the potential to further erode, assistance to woven man-made fibre fabrics. The Committee, therefore, recommended that imports of man-made fibre fabrics containing 20 per cent or less, by weight of chenille yarn be dutiable at 40 per cent the base quota rate for the equivalent man-made fibre fabrics. The government has accepted that recommendation.

Schedule 6 also introduces, first, two amendments to restore levels of assistance considered to have been removed by judgments of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; and secondly, three amendments to maintain the technical accuracy, remove a potential ambiguity and restore the intended coverage of certain provisions of the principal Act. Advice received from the Attorney-General's Department states that it is in order for such changes to be introduced directly by a Bill to amend the Customs Tariff Act. This procedure is being followed for goods known as polypropylene grass yarns and certain photographic chemicals which, as a result of Administrative Appeals Tribunal judgments, have had their intended levels of assistance substantially reduced.

The level of assistance for polypropylene grass yarns, which are principally used for the production of outdoor carpet, was last considered by the IAC in its 1981 Miscellaneous Textile Products report. Two major local manufacturers gave evidence to the IAC which recommended that the existing general tariff rate of 30 per cent be maintained. The Government accepted the IAC's recommendation. An importer of polypropylene grass yarns subsequently challenged the tariff classification of these yarns and obtained a ruling that such yarns were classified in a different tariff item from the one in which the 30 per cent rate of duty applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good yarn.

—Yes, and it is a clean one. As a result, the importer was able to enter goods which competed directly with the Australian product at minimum rates. Local manufacturers have made representations to the Government concerning their loss of assistance and requested that assistant levels be restored to that recommended by the IAC. After consideration of this matter, the Government accepts that intended assistance levels should be restored and, accordingly, an appropriate amendment to the Customs Tariff Act is being made by this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of certain photographic chemicals, the wording of the relevant provision was amended as a result of the Government's decision on the IAC report on customs tariff simplification but a general rate of duty of 15 per cent was maintained. An importer challenged the tariff classification applied to certain imported photographic chemicals before the AAT and the tribunal ruled that the wording contained in the simplified customs tariff enabled entry of the goods at minimum rates of duty. The terms of reference for the tariff simplification inquiry required that levels of assistance not be substantially altered. The revised wording applying to the photographic chemicals in question has, however, had the effect of substantially altering the intended level of assistance for such goods. Accordingly, the Government proposes in this Bill to restore the assistance level for the photographic chemicals involved.
The other changes in Schedule 6 which are being introduced directly by Bill relate to:

the correct definition of goods known as ethylene oxide derivatives. The Government has accepted the need for these changes after considering technical advice received from officers of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories; the removal of a potential ambiguity in the tariff description applying to certain plastic coated man-made fibre fabrics. As presently worded, the description might be interpreted as applying to a different range of plastic coated fabrics than intended; and a change in the tariff description of certain wrapping paper following research which confirms that the relevant provision should not apply to papers produced by a coating process.

Schedule 7 to the Bill introduces new assistance arrangements for the production of heavy commercial motor vehicles, parts and accessories, effective from 1 January 1986. In deciding upon these changes, the Government recognised that the level of activity and employment in the industry is related to the level of activity in the assembly sector. In recent years, the asssitance afforded assembly acitivy has been high, the industry has become more fragmented and local content and market share have declined.

Accordingly, the Government has decided that a modest reduction in assistance levels is warranted and could lead to an improvement in the structure of the industry whilst restraining costs and maintaining significant employment levels. The new arrangements are reflected in the introduction of a uniform 20 per cent general rate of duty for general purpose heavy commercial vehicles, most special purpose vehicles and fire-engines. This represents an increase in duties in respect of certain small fire-engines but a reduction in respect of the other vehicles to which I have referred. Split rates of duty on crane lorries are replaced by a single 30 per cent general rate of duty.

The current bounty arrangements on selected components will be phased out over a period of three years and be progressively replaced by an equivalent customs tariff which, by 1 January 1989, will reach a general rate of duty of 25 per cent. The change from bounty to tariff assistance is not designed to alter the level of assistance accorded these components. Filters, which presently attract general rates of duty of 2 per cent, 25 per cent or 35 per cent, depending upon their tariff classification, will become dutiable at a uniform rate of 25 per cent. Filters of New Zealand origin will, however, remain dutiable at current rates. In addition, the Government has asked the Automotive Industry Council to advise on what additional local components would be competitive with imports at the 25 per cent general tariff rate.

Schedule 7 also includes changes to the customs value criteria applying to certain footwear from 1 January 1986. These changes arise from the Government's acceptance of a recommendation by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee, in its May 1985 report, that the value of certain footwear increase from $1.15 to $1.35 per pair to help maintain the basic character of footwear not subject to quota. The value criterion of certain non-leather foot-wear is also increased from $9.50 to $11 per pair to help maintain the basic character of the product mix covered by two footwear quota categories. These changes also include the developing country arrangements for footwear to apply during 1986 under the textiles, clothing and footwear sectoral policy. Among the developing country arrangements is an increase from $3 per pair to $3.50 per pair in the value criterion for hand-made leather footwear.

Schedule 8 to the Bill is operative on and from the day on which certain sections of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 come into operation. The change contained in Schedule 8 relates to an amendement to item 15 in Part I of Schedule 4 to the Customs Tariff Act to enable the duty free entry of certain goods purchased at airports by passengers arriving from overseas. This change is complementary to the changes being proposed to other customs and excise legislation to implement the Government's decision in respect of inwards duty free shopping.
Financial Impact

Honourable members may recall that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his statement of 27 March 1985 on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure report on taxation expenditure, pointed out that the revenues raised by customs duties are incidental to their prime function of assistance to industry. With this proviso in mind, it has been possible to make estimates of the expected losses and gains in customs revenue in respect of the following new arrangements: A reveue gain of approximately $1m per annum could be expected in respect of metal working machine tools and robots; and a reduction of some $4m per annum in revenue is anticipated in relation to the heavy commercial motor vehicle changes. This reduction could be offset to some extent by increased imports of certain vehicles. In both cases there is also complementary bounty legislation. The bounty payments to be outlaid under the respective pieces of legislation also need to be taken into account to obtain the total impact of these assistance arrangements. For the financial year 1986-87 it is anticipated that a total of $16m will be outlaid under the two bounty schemes.

In regard to the provision to enable the introduction of inwards duty free shopping, the second reading speech for the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 addresses the question of financial impact. The changes in respect of polypropylene grass yarns and photographic chemicals, which are designed to restore levels of assistance considered to have been removed by Administrative Appeals Tribunal judgments, have a financial impact when judged against the revenue which would otherwise have been collected under the tariff classifications applied by the Tribunal. For polypropylene grass yarns, the change will result in approximately a $0.3m gain in a full year. The change on photographic chemicals is expected to result in a gain of $0.7m in a financial year.

The Government's decision to increase the duty on certain chenille fabrics may, by reducing the possibility of fabrics containing minimal chenille yarn being used in substitution for other fabrics, result in a $0.2m gain in a full financial year. All the other changes in the Bill are expected to have minimal financial impact. There are no significant administrative costs associated with the Bill. A summary of amendments for each Schedule to the Bill has been prepared. Copies are available from the Tables Office. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Augmentation of the taxiway system, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

The proposal is for the construction of new taxiways, reconstruction of an existing taxiway and provision of larger fillets at taxiway and runway intersections. The work is required to facilitate more efficient handling of aircraft and to reduce taxying delays and operating costs. The end result will be a reduction of present congestion and delay, together with reduced inconvenience to the travelling public.

Honourable members may be aware that Sydney Airport is small in size by international standards. What is not well known is that it ranks about thirty-second in terms of annual passenger and aircraft movements, and that in terms of relative capacity it is as busy as airports of top ranking. The Public Works Committee has reported favourably on the proposal and has recommended its construction. The Committee recommended also that consideration be given to the use of larger radii for heavily used runway entry points and that a study be undertaken into the provision of a rapid exit taxiway located south of taxiway A on the main 16-34 runway.

The Department of Aviation has examined the benefit, cost and practicality of further increasing the radius of runway entry points. The radius of existing entry points is 42 metres and an increase to 80 metres is proposed. This will raise the theoretical design entry speed from 14 knots to 20 knots. A further increase in the radius of entry points would raise the design entry speed, but at a substantial extra cost. For example, if the radius of the three entry points were increased to 250 metres, the entry speed at those locations would be raised to 35 knots at an estimated extra cost of $2m. An increase of the radius of the three entry points to 520 metres would raise the design entry speed to 50 knots at an extra cost of approximately $3m.

The Department of Aviation has advised that the construction of entry points with larger radii could not be justified on economic grounds and that difficult operational problems are involved when aircraft enter runways from curved taxiways at higher speeds and powers. Accordingly, it is not intended to include radii larger than those currently proposed at heavily used runway entry points.

As recommended by the Committee, a study also has been made of the proposal to provide a rapid exit taxiway south of taxiway A from the 16-34 runway. Construction of such a taxiway would involve the acquisition and reclamation of a part of Botany Bay, the lowering of part of General Holmes Drive, the provision of a taxiway bridge over General Holmes Drive and other associated works at a cost in the order of $16m. The Department of Aviation concluded that the benefit obtained from the construction of such a rapid exit taxiway would not at present justify expenditure of this magnitude.

The estimated cost of the proposed work, when referred to the Public Works Committee, was $16.4m at January 1985 prices. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee with a view to commencement of construction in the latter part of the 1985-86 financial year. I commend this motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the proposal. It is well known that there are increasing delays and congestion at Sydney Airport. In fact, both of the recommendations we are talking about this afternoon relate to moves to reduce the congestion and costly delays at Sydney Airport. Planes which fly into Sydney Airport quite often are required to circle overhead for some time before getting clearance to land. This is not just costly; it is inconvenient for people and it is negative from the point of view of the image of Kingsford-Smith Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The taxiway proposals that have been put forward by the Public Works Committee, as referred to by the Minister for Housing and Constructon (Mr West), certainly will assist in a more efficient operation at Kingsford-Smith Airport, but other action also is needed. I understand that new radar will be installed by mid-1987 and that certainly is essential. I am advised that there is also a need for flow control computers to be able to plot earlier and more completely and accurately the flight paths of aircraft so that they arrive and take off in a more appropriate and efficient manner.

I understand that the report of the Select Committee on Aircraft Noise, which is examining noise levels at airports around Australia, will be tabled shortly in this Parliament. Hopefully, that will be followed by an announcement by the Government on what I would call a more targeted and specific curfew arrangement at Mascot Airport, in relation to the types of aircraft, individual noise levels of those aircraft and use of runways. This will allow a more flexible curfew at Mascot Airport to allow for a more efficient utilisation of that airport.

The Government also will be making an announcement shortly concerning which of the sites of Wilton or Badgerys Creek will be the site for the second Sydney airport. However, that airport will not be completed until perhaps the year 2000. When the coalition Government lost office, it was well advanced with a proposal for a close spaced north-south parallel runway at Mascot Airport, because of its recognition of the congestion problem to which I have referred. My understanding is that there is now also consideration-not by the Government, but by those people who are concerned that Mascot Airport should be an efficient airport for Sydney, New South Wales and Australia generally in the long term future-for a wide-spaced parallel runway. That would be at the general aviation end of the airport, would not intrude as much into Botany Bay and, therefore, would not have those complications.

The point I make briefly is that I believe that whoever is in Government in the early 1990s will face a decision which will require the construction of a parallel runway at Mascot Airport because of the delays and congestion that will be then evident, irrespective of any improvements that will follow from the construction of these taxiways or other measures that may take place in the near future. What we are looking at today is an advance in that it is a recognition of this increasing delay situation at Mascot Airport, but by itself it will not in any way solve the problem. I have mentioned some of those other requirements, but in particular, sooner or later-probably by the early 1990s-I believe that the Government then in power will have to accept the inevitability of a parallel runway at Mascot Airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) for making available information to my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and me prior to his raising the matter in the House. As we all know, the Government is currently involved in what might cogently be described as a high risk economic strategy. Interest rates are currently at record levels in order to protect the value of the Australian dollar. The Government has repeatedly stated that it is its intention to keep interest rates at high levels because if they allow them to drift down, the Australian dollar will come down, the accord will collapse and we will have a new round of inflation and devaluation. This policy has had the effect of drying up liquidity in our community, specifically drying up housing loans- there are rationings in housing loans now-and interest rates, because of the cocktail method of lending, are now higher than they would otherwise have been.

SPEECH.PARA: We are moving toward an area of slackening economic activity and toward an area that will lead to the failure of the Government's economic policies. In those circumstances, we believe that the Government should be giving more attention to both its wages and its fiscal policy. Its wages policy at the moment relies heavily on the accord, and the accord has led us to a situation in which we are uncompetitive in world markets, and there is a need for less rigidity in our wages system. We do not quite know where the Government is in its situation with the accord.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the honourable member speaking to the motion?
—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am coming-
—I think that the honourable member is extending his remarks rather wide of the motion and I ask him to restrict them to the motion.

—I am coming to the question of fiscal policy, which is about Government spending, and this is a motion on Government spending. We do not quite know where the Government is on its wages policy. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have been blustering-

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. This motion is not a matter of fiscal policy at all; it relates to the augmentation of taxiway systems at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to confine this new and inexperienced shadow Minister to the matter in hand and to ask him to resume his seat if he does not do so.
—The point of order is sustained. I ask the honourable member once again to restrict his remarks to the motion.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. May I point out to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), for his benefit, that fiscal policy involves Government spending and the motion before us is a motion on Government spending? It is to that area that we believe that the Minister for Housing and Construction should give some attention, because the question that he really has to ask himself is: In the current economic climate, is this fiscal policy proposal on Government spending really appropriate? Nowhere in his statement does the Minister refer to the new Federal Airports Corporation Bill which was put in front of us earlier this afternoon. On page 3 of the Bill, Clause 6 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The functions of the Corporation are-
(a) to operate Federal airports in Australia . . .

It seems to me that if the function of the new Federal Airports Corporation is to operate Federal airports in Australia, surely the proposal that the Minister is putting to us today must come under its control. We suggest that the Minister should consult his colleague in order to ensure that we do not get another bureaucratic mess by this proposal falling between two departments. We certainly do not want to see $16m worth of taxpayers' money wasted. We would also be glad if the Minister would ensure that the maximum amount of work is given to the private sector in this project. Having cautioned the Government about the need for control of fiscal policy, I reiterate what my colleague the honourable member for Murray said, that the Opposition does not oppose this work.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Cunningham-Minister for Housing and Construction) (5.55)-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report:
Improvement of international terminal facilities, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

This proposed public work is remodelling and expansion of a number of areas of the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) international terminal to cater more adequately for current levels of international passenger traffic. The terminal was designed to handle aircraft movements and passenger loadings generated by the narrow-bodied aircraft prevalent in the early 1970s when the facility was commissioned. Some limited allowance was made to accommodate the then emerging wide-bodied aircraft types. Since that time the aircraft apron has been extended to handle wide-bodies jets but no major works have been carried out in the terminal itself. The terminal is now regularly seriously overcrowded, notwithstanding limitations placed on utilisation of the building and its services and controls placed on passenger arrival and departure rates. While it would be inappropriate to commit the proposed Federal Airports Corporation to a redevelopment program by commencing construction of major new facilities, it is essential that something be done to alleviate conditions.
It is proposed, therefore, that works be undertaken within the existing building complex and in its immediate vicinity including:
Extensions to and upgrading of the arrivals and departures levels including check-in, passenger processing, concession and baggage reclaim areas
provision of a new transit lounge;
upgrading of baggage conveyor facilities; and
provision of two additional aerobridges.

Subject to Public Works Committee considerations, it is planned that work commence in the first half of 1986 with a view to completion about the end of 1988. During this time the terminal will continue to operate, so there will be some unavoidable inconvenience to users. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $20m at September 1985 prices. I table plans of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second of the two proposals to relieve some of the congestion and delays that have occurred at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport at Mascot over the years. Once again, the Opposition does not oppose these recommendations. However, I should like to make some comments about whether the proposal is adequate. It certainly is correct that no major upgrading of the international terminal has taken place since its construction, and the $20m is a significant amount of expenditure. But if one looks at where the congestion will be relieved-and anyone who travels through Sydney's international terminal will be very much aware of this congestion-one will see that it is basically in the check-in and processing of passengers. This ignores one of the other problem areas, and that is the need for additional standing space or parking space for aircraft. I note that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has said that there will be two additional aerobridges.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the points that the Minister made was that it would be inappropriate for the Government to commit any greater expenditure on Sydney Airport or on the international terminal at Sydney Airport at this time because the Federal Airports Corporation is about to be put in place. In fact, as my colleague the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) mentioned, we have just had the introduction of the legislation for that Corporation. But I do not think that that is a particularly consistent argument when one considers that the second Sydney airport, at a cost of about $1,200m, is going on regardless of the Federal Airports Corporation. A new terminal is being built at Perth and at Brisbane a complete new airport is being built at a cost of about $500m. I hope that the Government will very shortly announce improvements to the Darwin Airport terminal, and hopefully that will be done well ahead of the Federal Airports Corporation being put in place because anybody who has been through the old aircraft hangar in Darwin will be well aware of the problem there.

I am not on the Public Works Committee and so I ask whether Committee members were aware that a proposal was put to the Government for the actual construction of a separate arrivals terminal in the international area at Sydney. My understanding-I am quite happy to be corrected if it is wrong-is that that would also have been privately financed; there would not have been any requirement for government finance and it would have achieved several significant improvements to the congestion problem in the international area. Firstly, it would not have caused inconvenience to the passengers. The Minister rightly makes the point that while this reconstruction is going on people using the terminal will be inconvenienced. Secondly, it would provide the additional capacity which is needed. More importantly, part of that proposal was to double the standing or parking area for aircraft from 13 to 26 places. It makes me wonder whether or not that information was available to the Committee. I suppose that if it was the Committee could do nothing about it because it could only follows this particular reference.

I want to make the point that, although acknowledging the need for improvements to the international terminal, I have doubts that the way the Government is proceeding with this is the most appropriate way, the most efficient way-and the most cost efficient way also, as I understand this counter-proposal to be-and one which will overcome congestion problems in the international area for many years to come. Irrespective of a second Sydney airport-once again we are talking about the year 2000-Sydney will remain and must remain the major international gateway for Australia and therefore anything that can be done now to overcome these problems for many years, and overcome them in a more cost efficient way, would appear to me to be a better way to go about solving this problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I thank the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) for making the information available to my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and me. The Opposition has no objection to the referral of this project to the Public Works Committee. I just note that the Minister, in dealing with the improvement of the international terminal facilities, mentioned the new Federal Airports Corporation but in his previous submission on the augmentation of the taxiway system he did not. We commend the Minister for his foresight as far as this project is concerned in ensuring that the Federal Airports Corporation is properly involved in the necessary consultations. Again we ask the Minister to enjoin the Public Works Committee to ensure that the private sector is involved to the maximum extent. Finally, we ask him to give some consideration in terms of timing to the Government's need to address itself to appropriate fiscal policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOME AND COMMUNITY CARE BILL 1985[COGNATE BILL:HOME AND COMMUNITY CARE (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the home and community care legislation was adjourned before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was making the point that when we are considering the additional services to be provided under these Bills we have to be very careful to ensure that home care is not taken in isolation, because there has to be a widespread and adequate support structure to back up the elderly citizens among us who are going to stay in their own homes. There has to be adequate provision of meals on wheels, and of home maintenance because for really elderly persons enjoying the after hours of their working lives things like mending broken windows or even changing a light bulb can create an incredible problem. This sort of assistance has to be available.

SPEECH.PARA: Community nursing is also of vast importance, as is the provision of home help for people who can no longer clean their bathrooms or do any of those basic things which are so important in maintaining the standard and quality of a home. Clearly the home and community care program is only one arm of the two parts necessary for aged services. Nursing homes will still be needed and adequate nursing home provision must still be made. In my electorate of Cowper, according to the 1981 Census, 14.1 per cent of the population was aged 65 years and over while those aged 70 years and over amounted to 7.94 per cent of the population. The formula for nursing home beds is considered to be one bed for every 12 1/2 people aged 70 years and over. Based on the current population estimates for the local government areas comprising the electorate of Cowper and assuming that the proportion of people aged 70 years and over has remained constant since the 1981 Census, the electorate of Cowper should have 825 nursing home beds. Instead it has only 590. That demonstrates quite clearly that in spite of the agreed need for more home and community care there is still a drastic need for nursing home beds in many parts of Australia.

The home and community care program should not therefore be an alternative to the provision of funding for nursing homes. I know that this Government is committed to improving the facilities available in the community, and I commend it for that, but in the friendliest fashion, I warn it about neglecting the need for and the provision of nursing home beds because it is a problem that is not going to go away. It will not solve itself and there has to be adequate funding to cater for an increasing need which will continue to grow from year to year.

The home and community care program seeks to provide a range of integrated home care and community based services for people who, in the absence of such support, would be at risk of either premature or inappropriate institutionalisation. I draw attention to one particular area of my electorate of Cowper-the Macleay Valley. To refresh the House's memory, the Macleay Valley runs through very fertile farmlands with marvellous beef cattle and dairy properties, great cheese production and a useful and very valuable tourist component in places like Hat Head, South West Rocks and Crescent Head. It also has in Kempsey a significant and useful industrial base with such companies as Clark Brick Ltd, Akubra hats and King Gee overalls. It is because of this very solid and productive area where people like to live that we have the present problem. In the Macleay Valley there is one nursing home, which is privately owned, and it applied earlier this year for additional beds. There is also a community group based on a number of senior citizens who have applied for funding to provide a community based nursing home. Both of these applications have been under consideration for most of this year. I have been in frequent contact with some officers of the Department of Community Services to try to speed up this process.

There certainly is a demonstrated need. But the present situation is most unsatisfactory on two counts. The senior citizens group has been most active and diligent in raising money. It has been assisted by service clubs and it has already raised a limited amount of money. But it is still waiting in frustration, not knowing whether it is going to get funding or not. Equally, the privately owned nursing home, which is ready to expand, has had a substantial sum of money tied up-for which it is paying a holding fee-for some months awaiting a decision. I take this opportunity to say to the Government and to the Minister for Community Service (Senator Grimes) that it would be most appropriate if we could do the right thing and make a decision. We should say to the privately owned nursing home: `You are not going to get it; so save the money that you have tied up, or `You will get it; so go full speed ahead'. Alternatively we should say to the senior citizens group: `You will get it; go full steam ahead', or in fairness to it, if it is not going to get the capital funding, we should put it in the picture too. I hope the Minister will make some decision on this quickly.

I would like to pay a tribute to the very large number of people associated with the care of the aged in my electorate. This applies right through the Hastings Valley, Macleay, Nambucca, Bellingen and Coffs Harbour areas. A number of bodies are doing an excellent job. I would like to mention in passing an assessment and rehabilitation team in Coffs Harbour headed by Dr Gordon Myall which has provided a report to the Commonwealth on the needs in that particular area. One of the problems is that there is a need to maximise the use of nursing home beds. We have to be quite certain that there are suitable beds for slow stream rehabilitation and for respite care. Patients should be encouraged to move on from a nursing home situation when they are well enough. It should not necessarily follow that any aged citizen who goes into a nursing home should be there to stay. I know this is the Government's policy in producing these other services. Again I do the right thing and commend the Government.

One of the other problems that has to be addressed is that if people are going to be taken out of a nursing home because they have received some rehabilitation which enables them to leave, we have to look at the provision of hostel accommodation as well. We should look at the needs of aged people and assess how the system can best work. I think the best way is to have a collection of units where a husband and wife can live by themselves, sustain themselves and look after themselves. What generally happens is that one partner passes on and the remaining partner moves into a hostel, receives the support of the surrounding community and the people running the hostel and, if the need occurs, ultimately moves into a nursing home proper. I think it should be pointed out that the costs of respite care, whether in a nursing home or a hostel, for one partner is usually beyond the means of most married couples who must still maintain their home and meet all their expenses, particularly when they are dependent on the pension as their only income.

There is a great need for hostel accommodation for the increasing number of single aged people who are finding that living alone is much more difficult but who are still too fit, too well and too able to be moved into a nursing home. One interesting idea that has recently emerged is the group home, where a number of aged people can live together in a small community. There are already a number of group homes operating in New South Wales. Some are based on the Abbyfield concept of supervised living and others in the Sydney metropolitan area have been instigated by local councils. However, there are some doubts about a group home situation. Some people could be concerned about security and, of course, there could be concern about the fitness or frailty of intending residents. Most importantly, the expectations of independence have to be catered for and there also has to be provision in the planning for future or incipient institutionalisation.

While many towns and suburbs have a community centre or a senior citizens centre, a great many communities throughout Australia do not have what so many people regard as a basic provision. Elderly people, living as married couples or alone, can suffer greatly from loneliness. This is one of the greatest problems that can be faced by any person. I see this very frequently; I am concerned about it and I care about it. I believe we need to work together in this Parliament to create the attitude which will lead to funding to provide for very special services. Nothing is going to make an elderly person who is living alone break down and die faster than being left alone, having no stimulation-just sitting by himself. I strongly advocate the provision of either senior citizen centres or community centres because they can provide a range of activities which would be of use to elderly people. I refer to day centre activities-card games, basket weaving and all sorts of other craft activities. There could be more formal educational activities. Just because someone is old does not mean that his or her brain has stopped. The provision of some educational activities could be very valuable indeed. The right sort of centre could include some paramedical services or even Meals on Wheels. But above all, such a centre would be valuable as a social centre, a drop-in centre, where the aged could be real people again, not people excluded from society, not people on whom we are practising our own particular form of apartheid. I am totally against the segregation of people. One of the things we have lost in our society is what I enjoyed as a young boy-contact with oldies. My kids were fortunate that they had the same thing, but there are so many communities in Australia where old people have no contact with children and children have no contact with old people. This is a very sad criticism of the way our society has gone.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a real problem.

—It is a very real problem. I have spoken about the need for care of the aged in community centres and so on, but even those in nursing homes are in need of more stimulation. The provision of occupational therapists and occupational therapy aids can make a tremendous difference to the people in nursing homes. More effort needs to be made to stimulate the residents with a variety of activities organised from within or outside the homes. Experience has found that the relatives of the residents may initially be antagonistic towards such changes but usually they work out and are in the best interests of our old people. I support the Government's home and community care program, but I stress that there is a great need for more nursing home beds and we should not ignore that need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members from both sides of the House who have made a contribution to the debate on this legislation. On the whole the contributions made by everyone who has contributed to the debate have been constructive. In general terms, they supported the Government's purpose in this legislation to create a program that will enable a much wider range of choices not only for people within the aged community but also for people with various disabilities who would be assisted by community support.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that characterise the contributions of Opposition members to debate from time to time is the goodies and baddies syndrome that we saw reflected at Question Time today. It seems that, while they welcome the program, they have suggested, on the one hand-this came from the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt)-that the Government has done some terrible things and introduced some measures which restrict expenditure on the aged and, on the other hand, that the Government is not doing enough in the home and community care program.

A number of references were made to the expenditure of $300m over three years to which the Government has made a commitment. The suggestion was that somehow this program is being underfunded, the implication being that there ought to be more money for the home and community care program because it falls in the area of goodies, and that more things ought to be done under this program, particularly in individual members' electorates.

The reality is that this program is a developmental program. In the first three years it is designed in a sense to carve the way towards a more comprehensive home and community care program. While the additional Commonwealth funding is substantial over the first three years of the program, it nevertheless takes us towards something like a 20 per cent real increase in funding for the programs relevant to the home and community care program. That is a very substantial rate of growth in new money. But, of course, it is recognised by the Government that there will need to be very substantial funding if the basic philosophical thrust of the Government is to be realised.

It is not true, as members of the Opposition have suggested, that somehow the Government is developing an anti-nursing home stance. That is not true. The Government recognises that we need a balance of services, that there has been a very severe imbalance in Commonwealth funding in recent years and that much more money has been provided for accommodation. As one speaker pointed out-I think it was the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay)-as funding for accommodation has been very largely Commonwealth funding, it suited the States to encourage the Commonwealth to spend more and more money on accommodation. It has not suited them to put in the kind of investment that is necessary in the local community to ensure that the very high proportion of people who remain at home have the kind of support that enables them to live useful and happy lives.

About 75 per cent of people over 65 years of age with moderate or severe handicaps and needing daily assistance require that assistance at the moment to come from their immediate family or friends. Under the programs which existed prior to the introduction of the HACC program, the vast majority of people in the community who perhaps required some support were left to carry on without that broader community support that is necessary. We do not see this support as in any sense a desire to replace institutional accommodation which, of course, will be required for people with particular needs.

I noted that the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) complimented the Government on the fact that we will put much greater emphasis on assessment. He made the extremely important point that many people who go into institutional accommodation often are encouraged to remain there for the rest of their lives. Very often that is not a good thing for those people. Very often the people who go into institutional accommodation could, with some support, remain in the community.

The measures that the Government-and indeed the Opposition, in its support of them-is endorsing will not be cheap. It is very easy to say that we need to move away from institutional care towards community-based care as a matter of principle. But, of course, we will still need to sustain very heavy spending on nursing homes, hostels and that kind of accommodation. At the same time very substantial spending will need to be sustained to provide better community support. That is why the Government has sought to achieve a negotiated situation in which the Commonwealth, the States-with increased assistance from the Commonwealth-and local government and community organisations can together work to provide a much more adequate program of support. That is ambitious and will be costly over a period. But in the long run it will have some savings built into it.

I guess the question that one asks oneself, given the bipartisan support for these measures, is whether the funding will in the long run also receive bipartisan support. As the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) suggested, the rhetoric of the Opposition has been that public expenditure needs to be severely cut back. We hear a great deal about areas in which it can be cut back. One hopes that the support that has been given to these measures by the Opposition indicates that in the future we will see projected the kind of growth that the Government has in mind so that in the long term-this is a program with a long term dimension there will be support from both sides of the House to ensure that the objectives of the program are achieved.

I conclude at that point. As I said, honourable members have made a very constructive contribution. The Bills are extremely important in laying the foundations for maximising the choices for aged people, not simply so that they can live longer but so that they can live much fuller and more satisfying lives.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Howe) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON AUSTRALIA CARD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a joint select committee be appointed to inquire into and report on all aspects of the government's proposals for an Australia Card, including-
(a) the costs of introducing and operating the system;

(b) the likely effectiveness of the proposed system in combating evasion of, and fraud against, the taxation and welfare systems, and in fulfilling the other purposes for which the system has been proposed;
(c) the most appropriate means of identification which should appear on Australia Cards to ensure the effectiveness of the system;
(d) the most appropriate method of establishing positive identification of individuals for the purpose of issuing Australia Cards;
(e) the experience of other countries in utilising identification systems;
(f) the inclusion of adequate protection against abuses of civil liberties and invasion of privacy;
(g) the comparable cost-effectiveness of alternative proposals to combat evasion of, and fraud against, the taxation and welfare system and the other purposes for which the system has been proposed;
(h) whether use of the Australia Card should be universal and/or compulsory and, if so, for what purposes and by whom;
(i) limits which should be placed on the requirement for individuals to produce an Australia Card;

(j) the extent to which the Australia Card may facilitate data linkage by Commonwealth departments and authorities, and the most appropriate means whereby such data linkage should be subjected to adequate supervision and safeguards, and
(k) other related matters which the committee may deem appropriate.

(2) That the committee consist of 8 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by effluxion of time.
(5) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman.

(6) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall perform the duties of the chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chairman and the deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee, the members present shall elect another member to perform the duties of the chairman at that meeting.
(7) That 4 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(8) That the committee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(9) That the committee have power to move from place to place.
(10) That the committee have power to adjourn from time to time.
(11) That the committee have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(12) That the committee report by 31 March 1986.
(13) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(15) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

Honourable members will recall that on 17 October 1985 I assured the House that I would, at an appropriate time, move on behalf of the Government for the establishment of a joint select committee to investigate and report to the Parliament on the Australia Card proposal. This motion fulfils that assurance.

As I then said, the Government has from the outset encouraged and welcomed public debate on the proposal. We recognise that any major change such as this needs the widest possible community understanding. It is for this reason that the Government has agreed to the establishment of this joint select committee with terms of reference which encompass the broadest possible range of issues associated with the proposal.

The terms of reference of the committee indicate quite clearly just how determined the Government is to ensure that this matter is subjected to the widest possible scrutiny. For the information of the House let me reiterate those terms of reference, which require the committee to inquire into and report on all aspects of the Government's proposals for an Australia Card, including:
(a) the costs of introducing and operating the system;

(b) the likely effectiveness of the proposed system in combating evasion of and fraud against the taxation and welfare systems, and in fulfilling the other purposes for which the system has been proposed;
(c) the most appropriate means of identification which should appear on Australia Cards to ensure the effectiveness of the system;
(d) the most appropriate method of establishing positive identification of individuals for the purpose of issuing cards;
(e) the experience of other countries in utilising identification systems;
(f) the inclusion of adequate protection against abuses of civil liberties and invasion of privacy;
(g) the comparable cost-effectiveness of alternative proposals to combat evasion of and fraud against the taxation and welfare system and the other purposes for which the system has been proposed;
(h) whether use of the Australia Card should be universal and/or compulsory and, if so, for what purposes and by whom;
(i) limits which should be placed on the requirement for individuals to produce an Australia Card;

(j) the extent to which the Australia Card may facilitate data linkage by Commonwealth departments and authorities, and the most appropriate means whereby such data linkage be subject to adequate supervision and safeguards; and
(k) other related matters which the committee may deem appropriate.

The terms of reference have been designed to enable the Parliament thoroughly to investigate the main aspects of the proposal and to satisfy itself as to the advantages which will accrue from its early introduction. Some honourable members have raised with me a concern as to whether the resolution enables the committee to attend to the issue of the Australia Card and illegal immigration. I believe that there is no reason for such disquiet. The phrase `the other purposes for which the system has been proposed', twice used in the resolution, clearly includes action against illegal immigration which was explicitly referred to in my speech to the Tax Summit. It would therefore be my expectation that the committee will examine the Australia Card and illegal immigration.

Through the committee, the Parliament will be able to satisfy itself that the benefits of the proposal will far outweigh its costs, that the civil liberties and privacy of our citizens will be adequately protected, and that the Australia Card proposal will be sufficiently effective in combating fraud against this nation's tax and welfare systems.

Members of the House will also note that the committee is to be required to report to the Parliament by 31 March 1986. Again, as I informed the House on 17 October last, in order to facilitate both the committee's deliberations and the proper planning for the Australia Card proposal, the committee will be requested to limit its activities prior to February 1986 to the soliciting and consideration of public submissions. Government departments and agencies will, where required, present submissions and evidence to the committee in February 1986.

The Health Insurance Commission will present its final planning report to the committee immediately upon completion of that report late in February 1986. Further, as previously agreed, I will arrange for release to the committee of the report of the Interdepartmental Committee on the National Identity System of 29 August 1985 and the interim planning report of the Health Insurance Commission of August 1985.

My introduction of this motion today will, I trust, be indicative of the Government's desire to subject this proposal to the closest possible public and parliamentary scrutiny. It is our belief that the committee will provide to honourable members the answers to the many questions that have been raised, both inside the Parliament and in the community, and will satisfy the various public concerns that have been expressed. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have stated on a number of occasions, both in this House and outside, the Opposition is deeply concerned about tax evasion and social security fraud. We, of course, want to ensure that everybody in the community contributes their fair and equitable share to the cost of providing government services. It is true that we believe overall government expenditure should be reduced. Nevertheless, there will be a continuing need for a fair and equitable system of raising revenue. Therefore, we have no hesitation in making the commitment to review positively any proposals which will overcome the problems of social security fraud and tax evasion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government originally proposed an identification card during the Tax Summit. No convincing case was put to the Tax Summit regarding the effectiveness of the proposal or its likely cost-benefit outcome. There was then some discussion within the Government ranks particularly about the privacy implications of the proposal. No further information was given to the public and in general we, the Australian citizenry, were left in the dark. Then out of the blue, on 19 September, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that we were going to have an Australia Card. In the same 20 lines that he gave to the Australia Card proposal in his statement he said that it was going to be effective in combating tax evasion and ending social security fraud. The only additional information provided was by way of an attachment to the Treasurer's statement. Some sketchy details of the proposal were provided in that three-and-a-half page attachment.

At no stage has any detailed information been provided to justify the Government's claims for the Australia Card. The fact that no such information has been provided makes me wonder whether the Government has such information. I have grave doubts that the Government can actually substantiate the claims that it has made. Therefore, when the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), the same Minister who has been responsible for introducing the most expensive, cruel and now totally discredited health system, came into this chamber--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is better than yours.

—Listen to the false horse laughs. This Government is the only government that has provided a two-tiered system of health care, one for the rich and one for the poor. The wealthy can pay to get into a hospital bed when they require one, while the poor pensioners get in a queue. They do not even have access--
—Order! I suggest that the honourable member for Barker return to the motion before the House.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I express genuine concern for the pensioners of this country-the 26,500, for example, in Victoria who are waiting for hospital beds under this Government's health system.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, the same Minister came into the House three or four weeks ago with legislation seeking $3.5m to fund the issue of the Australia Card. Naturally enough the Opposition called a halt to this runaway fiasco. At that time we suggested a committee of inquiry to see whether, in fact, a case could be made out and whether the Government could establish a case to support the identification card proposal. We want to know whether the card will actually be effective in combating tax evasion and social security fraud; we want to know whether the cost involved in introducing and operating ID cards will, in fact, be less than the expected increase in tax revenue and the reduction in welfare payments; and we want to know whether adequate protection of the privacy of the individual can be provided under the Government's proposal. Further, we made it clear that we would oppose any further expenditure on the card until the Government had provided evidence to substantiate the case it was making out and then we will consider the issue.

Faced with our opposition and with the fact that the legislation would not get through the Senate, the Government finally backed down and agreed to a committee of inquiry. When forced into this position to accept an inquiry and to prove its case, the Minister for Health comes along and says: `We have always welcomed public discussion and we have always wanted to provide a full public debate'. If the Government wanted to have a full public debate, why did it not provide us with some information?

TALK.START.PARA: —You blokes don't have enough brains to understand.

—Well, neither does the honourable member, quite clearly, and that is more the pity because it appears that the Government's State party organisations are not happy with the Government's decision. We have made no decision for or against an ID card. We want to see the facts that the Government supposedly has. If the facts are available, why is the Government hiding them? The case which the Government has put to date in favour of the Australia Card is not only lacking in detail and fails to substantiate the claims made, but it is also internally inconsistent. In addition, subsequent relevations by the Minister for Health have undermined both the projected revenue forecasts and have added to the doubts about the integrity of the proposed card. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), when he announced that we were going to have an Australia Card, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to combat tax evasion and reduce health and welfare fraud, the government has decided to implement a national identification system involving the issue to individuals of a card to be known as the Australia Card.

There is no doubt that we would all like to combat tax evasion and health and welfare fraud, but the question is: Will the Australia Card, as proposed by the Government, do that? The Government believes that an effective ID card system would raise an extra $800m in revenue, but it has opted for a system which will raise only $500m. Why the shortfall? That is because the Government will not include a photograph on the card. When the Treasurer said that the Australia Card would combat tax evasion, he actually meant that he was proposing a half-hearted approach which would, in fact, raise only five-eighths of the revenue which could be picked up by an Australia Card. No explanation has been given for the deletion of the photograph at a cost of between $300m and $350m of taxpayers funds. Maybe there is some good reason for deleting the photograph and failing to collect $350m of tax evasion. If there is a good reason, perhaps the Government will let members of the Opposition and the Australian public know. If the Government pretends to be so strong on tax equity and fairness and on stamping out the tax rorts--
Government members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Government members say: `Hear, hear!' If the Government pretends to be strong on these matters, why is it giving away $350m? There is a sudden, deathly silence from Government members. Why on earth will the Government not provide us with the justification for the decision it made to delete the photograph? There has been no substantiation of the original $800m revenue figure and, in addition, there has been no substantiation of the $540m revenue figure quoted in the annexure to the Treasurer's statement. Will that money actually be raised? No evidence has been provided to justify those claims. Presumably the justification for the Government's claimed revenue gains is based on catching those who have second jobs, are working under false names, are not lodging income tax returns and so on. No evidence has been provided to indicate that this should be the highest priority. For example, conventional wisdom is that the cash economy is the great area of evasion. If that is true, how much will be caught by this proposal? Clearly it will not catch those who merely understate their income by not declaring some of their cash income. They will not be picked up by this proposal, which of course raises the question as to whether the proposal is, properly targeted. The Government has not enlightened us in respect of those issues.

SPEECH.PARA: In the statement made by the Treasurer on 19 September it was suggested that in seven years time, that is, in 1992-93, the revenue gain following the introduction of the card would be $540m. Only one month later the Minister for Health said in a speech in Adelaide that the revenue gain was going to be of the order of $500m. If this rate of revision of the revenue estimate is to continue-if we drop $40m a month in the revenue estimates-in a year's time the revenue estimates will be nil. I just wonder what thought has been given within the Government to this proposal.

The Government estimates we have been given-we have been given a whole three and a half lines in an annexure to the Treasurer's statement-supposedly established that the cost of the card would be $127m and the annual administration cost would be $87m for the first seven years and $100m thereafter. The Government's proposal is that it will spend $729m over seven years to get an annual maximum additional revenue saving of $500m in seven year's time. There is real doubt about the cost effectiveness of the card and the Government's lack of detailed supporting evidence for its proposal has done nothing to allay the fears that the card may, in fact, not be cost effective. Already Health Minister Blewett has acknowledged that the integrity of the card is subject to and reliant on the assistance of the States in providing information from their births, deaths and marriages register. He has indicated that the month old cost estimates-that is, those given by the Treasurer to establish the card system-are on the low side. He has had a go at the revenue estimates as they may be a bit high. On the cost side he said: `There are actually going to be some extra costs over and above those that we have outlined'. He now plans to `bribe' the States to get hold of the required information from the births, deaths and marriages register. In light of Queensland's and Victoria's opposition to the ID card, I imagine that the Minister envisages offering a substantial bribe, especially after the Victorian ALP's decision to do everything it can to sabotage the Federal ALP's ID card proposal.

The Government has been forced to join with us in agreeing to our suggestion that a joint select committee be set up to look at the ID card proposal. We welcome the proposal. We look forward to participating on the committee. We are certainly keen to investigate ways of overcoming tax evasion and social security fraud. We will consider the ID card proposal when the committee report is tabled in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) for indicating his commitment this afternoon to the question of illegal immigration being considered as part of the terms of reference of the committee that will be set up to inquire into and report on the Australia Card. The Minister raised a significant matter in that regard in a statement he made in this place when last we sat. The significance of the ID card ran through that speech and in the policy that the Minister laid down. Although illegal immigration is not a specific part of the terms of reference for the proposed committee, the Minister has indicated in discussions that it should be considered by the committee. In my view it is as signficant as the other matters that are specifically mentioned by the Minister. I hope that the committee will give proper attention to that question and to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure that was presented to the House today.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Judiciary Amendment Bill is apparently an innocuous proposal. On listening to what the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) had to say in his second reading speech one would think that it was no more than a housekeeping measure. It was a very bland second reading speech on its face, if one did not listen carefully to the implications in it. One would therefore think that there was no sound reason for saying anything other than expressing agreement on the Bill. Yet if one looks at it more carefully, some important questions arise.

SPEECH.PARA: By this Bill, the Government seeks to exclude the supervisory powers of the courts in criminal trials for offences against the Commonwealth law to certify that legal aid should be granted to an accused person who is on trial. The provision to be repealed in section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act. Under that provision when a person committed for trial for an offence against a Commonwealth law applies to a justice of the High Court or to a judge of the Supreme Court for counsel for his defence, and it is found to the court's satisfaction that the applicant is without adequate means to provide defence for himself and that it is desirable in the interests of justice that such an appointment be made, the court shall certify that to the Attorney-General who may, if he thinks fit, thereupon cause arrangements to be made for the defence of the accused person.

Why is this provision to be removed? The Attorney-General has given a number of reasons. Briefly stated reasons appear in the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. I quote one sentence from the explanatory memorandum circulated with this Bill which states:
The provision predates the present comprehensive nationwide system of legal aid delivery, which is the appropriate source of legal aid in all cases.

Is it the appropriate source in all cases? Are there to be no other sources of legal aid? Is everything to be transferred beyond the powers of the courts? Do the courts not have a role? Apparently not. The purpose of the provision to be repealed is obvious and it was stated by Mr Justice Spender in the case of Maher v. the Attorney-General in May of 1985 as being:
. . . to ensure that injustice is not caused by the absence of proper provision for the defence of a person charged with serious offences against laws of the Commonwealth.

The Attorney-General, in his second reading speech, referred to the costs to the Commonwealth of applications granted under this provision. One does not have to say that the courts are always right; clearly they are not always right. One would think it possible to attribute fallibility to our legal aid systems and to the personnel who administer legal aid. The very fact that applications are being made to the court and are being granted does suggest that there is a hole in the provision of legal aid when persons are charged with offences against Commonwealth laws.

The essentials of an efficient and equitable legal aid system-I should think that we are all interested in having such a system-are these: In a very real sense, there must be equality of access to the courts and to legal representation. This requires a general equality in the quality, experience and expertise of legal representation. The plain fact is that broad expertise, high quality and wide experience are to be found in the private legal professions-experience, expertise and quality which could not be duplicated in legal aid agencies without unacceptable and unnecessary expenditure. The reason for this is very simple.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are unlimited fees for barristers.

—I hear an interjection that implies that this is an attempt to assist the legal profession. I say to the honourable member that it is an attempt to examine the issues and to look at how legal aid should be provided, not simply to mouth cliches put in one's mouth by the Department. The private legal professions attract the best for the very good reason that that is where one can prosper. That is where the good and the big cases are to be found. That is where the most interesting work is to be found.
