SPEECH.PARA: I do not for a moment decry the important work done by the various legal aid agencies or the personnel of those agencies. Let us remember, as every honourable member knows, what happens when senior and well-known people in this country, or, indeed, in this Parliament, get into trouble with the law. They go to the best in the business. Do they go for legal aid? Essentially, they go for quality, and quality in the administration of justice on both sides of the bar table is essential.

I raise these points because the proposed removal of this provision from the Act is directly concerned with the provision of legal aid. I ask: What is the present state of the Government's legal aid proposals? What is the state of development of those proposals? We know that the previous Attorney-General was interested in high matters of constitutional amendment. Those are glamorous and interesting matters, but they do not get down to what really matters for most people who have anything to do with the law, who are in need of help and who do not have a great deal of money. I refer to the efficient and fair provision of legal aid.

When the present Attorney-General took over, he decided in June of this year that the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council, which was established by the previous Government, should be allowed to go out of existence, and so it did. It is known that shortly before the Council went out of existence its members put some terms to the Commonwealth Attorney-General as to the form a national legal aid body should take which would be able to give independent advice to him on legal aid matters. Indeed, the Attorney- General, in a news release of 13 June 1985, said this of the Council:
The Council has done useful work and I congratulate it on what it has been able to achieve.
However the Council has neither the resources nor the statutory backing to carry out the task of monitoring and co-ordinating legal aid across Australia which clearly needs to be done.

The Attorney-General was expressing a very positive view which, quite clearly, required quick action so that the problem which he addressed could be overcome. What has been the response? So far as one can determine, nothing. We have no Commonwealth legal aid council. We have no substitute for that council. We have no mechanism for an independent advisory role for the professions. In short, we have no national legal aid advisory council. We have a Government reaction which is equal parts of inactivity, indecision and indolence.

As I have said, it is unfortunate that the previous Attorney-General was apparently too interested in other matters to concentrate his attention on how the system of justice works for the ordinary person who needs help. The present Attorney-General has now allowed some five months or so to go by since he made his decision. I am sure that we would all like to know what the present state of his thinking is, when we can expect some action and what it will be. There is good reason, therefore, to approach this apparently innocuous proposal with caution as one suspects that it is inspired by the Department. The consequence is that if it is passed there will be no supervisory role for the courts.

This caution is reinforced by the recent report of the Legal Aid Task Force of August this year. When I say recent, it is now not so recent. The thrust of that report is away from the private legal profession and towards a concentration on in-house services. So far as I am aware, the Attorney-General still has to make a decision as to what is to happen, which of the recommendations are to be accepted and which are to be rejected. We would like to know as soon as possible what is to happen, whether the report is to be accepted and the implications of acceptance of the report for the ordinary person who needs legal aid. The legal aid system is not about rich people who can afford to go to the courts. It is not about those who are backed by unions or other powerful organisations. It is about those who cannot afford to go to the courts and, because they cannot afford to, are effectively excluded from justice.

So we have the present position. After nearly three years we have a Government which appears to lack a clear view as to how legal aid should be provided and as to the role of the private profession in providing legal aid, although the suspicion must be that the departmental plan is to exclude the private profession as much as possible, to the detriment of those granted legal aid. I very much hope that the Attorney-General will make sure that the private profession's role in the provision of legal aid services and its advice as to how legal aid services should be maintained is kept because it would be very bad for the people of this country if everything-lock, stock and barrel-were to be pushed away from the involvement of the private practitioners, just as it would be very sad if the proposal now before the House, to which I have an amendment which has been circulated in my name and which I will move in the Committee stage, were to be passed.

Let me turn to the background of this Bill and the reasons for it which have been given by the Attorney-General. The first reason he gives is that the courts are incompetent. Those are not his words, but that is clearly what he is saying, because, among other things, he says that section 69 (3) is `out of step with modern developments in the provision of legal aid' and is `ripe for exploitation'-and this from a Government that is without any apparent policy towards the provision of legal aid. When one speaks of `ripe for exploitation', one has to ask: Who is being exploited? The answer must be that the courts are being exploited because it is to the courts that the application has to be made. So when one refers to exploitation one is saying that the courts are not competent to do this and it would be much better if it were to be handed over to others wiser in the ways of trials.

Let us look at the next thing the Attorney-General said. I do not intend to quote the whole of his remarks, but I will put the substance of his argument. He said that applications under section 69 (3) circumvent the legal aid system-circumvent it! One would think that he was talking about a tax avoidance scheme. He also said that the question of entitlement to legal aid is not suited to be determined by the courts. Really, it is not suited to be determined by the courts. This is a classic departmental view. Those who are not at the heart of things know better, grounded in ignorance of how the courts work, of how cases are fought. Of all the people to determine whether the interests of justice require that legal aid be given, judges are in the best position. They are there because, appointed by governments of different political persuasion, they are thought to be the most competent people around. They invariably have a great deal of experience of courtroom work as advocates. Frequently they have 30, 40 or more years experience in the business of law and of the courts. The issues are before them and, if they wish, they can interrogate very closely those who apply and say that they are without means.

I have said before that I do not suggest that courts do not make mistakes, but we should not think that others outside the courts are in a better position to make decisions of this kind. It is absolute nonsense to think that the judges are not the best qualified. I do not for a moment say that we should hand over the legal aid system to them and I do not say that we should hand over the day to day burden of administering the legal aid system to the courts, but I do say that the interests of justice require that there be in cases under Commonwealth laws, because that is what we are concerned with, a supervisory role for the courts.

Let me go to another reason put by the Attorney-General. He said that we now have `a very comprehensive and integrated system of legal aid', to which has been allocated, I might add, some $70m in 1985-86 and which provides for `legal aid in relation to indictable Commonwealth criminal offences with slight variations amongst jurisdictions as to means and merits tests'. The Attorney-General is talking about a comprehensive system, and I read with great interest the report of the Legal Aid Task Force of August 1985. Let me quote from that report, and in doing so let me express the immediate caution that it is speaking of the system as a whole and is not directing its attention to applications under section 69 (3), nor is it concerned exclusively with cases falling within Commonwealth criminal provisions. It says this in paragraph 3.20:

It is not reasonable or practicable to expect that legal aid commissions, who so jealously guard their independence, would agree either between themselves or with the Commonwealth on such fundamental issues as those listed in paragraph 3.18.

Those issues were the role of legal aid bodies, financial eligibility criteria, matters in which legal aid should be granted, contributions policy and methods of delivery. Here we have the Legal Aid Task Force saying that we cannot expect agreement on those fundamental matters. Where, tell me, is the comprehensive and integrated system of legal aid of which the Attorney-General boasts? Let me continue with the quote from paragraph 3.20. It says:
The experience to date tells the story, as evidenced by the disparate results that are achieved as a consequence of the variation in operation from one legal aid body to the next.
Where again is that comprehensive and integrated system of legal aid? In paragraph 4.1 the report says:

In short, depending on where persons live in Australia, their chances of obtaining legal aid, the nature of the service to be provided, or the contribution that they will be required to pay for that service, will differ.

As I have made clear, I do not suggest that that report is directed to matters falling exclusively within the province of offences against Commonwealth laws, but it seems to say very clearly that the Attorney-General is quite mistaken when he speaks in support of his argument for the abolition of section 69 (3) of a comprehensive and integrated system.

As I have said, the courts are overall the best qualified. It would be a great pity if their supervisory role was to be gotten rid of in this offhand manner. I think the Bill could be improved and during the Committee stage I shall propose an amendment to that effect which has already been circulated in my name. While the courts are not always right, I stress that their experience places them in a position better than that of anyone else to determine the two critical issues-the needs of justice and financial need. This is too important a matter to turn over entirely to a process administered entirely outside the courts. Therefore, I ask the Attorney-General, when he replies, to consider ceding to the amendment which I have proposed as an improvement, perhaps, or a half-way house between total abolition on the one hand and the existing clause on the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that on a matter of this nature the Opposition would have done some research on and made an intellectual examination of the background and history of section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act 1903. Opposition members should have tried to understand where it came from, why it exists and why it is no longer necessary. We have not had that content from them at all and I am rather disappointed with the nature of the debate on the Judiciary Amendment Bill 1985 at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Under section 69 (3) a person charged with an offence against the laws of the Commonwealth may apply to a judge of the High Court or of a Supreme Court of a State for the appointment of counsel for his or her defence. If a judge certifies to the Attorney-General that the person is without adequate means to provide for his or her own defence, and that it is desirable in the interests of justice that an appointment of counsel be made, the Attorney-General may make arrangements for the defence. These arrangements would normally be the provision of financial assistance to enable the person to retain solicitor and counsel.

The provision pre-dates the present comprehensive nationwide system of legal aid delivery, which is the appropriate source of legal aid in all cases. The procedure under section 69 (3), whereunder an applicant for legal aid can involve the courts in deciding the appropriateness or otherwise of a grant of legal aid, is cumbersome, expensive and a duplication of functions now better performed by properly constituted legal aid bodies in all States and Territories. Accordingly repeal of section 69 (3) would rationalise the delivery of legal aid in Federal criminal matters.

This section has a long and very interesting history. Its genesis can be found in what was once called the poor prisoners defence Act. I am indebted to a very detailed research undertaken by His Honour Mr Justice Sholl of the Victorian Supreme Court which is cited in Borradale v. Davenport, 1958, at page 470 of Victorian reports. Before the judicature Acts the better opinion was that because of the operation of statutes giving rights to costs the common law courts had, at any rate in civil actions, no residual common law jurisdiction to admit persons as pauper litigants. They were restricted to cases in which such admission was authorised by, or under, statute. On the other hand, in criminal and quasi-criminal matters the common law courts appeared to have authorised a discretionary common law jurisdiction to admit litigants as paupers in certain cases.

Courts of equity created their own practice, although in general they proceeded in relation to such litigants by the analogy of the common law practice. They did not restrict themselves thereto; in some cases they departed from it. The reasons for the existence of the situation just described are historical. According to Serjeant Hullock, whose work was first published in 1792, a plaintiff's right to costs in common law actions was established by a series of statutes of which the first and most important was in 1278 in the reign of Edward I. Costs of appeals, including criminal appeals, to general or quarter sessions were dealt with by various statutes, mainly dating from the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Costs of proceedings by way of certiorari to remove into the King's Bench proceedings before justices or sessions were dealt with in a number of cases by statutes which provided for their being secured by recognisances to prosecute the proceedings. In that case I refer to Hullock, volume II page 561. It may do Opposition members some good to do some research and read Serjeant Hullock's excellent book.

The equity jurisdiction as to costs is said by Mr Beames, whose work was first published in 1822, to have originated in 1393. It is a very old section, is it not? The admission of persons as litigants in forma pauperis appears to have begun at common law at least as early as 1475-76. However, the practice was recognised and regulated in 1494 and that is referred to in Beames and also Daniell's Chancery Practice Sixth Edition 1882, volume I, at pages 85 and 165. The statutes passed in subsequent centuries will be referred to in these authorities.

By the Act of Henry VII, a pauper plaintiff had counsel and attorney assigned to him to act without reward. I can guarantee that the modern Bar will not have a bar of that. Under the Act he was not to pay costs if he lost but was to suffer such other punishment as the court thought reasonable. Under this statute the curious practice arose of giving such a plaintiff, by order, the option of paying costs or of being whipped. I am sure there are honourable members opposite who would support such a proposal today if a person did not pay his bills. It appears from Drennan v. Andrew, 1866 1 Chancery law reports at page 301 that in Elizabeth's day a female plaintiff was so whipped. However, by Lord Holt's time the practice had fallen into disuse, for that learned chief justice refused a motion to have a pauper whipped for the non-payment of costs. He observed that `there was no officer for the purpose, and he had never known it done'.

At common law it was ultimately held that there was no power to admit a defendant in a civil case in forma pauperis, though apparently there were some differences of opinion on this point. That case is reported in Hullock, volume 1 at page 228 and 229 where early authorities are clearly cited and discussed. The learned author observed:

A defendant in a civil action cannot be admitted to defend in forma pauperus; because no person can be admitted either to sue or defend as a pauper, but under some Act of Parliament, and the statutes . . . contain no provisions on behalf of defendants, but merely enable plaintiffs to sue in that form. And if the courts had a discretionary power, without the direction of a statute, to admit persons in civil suits to proceed in forma pauperis, they would in effect possess a power of dispensing, in many instances, with the operation of the statutes relative to costs.
The question we are looking at now was discussed in 1828. It sometimes takes the Opposition a long while to catch up.

Though Equity claimed to proceed in the matter of pauper litigants by analogy, it in fact varied its practice widely from that of the common law courts. Indeed, in the time of Lord Bacon defendants were admitted in a proper case as paupers, but plaintiffs in most cases were referred to the Court of Requests. Thereafter, both plaintiffs and defendants were so admitted. Even at common law, however, the courts considered that they had a discretionary jurisdiction to admit a person as a pauper party, either as defendant or as prosecutor, in proceedings on the Crown side, where no right of the opposite party to costs was thereby defeated.

Some of the older precedents cited in Wright's case were cases in which defendants had been admitted in forma pauperis to reverse outlaw- ries. One was a case in which the defendant was admitted in forma pauperis to prosecute a writ of error upon an indictment. Several cases of defendants admitted to defend indictments as paupers are referred to in the authorities I have cited. As Mr Justice Maule observed in Brunt v. Wardle, this could have been done only by virtue of the common law authority of the courts. On the other hand, where a defendant removed an indictment, without good cause, into the King's Bench, he was refused leave to defend as a pauper.

As the history of this particular section shows, it came from this very ancient jurisdiction. It was incorporated into our country with the establishment of the early colonies. With the eventual federation of Australia there followed a number of Acts known as Judicature Acts. Those early sections of English law, inherited through the colonial system, were in effect brought into Australia through the Judicature Acts and that is where section 69 (3) comes from.

For Opposition members today to talk about the importance of this section in the provision of legal aid is for them to show that they have not bothered to have a look at it. They have ignored the first premise of research; to ask what the section is for, where it comes from and what it does. It does not do anything, except enable people like Mr Maher to set up companies and stack away their wealth in corporate structures, so that they do not have a penny in their name. They use this anachronism-that is all it is-to go to court and get the taxpayers-

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I interrupt my learned friend to draw the attention of the Chair to the fact that this matter is the subject of an appeal to the Federal Court of Australia. In those circumstances my honourable friend should not be referring to the matter of that particular case; it is sub judice.
—The honourable member will not refer to the case.
—Yes, Madam Deputy Speaker. I am not referring to the facts of the case, but to the facts of legal aid, which are different.
—The honourable member will avoid the case.

—It is interesting to see members of the legal profession on the other side take the course of action they have, because it is not supported by judges. That is one of the weird things about this. In an unreported decision of R. v. Harris on 4 July this year Mr Justice Ormiston said exactly what I have said; that it is an historical anachronism. That is exactly what it is, as I think I have detailed adequately today. No one will lose legal aid on this matter. The suggestion that it has any relevance to the legal aid system in this country ignores its history. It is another example of the Opposition's tawdry approach in this House of coming along on anything the Government does and trying to find some reason to stand up and talk and find an amendment. It is irrelevant. The Bill is a valuable Bill which will remove from our statutes an Act which goes back to 1827 and which no longer applies in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry about the concluding remarks of the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) because I think, with respect, he did not give credit to the very fundamental issues which are involved in a proper consideration of the Judiciary Amendment Bill. I say from the outset that I count it an honour as one of Her Majesty's younger counsel, to follow the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), the current shadow Attorney-General and the next Attorney-General of the Commonwealth of Australia, in leading for the Opposition in this debate. Unlike both the honourable member for North Sydney and the honourable member for McEwen who preceded me, I want to trace the history of the development of this area of the law since 1962 and I appeal to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) who is also the Deputy Prime Minister of this country to accept and recognise the wisdom, justice and humanity which is contained in the proposed amendment to be moved by the honourable member for North Sydney, and to do that notwithstanding Caucus and Cabinet decisions. I ask the Attorney-General, as the senior law officer of the Commonwealth, to exercise his discretion and to accept this amendment when we consider this Bill in Committee. As the honourable member for North Sydney has said, the Opposition will vote against this Bill because we believe the Government is taking away something which is basic and fundamental.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Deputy Speaker, I know when I speak of these matters that you, because of your electoral work will recognise the truth of what I am saying. The tragedy in Australia today is that the courts are only accessible to very poor Australians and to very rich Australians. The ordinary Australians today cannot get into the courts of this land in civil matters and cannot afford the costs of defence in criminal matters. I regret to say on the basis of my professional record-I say it non-politically-that notwithstanding the best endeavours of Attorneys-General, both Liberal and Labor over the last 20 years, in 1962 there was more justice in relation to legal aid and there was more justice in relation to assisting persons before the courts than there is in 1985. I am going to shock a few people by some of the comments that I am going to make, including some of my colleagues from the Australian Labor Party in Victoria. Let me get this one off my chest here and now. I think it is scandalous that Norm Gallagher, whatever he did or did not do had to endure a trial which extended for some 56 days without being granted legal aid.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out that there is also an appeal in that case.
—Indeed, but not on the question of legal aid.
—I suggest that the honourable member avoids-
—I make the point, with respect--
—Double standards.

—I am sorry that there is levity in the ranks of the Hawke socialist Government. I note with some pleasure that the Deputy Prime Minister does not join in the raucous behaviour that is coming from the Government back benches. I believe it is wrong that a person in this country stands trial-a trial which extends for 56 days-and is denied legal aid. I put that on the record. If one wants proof of what I am saying, one can look at a copy of the Melbourne Age of just a few weeks ago because quite fortuitously I met the gentleman concerned at the Bendigo Hotel, which is run by a Mr Peter Jones, and I was staggered to find that at that stage, with his trial drawing to a close, Norm Gallagher had not received one cent of legal aid.

SPEECH.PARA: I say nothing about the merits of the conviction, the question of the appeal or any issue. However, what I do say is that it would not have happened in 1962. Why not? Next to the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia I put it to this House that the Judiciary Act 1903 is the most important statute on the books of the Commonwealth. It is the statute which sets up the entire structure for the exercise of the judicial power of the Commonwealth. As the honourable member for North Sydney said, and he is far more experienced in these matters, the question of a fair trial and the question of the right to legal representation is fundamental to the exercise of the basic human rights of each and every Australian, whether born in this country or having come to this country from another place.

Madam Deputy Speaker, let me take your memory back and the memories of other honourable members, and particularly the memory of the Attorney-General, because he will know what I am saying is true, to what was the situation in 1962. There was no Commonwealth legal aid scheme in 1962. There were State legal aid schemes. I was admitted to the Bar of the Supreme Court of Tasmania on 19 February 1962, and I will tell the House what the rules were there about legal aid. There was a roster. If one was allocated a trial, whether it was for two days, two weeks or two months, one took that trial at one-third of the normal counsel's fees; the two-thirds was a contribution which one made as a member of the profession to the benefit of the community. One received one-third of normal counsel's fees, and one paid tax on that. A few years later it became 50 per cent of counsel's fees. But when the Australian legal aid scheme came on to the arena, in the term of the Whitlam Government, I was staggered-and I think a lot of Australians were staggered-at what, with the very best intentions in the world, occurred.

Let me give a classic example. The first thing said was that the Australian legal aid scale for remuneration would be that applying in Canberra. Let me say without any shame, because I have no wealth at all, that the counsel's fees payable in Canberra were a mile above the fees that were payable in Hobart, and a mile above the fees that were paid in Townsville, or in Perth, or in Bathurst. What happened was that instead of making a personal financial sacrifice-which I and many other young barristers of my day did, because we believed it was right, as did the present Attorney-General-we found that we were embarrassed to be told that we would be paid at a higher rate than we would have been paid if we had been entitled to full counsel's fees. I just want to make the point that when a few of us raised this matter in the Tasmanian Bar Association, of which I had the honour to be Vice-President in 1974, we were laughed at. I know that my friend the honour- able member for Leichardt (Mr Gayler) would know exactly what I am saying. We were told, `Don't be stupid'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would he really?

—Yes, I think he does on this matter. We were told, `Don't be stupid, that is the counsel's fees.' I might tell the House that I did a trial for Aboriginal Legal Aid in 1975, in the Supreme Court of Tasmania, that went for some 11 days. It ended in an acquittal, the most gratifying acquittal of my Bar career, involving over 300 criminal trials, including 13 murder trials. Why was it gratifying to me? It was because it involved an Aboriginal prisoner in this country who had been assaulted and persecuted by warders who then turned around and charged him with assaulting them. Had he been convicted, he would have received a very long custodial sentence. What I found there was that when I rendered my reduced counsel's fee memorandum-because in our State at that stage we had not properly developed a separate Bar-I was told that it was embarrassing because I had not charged sufficient to reach the minimum to which I was entitled under Aboriginal Legal aid.

SPEECH.PARA: With the best will in the world, I have to suggest that the Attorney-General of the day in 1974 made a fundamental error when he said on the occasion of the official opening of an Australian Legal Aid office: `You are not to regard yourselves as lawyers but more as social scientists'. I have to say that, with the best intentions in the world, I think that is where the rot set in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Social engineering.

—Social engineering-my honourable and learned colleague makes the point. What was wrong with a system in which the Chief Magistrate, Mr R. F. Turner, said at lock-up court on a Monday morning, with about 70 defendants coming up: `Mr Hodgman, would you mind talking to this defendant and advising him as to how he should plead'? And we did that. There was no question of rendering a fee. I have heard Mr Justice Gibson, Sir Marcus Gibson, who is still alive-the Attorney-General would know of his judgments; he is one of the greatest judges ever of the Supreme Court of Tasmania-say, effectively: `Mr So-and-so, this man clearly needs legal assistance. Will you take the matter on?' I saw it happen. The dock brief of the Old Bailey was the dock brief of Darlinghurst and the dock brief of Hobart Town. I have seen counsel 25 years ago take on a dock brief and see it right through, the question of costs and fees never having entered their minds. That was the spirit of the tradition of the father of the honourable member for North Sydney, of my father, and of others who believed that the law was a profession and not a licence to make money.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we have today? One cannot throw a brief at a young barrister today. I can remember-I should not digress, Madam Deputy Speaker, but this is worth recalling-arriving at the robing room of the Supreme Court of Tasmania on a cold Monday morning in the middle of a Tasmanian winter and meeting Mr Christopher Wright. He had been literally thrown a brief by his father, now Sir Reginald Wright, and I had also been given a brief by my father. I said `Are you for the plaintiff?' and he said `Yes'. I said: `Thank heaven for that; I can at least have a look at my brief while you are opening for the plaintiff'. That sort of thing does not happen very often, but the plain fact is that this was part of the tradition. Today counsel wants 28 days notice. I do not know whether the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) will speak, but he is one of the few, as is my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who could pick up a brief on a couple of minutes notice and argue it very well.

I come back to the fundamental point. Section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act, as the honourable member for North Sydney pointed out, gave an additional discretion to the judiciary in appropriate cases in order to ensure that the interests of justice were served and that a person would have legal aid in that arrangements would be made for the defence of that accused person. Why does the Attorney-General, with all his broad comments about the comprehensive nature of Australian legal aid-the system is still operating in the States-have so little confidence in the judiciary that he takes away this provision which has remained almost unaltered as part of the law of the Commonwealth of Australia for the last 82 years? Why does he do it?

I say to my honourable and learned friends opposite that members of the judiciary might say that they do not think it is relevant. A learned judge might describe it as an historical anachronism, but let me put it to honourable members that if this saves a miscarriage of justice in just one trial in Australia in one year, I believe this Parliament should uphold that right. I put it to honourable members that it is for the trial judge to decide. Let us take a case-I have seen this and I am sure that the Attorney-General has seen it too-where somebody comes in bold as brass and says: `Your Honour, I intend to defend myself'. So far so good. The case starts; it then becomes painfully obvious to everybody that the man in the dock who thinks he is going to defend himself is, frankly, an idiot who does not understand the law and has no idea of cross-examination. Has the Attorney-General not seen an accused, in person, trying to cross-examine when he cannot even form a question? He puts a statement of fact. If the Attorney has not read the High Court decision in Dawson's case he should look at that because, as the honourable member for North Sydney has pointed out as a fundamental plank of the Opposition's approach in this matter, the Government is displaying in this amendment a vote of no confidence in the judiciary of Australia. The Government is saying: `We will not even let the judiciary exercise the powers given under section 69 (3)'.

The Attorney and Deputy Prime Minister, on any fair basis, is a reasonable man and recognised as such on both sides of this House and in the other place. I appeal to him to look carefully at the amendment drawn by the honourable member for North Sydney. The Attorney will effect the purpose he seeks-I am sad that he will do so-that of taking out section 69 (3) which, I draw to his attention, was last amended just 12 months after Robert Gordon Menzies became Prime Minister of this country. It has not been amended by any government since 1950. The Whitlam Government did not see fit to meddle with it and I am surprised, with respect, and disappointed that the Hawke socialist Government has seen fit to meddle with it.

The Government can have its cake and eat it because if it gets the Bill into the Committee stage-as it tragically in my view will-it can achieve its fundamental purpose but it can accept the amendment on a totally non-partisan and non-political basis because it has nothing to do with politics, as the honourable member for North Sydney has pointed out. He makes a plea for a proviso-a proviso which will retain a fundamental right of every Australian man and woman who comes before the courts of this land in respect of matters falling within the judicial powers of the Commonwealth of Australia. I ask whether the honourable members opposite, with all their altruism and idealism, are prepared to say that they do not have confidence in the judges of this country to exercise this power fairly and properly. I do not believe that they will be heard to say that.

In conclusion, with all due respect to the honourable member for McEwen, I would not dare to contradict let alone criticise the honourable member for North Sydney even if I thought I was right and he was wrong, because our legal system is based on seniority and I happen to have a healthy respect for those whose experience, standing and capacity are superior to my own. I ask honourable members opposite, many of whom I have an enormous regard for despite our political differences, to give the Attorney-General the strength and support to accept the amendment which the Opposition proposes. Better still, join with the Opposition in defeating this Bill at the second reading stage on the voices without the necessity of taking the matter to a division, and uphold the rights of Australian judges to determine in appropriate cases that legal aid will be provided to Australian men and women when the justice of the case does not just require it but emphatically demands it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We must say of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) that he is obviously a man of charity, a man of generosity and a man of compassion. He has told the chamber tonight that for most of the time that he has practised in the law he has done so either for a third of the fee or for nothing at all. Is it any wonder that he has no funds? It is a shame that we should have such a light-hearted approach to the Judiciary Amendment Bill. Notwithstanding that the honourable member for Denison was well wide of the mark as far as section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act is concerned, he was much closer to it than the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), who knew nothing about it. We heard a plea from the honourable member for Denison, but if this legal aid provision is such a hallmark in our society, if it is required by the citizens of this country, why did he not tell the House and the people of Australia that since 1970 it has been used on only eight occasions? He did not mention that. It is interesting also to note that of those eight occasions more than half have occurred this year. The people involved in bottom of the harbour schemes and conspiracies to import drugs into Australia are the people applying now under this shield under this anachronistic piece of legislation brought down in 1903.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill, introduced to repeal sub-section (3) of section 69 of the Judiciary Act, is most fitting, notwithstanding that its introduction has been, unfortunately, delayed too long. The sub-section is one of the original provisions of the Act and it has until now remained substantially unaltered. At the time of its introduction, legal aid in criminal proceedings was most uncommon. If one cares to look at the Hansard record of when this Bill was introduced one can see that it was introduced solely as a method of legally aiding those who did not have the means-the funds-to defend themselves. There can be no doubt about that. The inclusion of sub-section (3) of section 69 of the Judiciary Act was solely for that purpose.

What has changed that would make the purport of that sub-section any different now from what it was 82 years ago? Of course, many things have changed. Since the early 1970s we have had a legal aid system in Australia that more than adequately looks after those people who are in need of legal assistance. Now that the honourable member for North Sydney has returned to the chamber, I ask him whether he told the House that since 1970 there have been a mere eight applications under this provision of the Judiciary Act. I will explain and outline to honourable members later what the judiciary in 1985, not 1903, thinks of this sub-section. With all due respect to the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), I am talking of 1985 and not 1678. In 1985 the judiciary looks upon it as a superfluous piece of legislation that has been used quite underhandedly.

Under the existing provisions of the Act a person charged with an offence against the laws of the Commonwealth may apply to a judge of the High Court of Australia or of a Supreme Court of a State for the appointment of counsel for his or her defence. If the judge certifies to the Attorney-General that the person is without adequate means to provide for his or her own defence and that it is desirable in the interests of justice that an appointment of counsel be made, the Attorney-General may make arrangements for the defence. Of course, in more recent times the statement `may make arrangements' has been shown to be more mandatory than one might expect, having regard to the language of the Act. As has been seen in recent trials, those arrangements would clearly mean the provision of financial assistance to enable the person to retain a solicitor and counsel.

It is important to note that the provision to be repealed predates the present comprehensive, nation-wide system of legal aid which is, and should be, available to those without adequate means to provide for their own defence. In fact, the introduction by the Whitlam Administration during the 1970s of legislation providing for the Australian Legal Aid Office and the subsequent integration of that system of legal aid with State and Territory commissions has made the provisions of section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act 1903 outmoded.

Apart from the fact that adequate legal aid is now available in our society, a factor that also should be taken into consideration as to whether section 69 (3) now plays any realistic or valid role in proceedings in our legal system is that of judicial responsibility. In that regard, I refer to a recent decision in the matter of the Queen v. Maher. In an application made under this legislation the presiding judge, Mr Justice Carter, stated, in his judgment

I wish to make it crystal clear that the course I propose has been decided upon, not because I have been asked specifically to order in terms of section 69 but is taken because I believe it is a matter of judicial responsibility and is taken irrespective of the fact that an application has been made to me under section 69 of the Judiciary Act.
In one word, he said that the section is superfluous. He continued:
The responsibility remains with the court to the extent which I have indicated whether or not an application is made under that section.

Once again, that is judicial responsibility. In accordance with the practice of presiding judges, there is little doubt that the court has the inherent power to ensure that the interests of justice are met, including in the circumstances of an accused not having adequate means to provide for himself. Of course, there are other quite pertinent and valid reasons which illustrate that through the effluxion of time this provision has now become outmoded. Not least of these is the difficulty faced by a presiding judge in dealing with an application brought under this particular section of the of the Act. Once again I refer to the dictum of Mr Justice Carter in the case I mentioned previously. He stated:

Last Friday an application was made to me that I certify in terms of section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act. I referred then to the fact that the application was made substantially after the time at which the section envisaged the matters contained in the section would arise for consideration.
He continued:

I also indicated my concern on that occasion that any certification by me in terms of the section which touches the question of the accused Maher's resources might be seen to involve a finding of fact which has wider implications . . .
I am certain that the honourable member for North Sydney as a practising QC would know what Mr Justice Carter was talking about. The judge continued:
. . . and at the same time I expressed my concern that I was not satisfied nor could I be on the material before me that I knew the whole truth of the matter.

It is obvious that the judge was referring to difficulties which were incumbent on his having to consider an application under the relevant section after the trial had commenced. Mr Justice Carter was also critical that the role which a judge had to carry out was essentially a matter for the executive arm of government to be decided by executive process. He indicated that matters that had been pursued before him ought to have been pursued elsewhere in the first place. He went on to say that he had been asked to exercise powers given to the court in this area in a way in which it was never intended that those powers should be used. (Quorum formed) I congratulate the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) for one of his more positive contributions in this House in calling that quorum. I am surprised that he is able to count that far.

I agree with the criticism of the Act. It has been very long and very loud by the judiciary in more recent times. I also agree with the comments made by the learned trial judge. It is interesting to note that other members of the judiciary have also been critical of this legislation. I do not have to go into that, but earlier this evening the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) mentioned the comments of Mr Justice Ormiston in a Victorian case. Of course if, as is suggested by those opposite, the section under discussion is retained, the judiciary will be in the untenable situation of having to conduct what could be in some circumstances prolonged inquiries into such areas as the means of an accused in order to make certain administrative decisions, a role which was quite properly pointed out by Mr Justice Carter to be more properly exercised in the executive processes of government, whether State or Federal.

Having given my full support to the Bill, it goes without saying that I am opposed to the amendment to be moved by the honourable member for North Sydney. If his amendment were to be passed it would retain the anachronistic provision which has been criticised by judges throughout this land. To add to the clause the provision `or refer the matter to such legal authorities as he considers appropriate' does nothing to overcome the difficulties that exist with the present legislation which was introduced initially over 80 years ago.

To pose the simple situation of an accused making application under the relevant section being referred to a legal aid authority by the judge, I simply ask: What would preclude an accused from making subsequent application in the terms of such amended legislation? There is nothing. I might add that the honourable member for North Sydney did not address himself to that. Leaving aside that criticism, one must return to the inherent powers of a justice of which I have previously spoken; that is, to ensure in the interests of justice that an accused without adequate means is provided with adequate representation for his defence. This, together with all the other avenues of legal aid available in this country, makes, in my respectful submission, section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act superfluous. In conclusion I might say that the proposed amendment by the Opposition is nothing short of ridiculous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise in this House to support the amendment to be moved so ably by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and to oppose the position taken by the temporary Government of this country. It is indeed a very sad day for the people of Australia when a representative of a party which professes to look after the poor and the underprivileged seeks the repeal of part of the Act which provides for legal aid for our citizens. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in his explanatory memorandum, pointed out that the purpose of the Judiciary Amendment Bill was to repeal section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act 1903

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair invites the accused to maintain the decorum consistent with their circumstances.

—The sub-section in question permits a person committed for trial against Commonwealth law to apply to a justice of the High Court of Australia or a justice of a supreme court for the appointment of counsel for his defence. In this event, if it is found to the court's satisfaction that the applicant is without adequate means to provide defence for himself and that it is desirable in the interests of justice that such an appointment be made, the judge shall certify this to the Attorney-General, who may, if he thinks fit, thereupon cause arrangements to be made for the defence of the accused person. One can wonder about the sensitivity of the Attorney and the Government in relation to this matter. By the admission of the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), the previous speaker, only eight applications have been made under this sub-section in the last 13 years. If that is the case, why has the Government, in this busy legislative time, brought forward this Bill to try to deprive the citizens of Australia of legal aid rights?
—A waste of time.

—It is a waste of time. It is a shocking negation of the Government's responsibility as a government. The honourable member for Leichhardt outlined the situation which faced a certain person, Mr Maher, in recent times. While we in this country do not in any way, shape or form seek to protect anyone who might breach the law, we believe that it is the right of every citizen to have a fair trial. We believe that every citizen has the right to put forward his case before the courts of this land so that they are able to determine, in accordance with the laws, whether or not an accused is in fact guilty. As the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) said, justice is not yet dead, but if this Government had its way that would be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The person referred to by the honourable member for Leichhardt sought approval from the trial judge for aid under the sub-section proposed to be repealed by this Bill. Mr Justice Carter certified, in terms of the sub-section, that Mr Maher was without adequate means with which to defend himself and, further, that it was in the best interests of justice that he be defended. The judgment was sent to the Federal Attorney-General who, because he is an honourable man, rather surprisingly responded that he would not give aid to Mr Maher on the basis that he was not satisfied that there was no other source from which he could receive payment for his defence.

Inquiries were then made of the Attorney-General as to the identity of the other sources suggested by him, but he could not give it. Approaches were made to the Federal Court. Detailed argument ensued with the Attorney-General being very well represented by eminent counsel. The Federal Court ordered that the decision of the Attorney-General refusing aid be quashed and that the matter be sent back to him to be dealt with according to law and Mr Maher was awarded costs.

I certainly do not-and I am certain that members on both sides of the House do not-presume to comment on the actual substance of the charges against Mr Maher. That would be entirely inappropriate. But it is a fundamental right of every citizen to have access to our courts. Earlier one honourable member-I think it was the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), one of the most effective members of this chamber-said that the people of this country who have access to the courts are the very poor and the very rich; the middle class in this country, the ordinary average person, has great difficulty because of the cost of litigation.

I mentioned earlier that there have been only eight applications under this sub-section in the last 13 years. Of course it is appropriate for people seeking aid normally to approach the legal aid authorities. The Opposition believes that that is the procedure to be followed in most cases. However, there are instances in which the ordinary legal aid system may not cater for some Australians. In the case of Mr Maher, he had had extreme difficulties in that his assets had been frozen and he did not have access to funds or aid. He was faced with having to conduct his own defence. He was pitted against some of the best legal brains in the country. Regardless of anything a man may or may not have done, it is only right that in this democratic country he should be able to obtain legal advice and be represented before the courts. Those honourable members opposite who call out in a very raucous way and claim that that particular defendant was not entitled to a defence should stand condemned. We on this side of the House will not under any circumstances countenance the approach of those honourable members opposite. I am pleased that the Attorney has not joined them in those noisy cries. He knows, and I understand that he fundamentally believes, that Australians are entitled to legal aid and to be legally represented. It is with a great deal of disappointment that I note his attitude in this case. It seems to be entirely out of character for a man who in the past has shown so much compassion and understanding and such a great degree of reason to succumb to Labor sensitivities, to bring this Bill into this House.

It is important that we support the amendment to be moved by my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney, an excellent person who will be the Attorney-General of this country in a very short time-in fact a much shorter time than honourable members opposite realise. He has thoughtfully gone into the various issues confronting this House at this time. We in the Opposition would welcome any honourable members opposite who wished to walk across to join us to vote with us to ensure that there is fairness and equity in the legal aid system of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members for their contributions. I say at the outset that I found it very interesting to be given such an historical background to the section of the Judiciary Act that we are debating. I recognise that in Australia the provision was enacted in 1903. But I was not aware of some of the factors which have been brought into the debate by my colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). As a matter of interest, I noted that in the famous case of Donogue v. Stevenson, which happens to be the snail in the bottle case, the lady was a pauper. The question is: How did she get her case before the House of Lords? Possibly it came about because of the attitude of the profession in those days, which the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) so eloquently expressed. The profession was able to do the work for nothing. Those days appear to have passed. I say in reply that I am unable to accept the proposed amendment because it states that I will continue my role of endeavouring to find legal aid, if that is what is deemed to be appropriate. Let me make the point that this legislation was introduced in 1903. It was certainly amended in 1950 by removing the word `indictable'. But apart from that it was always there on the basis that when people were facing trial, particularly before a jury, something could be done to give them assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the honourable member for Denison spoke very well about the attitude of the profession as it has been in the past and as it still is. It does a lot of work for nothing or for reduced fees. Nevertheless, a lot of work is now being done for substantial fees. Therefore, one has the inevitable problem as to the amount of financial resources that are available. Let me assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I have looked at some statistics that I have here. This year we are spending $72m on legal aid. In 1977-78 we spent $19m. So one can see the rapid escalation in the amount spent on legal aid. Of course, if we look at the report of the Legal Aid Task Force which the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) referred to, we will notice that legal aid is not provided for pleas of guilty or committal proceedings. There can be a capacity within the profession-I am sure it is done at times-whereby it can service people at a substantially reduced fee or for no fee. I am not here to argue that case, except to say that members of the profession have always done that. I admire them for it. They will continue to do it.

We are dealing with the issue of whether the section is now appropriate, because there are alternative methods of providing legal aid. The honourable member for North Sydney did not really address his mind to the alternative mechanisms. In every sense there are State commissions which were set up, I might say, by a previous Liberal Attorney-General. I think it was Mr Ellicott. I do not propose to dismantle them. They are there to assess the merits of each applicant. They are composed of members of the private profession, which I would have thought the honourable gentleman would have been able to identify. They make the decisions. Further, an appeal against their decisions can be heard by an appropriate review committee, which again comprises members of the profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to courts.

—Not to courts, no, but to the profession itself. The issue is that we are dealing with matters to which the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) addressed his mind when he referred to the judgment of the judge in that particular case. He said it was inappropriate for him to try to assess the situation. I make no comment as to that particular situation, execept to say that it became a matter of some notoriety that the person who was seeking legal aid was being driven to the court in a Rolls Royce. That seemed to be a little unusual. If we look at the factors that the appropriate legal aid committee in that State-it happened to be Queensland-was able to deal with, it spoke about the lifestyle of applicants. That is one of the criteria it used for assessment. I have no doubt that if that committee felt that the lifestyle was so flamboyant and that the person had what appeared to be substantial family support, it made that decision on a bona fide basis. Nevertheless, that decision was taken virtually by an appeal to the court. The judge said in the first instance: `I would not give legal aid in the case'. There was a further appeal to the judicial review. That review directed that there would need to be legal aid. Let us look at the question of the judge himself. He said: `The fact that I have so certified is not binding in any respect'. But as a result of deliberations it now appears that the Attorney-General has no discretion in the matter and, in fact, it could be binding. So we have this extraordinary situation because of this case.

SPEECH.PARA: I was rather surprised to find that the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) was so concerned about this matter because the Party of which he is a member, which is in power in Queensland, was very concerned about the fact that legal aid had to be granted in this case. It felt it was outrageous. Right throughout Queensland members of that Party said that it made a laughing stock of the fact that legal aid-in other words, taxpayers' money-was directed to be given when the circumstances of the applicant appeared to be so affluent to all and sundry. So we have to look at public opinion in this situation. I invite the honourable member for Fisher to discuss the matter with his own Attorney-General in Queensland. In that case I asked whether the Queensland Legal Aid Commission could not assist this person. It said no, for reasons that it regarded as bona fide.

I think we have to look at this matter and get it right into perspective. We are talking here about the profession being directly involved in being able to assess the situation of legal aid. In no case will it become a question of the bureaucracy of my Department making that decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not your Department.

—The honourable member made reference to the fact that perhaps I was taking too much notice of my Department. My Department was not involved in this matter. The commissions were set up under the previous Government. I think a bona fide set up is a fair approach. These commissions were not able to be as successful as we would have liked them to be for the reasons that I will mention now. If we are obliged to spend $72m this year and we look at the escalating figures we come to the point where a line has to be drawn as to how much more money will be given to enable us to make grants to every applicant. We do not have those financial resources. But $72m is a pretty fair amount considering the fact that the former Government gave $19m in 1978.

SPEECH.PARA: The interesting thing is that only 14 applications have been made pursuant to this section of the Act since 1978 but 10 of those 14 applications have been made this year. Honourable members will notice the difference. There has been a sudden escalation. These people are saying: `We will go off to the court and we will seek an order from the judge on the basis that the Attorney-General will have to provide it'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had they previously applied for legal aid?

—Yes, they had; the honourable gentleman is entitled to ask that question. They had previously applied for legal aid and had been refused by the respective commissioners. I have no doubt that, in many cases, the commission felt that it could not give the sort of money that had been demanded. The interesting thing about a number of these applicants is that they also want to determine who their counsel and solicitors will be and they want to determine the rates which are well above what we would call normal rates. So we have an additional factor here. I can understand the private profession assessing the situation for example, in the Victorian case, where I will be giving legal aid by direction and where the cost will be almost $1m. The applicants in that case were seeking further legal aid on the basis that they wanted to be able to listen to 609 hours of recorded telephone conversations. The commission said to them: `You ought to listen to the 609 hours of conversation yourselves'. Of course, they said: `No. We want our learned counsel, both senior and junior and our solicitors to be there'. So these people have had to be provided to listen to 609 hours of their own conversations.
—Are they getting party and party or solicitor-client costs now?

—I think they are getting solicitor-client costs. I make the point that, if I have a budgetary allocation of $72m on the basis of a reasonable assessment of the number of applications which the commissions are dealing with fairly and in a bona fide way, I cannot afford to be caught in the other issues where so many more people will come on and say: `Never mind. If the legal profession knocks you back through the commission we will go to the court and get an order'. The judge himself could say: `I do not have time to go through all the merits of this. I will suggest that it be done this way under the Act'. His Honour Mr Justice Carter said that it was not really a matter for him. He said that it was inappropriate for him to be trying to determine matters of legal aid; it was a matter for the Executive, and the Executive has given this back to the professions through the commissions. I assure honourable members that I value the work done by the commissions. The problem we have is in trying to get the States to continue to make their contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: On that note let me explain what the honourable member for North Sydney was saying about what is happening in legal aid. The advisory council was given notice by my predecessor that it would expire, and of course it has expired in accordance with the notice. The advisory committee saw me, although not in relation to whether it would be retained. It accepted that there might need to be a better mechanism. I said that I thought we could do something about getting a better understanding of what we could do with our resources and guaranteeing that we got work done in accordance with what the profession wants. I would dearly like to see young members of the profession on panels in the courts and being able to perform. I think that is important. We are not here to alter the structure in any way; we are trying to get the best use of the financial resources we have. I said to the people concerned: `I still want you to be involved. We have to think of a better mechanism and you can advise me how best to achieve it'.

I would dearly like to see the profession advising me on how panels can be created, whether in the courts of petty sessions or in the various other jurisdictions, so that impecunious applicants can be dealt with immediately. Perhaps we can get rid of some of the administrative costs involved in assessing forms because the profession has always been able to do that. I think it would not be beyond the wit of the responsible registrars or people in the courts to assess readily whether an applicant is needy or otherwise. In other words, we could get a very quick method, but it would require a lot of sacrifice by the profession. I know it is prepared to do that, but it cannot be done at the fees that are now being set as appropriate. That sort of rate cannot be kept up. I am not suggesting that the rate has to be dropped, but in cases where no legal aid has been given it would be appropriate to consider methods such as that.

I want to reconstitute an advisory council to see how best we can do this together. That is the point. I have had the line drawn for me-$72m is about it; it cannot go to $80m or $90m. To divert for a minute, when $38m is going on family law cases, we can see that there is a lack of balance in priorities. When we consider that only 7 per cent of those family law cases are contested, we must ask ourselves how in the name of fortune we are spending so much legal aid money on so few cases in that jurisdiction. The most progressive aspect of this is that judges are looking at better methods of dispute resolution. It will be the most progressive method the judiciary and the legal system can achieve. In other words, there might be better methods for pre-trial conferences and for assembling evidence. It will be faster and less expensive if we can agree on procedures such as those. That reform can come from within, and I am sure it will. It will help the administration of justice.

I want to thank all those honourable members who participated in this debate. I do not agree with some of the suggestions that have been made about the Government abandoning the concept of legal aid. We are not doing that. We are more involved with legal aid than ever; we are more financially committed than ever. We are offering the service to more people than ever, but decisions are made on an impartial basis by the profession itself, really. In other words, legal aid commissions are the appropriate bodies to deal with these matters, and appeal arrangements are already in place. I want to make the point too that, in some cases, legal aid is looked at with a lifestyle criterion in mind, and there is nothing wrong with that. In other words, just because a person appears not to have any money, if his lifestyle is such that he arrives in a Rolls Royce and lives in a mansion the commissions are entitled to think that the person is not impecunious. That is one of the criteria they are applying. I make the point also that in some cases we are having difficulty because aid has been refused by the Australian Legal Aid Office and the Aboriginal Legal Service. In those cases an assessment is made by ourselves and others and the applications are refused, yet we are still being asked to pick up the obligation because of this section. The figures I have mentioned do not include Commonwealth expenditure in connection with Aboriginal legal services and community legal services, so the total is well above the figure I have mentioned.

In summary, we have had to bring up to date an old Act that is anachronistic and inappropriate. It was all right in 1903 when there were virtually no legal aid services available. At that time there was some suggestion of appropriation discretion being given to a judge. Things have improved rapidly since then, particularly in the 1970s and in the 1980s. We now have very worthwhile and effective legal aid commissions that can assess the merits of all applicants. In fact, I would be very surprised if anybody appearing in front of a jury were not represented because of difficulties with legal aid. I do not think any judge, as the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) would say, would want a trial to go on if the accused was saying: `I cannot get any support'. That sort of thing really does not happen. Everybody can make an application to a legal aid commission if that is where he feels he ought to go.

So what we are dealing with here are exceptional circumstances which appear to have come into fashion this year. Ten applications have been made this year pursuant to the Act because the applicants were all rejected under the normal procedure. In other words, it is virtually the intelligent thing for some people to say: `I can do better. I can still get my own lawyer at his price but get it paid for pursuant to an order made under section 69 (3)'. That was not the intention of the legislation. The intention of section 69 (3) was to provide a basis for legal representation when no other alternative was available. An alternative is available and is well used.

I inform the honourable member for Fisher that the Queensland Legal Aid Commission makes the decisions in Queensland and I do not disagree with what it decides. The honourable member complained about a decision of his own Queensland Legal Aid Commission. He wants to remember that I do not make those decisions. I am very satisfied with what His Honour Mr Justice Carter said. The responsibility of the court is onerous enough without having to work out whether legal aid should be granted. In fact, by the court so doing, an accused may well be prejudiced. We should leave it to the profession and the Commission to act in this matter, and they are doing just that. Where a request is refused a person has the right of appeal. I think that the procedures are adequate enough. However, to have me then involved on the basis that it is deemed to be mandatory that I make a decision and that therefore I have no discretion is really counterproductive and contrary to the intention of setting up the commissions to assess the situation on merit.

It is obvious that not everybody can get legal aid. It is clear that the taxpayer cannot afford to give everybody legal aid. Litigation is much more extensive than that would permit. So there has to be priority. Basically it is applied in cases where people who are very poor come before the courts. But I welcome the fact that the profession has always been prepared to co-operate and is very much involved. I intend to keep it that way. The only solution that I need now is how we can spread the $72m a little further than it might otherwise go. If I have to spend $1m a case under certain directions, that amount will not go very far. That is the reason why we have had to say: `Let us get some common sense into this situation. This is an Act which is outdated. The alternative is there'. While ever the alternative is there, and I am sure it will remain irrespective of what government is about, we have no intention of affecting the rights of citizens in any way. However, we have an obligation to guarantee that the taxpayers' money is effectively used. On that basis, the alternative suggested by way of an amendment cannot be accepted because it would leave me in the position of still having to make such other legal aid arrangements as I considered appropriate.

It is not for me to use a discretion when in fact the discretion is being effectively, intelligently and equitably used by legal aid commissions on which the private profession is adequately represented. I would be very surprised if I did not hear about an application that was refused by a legal aid commission. However, I would be very surprised if I were prone to rescind a decision that was made by a commission to refuse an application, because the commissions are made up by very balanced people who would assess these matters in accordance with criteria. I have never had any complaint about the decisions of those commissions. In every case they deal with applications fairly and effectively. Members of the commissions do the work virtually on a voluntarily basis; I must say that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called privatisation.

—The honourable member may call it what he likes. However, it is called justice. From my point of view, I think they are doing an admirable job. Certainly we have to talk about whether we can improve the situation and this is the other point that I mentioned earlier. I think that we can do better, but it would require greater sacrifice from the profession. It would also require reformation and innovation of the procedures of the court in order to reduce costs. It is very clear to me that what we are about here is just removing an old provision that is no longer appropriate, and the amendment foreshadowed by the honourable member for North Sydney would leave me in the situation of having to-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The Minister's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 1, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Indictments
``3. Section 69 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting in sub-section (3) `or refer the matter to such legal aid authorities as he considers appropriate' after `the accused person'.''.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has already said that he does not agree to this amendment. I wish to explain it, although I have faint hopes of changing his mind, because I think that he has rather misunderstood it. If my amendment were accepted, it would be added to the end of the relevant part of section 69 (3) of the Act, which states:

If it be found to the satisfaction of the Justice or Judge that such person is without adequate means to provide defence for himself, and that it is desirable in the interests of justice that such an appointment should be made, the Justice or Judge shall certify this to the Attorney-General, who may if he thinks fit thereupon cause arrangements to be made for the defence of the accused person . . .
To this sentence would be added my amendment, which states:
Or refer the matter to such legal aid authorities as he considers appropriate.

That would overcome the kind of problem, one would think, that the Attorney-General was so concerned about. After all, it would give him a discretion to refer the matter to legal aid authorities. Some complaints have been made by some honourable members on the other side of the chamber about the fact that this provision goes back a very long time. So it does. So does trial by jury. So does habeas corpus and so do a lot of the rights on which we exist and for which we depend.

Let us put to one side all this talk about Daniell's Chancery Practice. Let us put to one side the fact that some judges may not be terribly happy with having the onerous job of deciding whether or not these applications should be granted. Let us look at the facts which have been put so candidly by the Attorney-General and which have demonstrated the reason for this provision.

In the first place, the Attorney-General referred to the Maher case. That is an example, one would think, of hard cases making bad law. It appears that there is some feeling of resentment in the Attorney-General's Department. I do not say that applies to the Attorney-General-I do not think that he is a man given very greatly to resentment-but certainly the Department feels that things were badly done. This may be the reason why we are discussing this Bill today and not for any other reason. It does not matter whether this case was right or wrong; the question is whether or not the discretion and the power should remain in the court. Where necessary and regardless of how infrequently it may be necessary to have recourse to the court, it should have the power to make orders in the interests of justice.

The Attorney-General, in his disarming and frank manner, let the cat out of the bag. As he said, 10 applications have been refused this year. Those 10 applications are being heard. I do not know whether they have been successful. I presume that some of them may have been successful. But at all events these applications are pending or have been successfully heard or unsuccessfully dealt with under section 69 (3). The Attorney-General cited a particular case. I have read that case, along with other unreported decisions upon this provision. It is worth while understanding what it was all about. The Attorney cited the case where an accused person wanted to get his legal advisers to listen to tapes for 609 hours. One would think to oneself: `That is rather odd'. But these tapes were 609 hours of intercepted telephone conversations. Let me quote from the judgment of Mr Justice Ormiston:

On 3rd June this year I ruled that the accused and their legal representatives should have access to material produced on subpoena duces tecum consisting of 609 hours of tape-recorded intercepted telephone conversations of the accused and alleged co-conspirators . . .

We all know why the judge made that order. It is perfectly futile to say that the accused may listen to the tapes, but not his legal representatives. If his legal representatives are going to listen for 609 hours, one would expect them to be paid, would one not? It would be astonishing if they were not. Six hundred and nine hours out of a 50-hour or 60-hour week is a long time out of one's working life. I go on with the judgment. What happened? Mr Justice Ormiston referred to the conditions that had been imposed by the Legal Aid Commission, the first being that the Commission had determined an agreed reading fee. Apparently, it was not willing to increase it. The judge said:

Council for each accused informed me that, because of the terms of the confirmed decision of 6th June, they had returned their briefs for the trial. They had accepted instructions, however, to pursue the application under s. 69 (3) . . .

One can understand why one would return one's brief, even though it is a very major thing to do in a criminal trial. Who here would want to sit down and spend 609 hours of his time unpaid preparing for a trial? The judge considered the arguments and went on to say:

There remains the question of whether it is desirable in the interests of justice that an appointment of counsel be made. I have no difficulty in reaching that conclusion. I accept that the condition is not satisfied merely because the accused wishes to contest a criminal trial, but, as I have already stated, the charge bears the maximum penalty of life imprisonment. The material and the evidentiary issues are highly complicated, at least to my view at the present time. The Crown cannot be fairly asked to look after the accused's interests in this case.
That is a fairly elementary proposition, is it not? The judge went on to say:

I therefore propose to certify that I am satisfied that each of the accused is without adequate means to provide a defence for himself or herself, and that it is desirable in the interests of justice that counsel be appointed for his or her defence. Of course, I can say nothing as to the manner in which the Attorney-General will provide that assistance.

If the Attorney-General is under the impression that somehow the courts direct what the assistance is and how much counsel are to be paid, he is quite wrong. In that event he has been mistakenly advised. The fees are not set by the courts. We know that applications have been made because legal aid has been refused. We know that in a murder case, where the accused were facing life imprisonment, the judge decided that the interests of justice required him to come to a different conclusion from that of the Legal Aid Commission. That establishes the reason why the discretion should remain.
