Regardless of how well intentioned judges are, regardless, indeed, of how expert they are and regardless of the time they may be able to give to these applications, they still remain the most experienced people in the business of administering justice. What the courts are about is administering justice to the consumers of justice, and the consumers of justice are those who appear, whether as defendants in criminal cases or as litigants in civil cases. Therefore, I ask of the Attorney-General, though not with high hopes of his accepting the proposition, that since his arguments are not well based, that since the case he referred to provides the most vivid illustration of the reason why the discretion should remain in the court, he reconsider and support the amendment, which would leave him pretty much in control of events, or at least as far in control of events as he needs to be, and would leave a supervisory power in the courts to be used in cases where it merits being used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support with pleasure the amendment moved by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), and I again appeal to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to consider carefully what the honourable member for North Sydney said and, even at this stage, to review the Government's decision not to accept the amendment. What this amendment does is almost exactly what the Attorney-General was appealing for in his concluding remarks in the second reading debate. The Attorney-General then asked that the question of granting legal aid be dealt with by the legal aid commissions. He asked for the bodies who are entrusted with administering legal aid to have the right to determine those matters rather than to retain what the Attorney-General described, I suggest erroneously, as an anachronistic provision. The amendment facilitates exactly what the Attorney-General said. It means that when a learned judge refers the case to the Attorney-General he has two choices: He can either make the appropriate arrangements for the provision of counsel for the defence of that person, or refer it to such legal aid authority as he considers appropriate for that authority to make the decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I submit that this debate has been outstanding because it has been non-partisan and non-political. I put it to the Attorney-General that what the honourable member for North Sydney proposes gives the Attorney-General the best of both worlds. It means that the Attorney-General, as the principal crown law officer of the Commonwealth, can either decide himself or refer the matter to the commission. The Attorney-General indicated, I think properly, that in his view these matters should be dealt with by the commission. If that is so, the Attorney-General exercises his discretion in each case by referring it to the commission. To take it at its highest, what does this mean? It means that a person can make an application to the commission and then be refused legal aid. It means that when he comes up for trial his counsel can make application under section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act to the learned trial judge. The learned trial judge will then make a determination as to whether, I respectfully submit, there is a prima facie case for legal aid to be granted. He makes the order under section 69 (3) and it lands on the Attorney's desk. The Attorney then has the alternative either to make the arrangements which the learned trial judge has directed-and I quote verbatim `. . . that it is desirable in the interests of justice that counsel be appointed'-or, if the Attorney so desires, to hand the matter over to the commission.

I appeal to the Attorney, as did the honourable member for North Sydney, to accept this amendment because it will give the Attorney the best of both worlds. He can either deal with it himself or send it to the commission. Contrary to the second reading speech and accepting, as I have, the Attorney's obvious sincerity and fairness in this matter, I now put it to the Committee that, if the Attorney rejects the amendment, unwittingly this Government will be breaching, indeed repudiating, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to which Australia is a party. Let me quote it verbatim before the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), who has joined us in the dying hours of the debate, laughs. It says:

Everyone shall be entitled to the following minimum guarantees- . . . to have legal assistance assigned to him, in any case where the interests of justice so require, and without payment by him in any such case if he does not have sufficient means to pay for it.

What do we find? We find by an extraordinary coincidence of history that the founding fathers, who were working on the Judiciary Act 1903 at the same time as they were working on the Constitution, came up with the identical words in section 69 (3) as we find in Article 14.3 (d) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

I note the presence in the chamber of the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones). He and I will remember a case many years ago involving a man named Tait. That man was prejudged by the media because of the circumstances of a crime which were horrific. If one had put the question to everyone in the street at the time `Should this man be given legal aid?' the answer would have been negative. He was a man whom a government endeavoured to hang. I can remember seeing the now senior puisne judge of the Supreme Court of Victoria, Mr Justice Starke, arguing before the High Court of Australia presided over by that great jurist, Sir Owen Dixon, 23 hours before Tait was to be executed. I remember with pride the role played by the Minister for Science and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding). I also remember the role of others from all sides of politics who came out in relation to that matter. I suggest that we put the clock back to 1962, the year of the case of Robert Peter Tait. What would the Attorney-General do in that situation? What would he do if a judge said: `You, Tait, in my opinion will not have a fair trial unless counsel is assigned to you.'? On what the Attorney-General has said tonight, he would say: `I am sorry, I wash my hands of this matter; it goes to the commission'. I submit that that is an abrogation and an abdication of his function as the principal Crown Law Officer of the Commonwealth which he, in his heart, does not intend.

In the minute remaining to me I plead with the Attorney because I believe the honourable member for North Sydney has put forward an unanswerable case. Rather than vote against our amendment tonight, the Attorney should defer this matter and take advice. That would not add to the cost for the simple reason that if the amendment is defeated and what he has said is to be the order of the day, there will be a commission making the decision. I do not accept that commissions, including those comprising members of my own profession, are infallible. I must say-and I think the honourable member for North Sydney adverted to this-I do not think there is any right of appeal in my State of Tasmania. I must put it to the Attorney-General, because I was surprised to hear him say that there was a right of appeal. I am not aware of it. There is certainly no judicial appeal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to the courts, but to the profession.
—Please, you are a fundamental lawyer. What you are doing here is substituting an administrative or quasi-administrative decision-making process for a judicial one.
—What is your amendment doing?
—The amendment gives you the option of both.
—No it does not.

—With respect, the Attorney-General does not seem to understand what the amendment says. The amendment says that the learned judge should refer the matter to the Attorney-General for him to arrange legal aid and, as the honourable member for North Sydney has moved, the Attorney-General then has the option-the Attorney-General not the judge-to refer the matter to such legal aid authority as he considers appropriate. I know that I am not the most eloquent or intelligent member of this chamber, but I would have thought that the Attorney would have seized this as a very fair and commendable amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I shall report progress.

Mr Lionel Bowen-I require that the question be put forthwith without debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nearly finished. I appeal to the Attorney-General. The honourable member for North Sydney spelt out the position eloquently and, I believe, persuasively. I appeal to the Attorney to take the time to check what he said. The amendment gives an alternative under the present section 69 (3) so that the Attorney may arrange these matters. He is not happy about that because he has said that this section over the last 12 months has been used 10 times. He said that it is not right for an Attorney-General, or a judge for that matter, to make such an order.

SPEECH.PARA: He said that it should be done by the legal aid authority namely, the Legal Aid Commission. That is exactly what the amendment of the honourable member for North Sydney gives him the right to do. Rather than scrapping section 69 (3) from the Judiciary Act, which is the second most important legal enactment of the Commonwealth of Australia, I appeal to the Attorney to accept the amendment. It will not cost him any more because I guarantee the odds are that those matters which the Attorney passes to the Commission, having come via the judicial process, are likely to be approved for legal aid in any event.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is not agreed to for the reasons that have been mentioned. There is an alternative and that happens to be the legal aid commissions in addition to what already exists under the old Act of 1903 when they did not exist. There was a provision under which the Attorney-General, if he thought fit, could make arrangements. All of those matters have been arranged in terms of the legal aid commissions. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) moved an amendment which gets me back to the position that I might refer the matter to such legal aid authorities as I consider appropriate, and these would be the commissions. It is usually the case that the matters have already been referred to them. The judges say: `We cannot be making detailed examination of the facts because a judgment has to be made on whether or not people have the means'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no good the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) shaking his head. It is not a question of whether people need legal aid. It is agreed that they need legal aid. The question is: Have they the means to provide their own legal representation? We are talking about these cases on that basis. The Family Court of Australia can do it, as can all courts. I do not know of any accused who has gone without legal aid. The profession is always able to provide assistance except in areas which the task force identified. This has been withdrawn in pleas of guilty and in committal cases. The point at issue and the one which the honourable member for North Sydney was anxious to talk about was a case which I do not want to name. However, it was made very clear that the Victorian Legal Aid Commission decided that it was not going to extend its legal aid to defend the accused. It objected to the fact that it was necessary to listen to 609 hours of tapes. That was the decision and that is where there was some argument. The cost of that was $500,000.

I can understand the Commission making a decision that it wanted people to listen to the tapes and make the appropriate notes. In other words, it was merely going over a known factor of what was said by whom to whom. It was just a question of fact and I think that that was a valid assessment. Instead of having to spend half a million dollars for legal fees, it could get it done by another method. That is the basis of that argument.

The other matter became a laughing stock. When the Queensland Legal Aid Commission refused an applicant, it did so on the basis that the applicant was well known and appeared to have access to substantial resources. That is a fact. It is not much good the honourable gentleman and me arguing that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like preparing a case.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney has had his go and it is now the Attorney-General's turn.
—It is just a friendly back and forth chat.
—The honourable member will cease interjecting.

—I appreciate your assistance, Madam Chairman, because what we are trying to do here is look at the specific cases. Where have the legal aid commissions been in error? I do not think they have been. They have judged the issues on the merits as they see them, and the members of those commissions are from the private legal profession. Why should I say now that I will send this matter back? That is about the best I could do under the amendment; refer it back. I could do that now or at any time. In fact the accused, or those who were seeking aid, would do it many times. There is an appeal system in the profession; it is not a judicial appeal; I accept that. The honourable member gets worried about the fact that when I say `appeal' I must mean a judicial one, but I do not. I mean the fact that the commissions have their own methods of appeal for reviewing their own decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: What are we arguing about here? We are not arguing about the fact that anybody has been denied legal representation; we are arguing about the fact of the monetary equivalent that might be given to an applicant. That is the position. In some cases the applicant--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not arguing about principles; we are arguing about cash.

—We are arguing about principles, because we say we do not want to see anybody without legal representation. The principle has always existed that if a person has adequate resources he or she does not get legal aid. That is the position. The honourable gentleman opposite says that means that once the applicant asks for legal aid the commission must accept the applicant's view and give him or her legal aid.
—I have never said that, and you know it.

—No, but we get to that position because there has to be a group which will judge the situation. That is the point. The honourable member's amendment merely says that this matter should be referred back to that group. I do not know what for. The group has already dealt with it. What other appropriate legal authority would be there?
—They have been found in error.

—If there is an error, I am sure that it will be identified by the person making the application. Certainly I would think that when a person comes before a court and is standing there unrepresented it is normal for the judge to make further inquiries. I do not know of any court that is prevented from doing that. A judge would not look at an accused and say: `I do not have to worry whether he is represented or not. I will just assume that he does not want any representation'. The accused themselves are always the first to speak up as to their position. Cases are adjourned on the basis that the accused might get legal aid.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it clear that legal aid is a very effective business at present which is using up $72m. It is not a small business or an ad hoc charity handout arrangement. The legal profession has established a clear-cut set of guidelines as to what is a reasonable fee in the appropriate States. In some cases applicants have said: `We do not want the legal aid offered to us; we want to engage our own counsel and solicitors at a higher fee'. That is the other factor. So it is not appropriate for me to say to the honourable gentlemen opposite that there is nothing wrong with his amendment. All it would do is send the matter back to where it came from. The fact that he has moved the amendment seems to recognise that there is some defect in the present situation, which there is. In other words, the alternative mechanism is there and it can be and is being used effectively. If the Opposition wants a review of legal aid decisions because it is not satisfied with them, it would not be doing it this way. It would be doing it in some other way; perhaps on the basis that the legal aid commissions will be the subject of review, as they are. The point is that the decisions are reviewed.

I make the point that it has become a fashion this year to suggest that if legal aid commissions have not given the right decision people can go to court on an application under section 69 (3) and ask the Attorney-General to do better. That is the point. The honourable member for North Sydney says: `The best thing the Attorney-General can do under the amendment is to refer it to an appropriate legal aid authority'. That is all this amendment would do. It gets me no further. It does not solve the problem. He and I both agree that the appropriate authority is the legal aid commission. We might disagree as to its decisions, but I am convinced that the decisions the commission makes are bona fide decisions. It makes decisions on a judgment of the circumstances of the case or what it calls the lifestyle. On that basis there is no merit in accepting an amendment which merely puts me in the position of doing something that has already been done. In every case there has been a question before the legal aid commissions, and in every case those commissions have made a decision. In some cases there have been appeals from those decisions. It is as simple as that. The honourable gentleman's amendment would mean that I should refer it back to the commission. I do not see any merit in it. I can understand the concern that people might not be represented but I am not aware that that has ever happened.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen)-by leave-proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I will take but one minute-
—Sit down, you clown.

—I am very surprised that honourable members opposite, some of whom I know are acquainted with a recent case which I believe to have been a travesty, are treating with levity the right of an honourable member on a third reading to appeal to the Government to look again at a Bill before it is passed into law.
—Sit down, you have had three goes.

—I might have 23 goes if it is in the interests of the people of Australia. The attitude of honourable members opposite shows that they just do not appreciate what this matter is about. I think that is very unfortunate. I say to the honourable members from Moscow corner that Mr Norm Gallagher will find more comfort in my remarks than in their attitudes displayed in this House tonight. Each citizen of this country is entitled to precisely what the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) pleaded for. It is a tragedy that the Government has not accepted the amendment. The Government still has time to think again and accept the honourable member's proposal before it is too late and the citizens of this country lose a fundamental basic right which is their birthright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The stated purpose of the Customs Tariff (Stand-by Duty) Bill 1985 is to impose a 3c per litre-that is about $5 per barrel-special customs duty on imports of light crude oils and petroleum products by local oil refiners who do not pick up their allocation of Australian crude oil. No duty wil be payable on imports that are used to meet the demand for heavy oil products such a bitumen. For Bass Strait oil, action to impose the duty will commence when a refiner has had a shortfall in liftings for each of three consecutive months occurring after June 1985. In relation to smaller oil producing areas, action will commence after a shortfall has occurred in each of six consecutive months occurring after March 1985. This Bill is an attempt by the Government to further increase its control over oil production in Australia.
—Shame!

—Absolutely. In effect, the Bill allows the Government to dictate the source and the amount of crude oil refiners must use and to penalise those who step out of line. This Bill therefore gives the Government the power to maintain its revenue from the crude oil levy. The coalition is opposed to increased regulation of the oil industry and will vote against the Bill. Oil industry representatives are also opposed to the proposal. They are well aware that any short-sighted motivation could well lead to further government control and taxes which would absolutely destroy this industry. The Government's legislation and proposals for legislation in the oil industry are aimed at control and extra revenue for the Government. These are the primary motivations of this Hawke Labor Government. The Government initially introduced similar legislation in May 1984. However, following overwhelming industry opposition to the measures proposed, the Bill was left to lapse.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Government has apparently made some concession to meet the criticisms of industry, the general and vital principle of the legislation remains unchanged. The legislation is contrary to the spirit of the voluntary allocation arrangements and to other measures to deregulate the crude oil market. Longer term exports were permitted in the 1985-86 Budget. The proposal is also inequitable in that there are no other controls over imports. The duty would not apply to independent retailers. The Opposition believes that there should be a move towards further deregulation of the oil industry to allow the operation of free market forces which would permit crude oil production and prices to reflect true world market conditions.

Australian fuel users have seen increases in the price of fuel this year at a time of world oil surpluses. Analysis of fuel prices shows that 60 per cent of those prices, or about 32c per litre of fuel, goes back to the Federal Government. The economy has a fragile dependency on oil taxes, as shown by the Budget figures for recent years set out in a table which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard. I have shown it to the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones).
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This schedule shows the reliance of the Federal Government on levies, excises and royalties on fuel to the extent of 10.9 per cent of revenue in 1982-83, 11.8 per cent in 1983-84 and 11.4 per cent in 1984-85. The figure for the coming year is contemplated to be 10.8 per cent. In that four-year period the revenue to government has increased from $4.8 billion to nearly $6.9 billion. It makes up a large part of Federal revenue, and that is being reflected in prices. Refiners have had an incentive not to pick up locally produced oil during the world oil market downturn in 1984 and following the depreciation of the Australian dollar during 1985. Both of those occurrences led to lower priced crude oil import alternatives.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the devaluation and the increase in the price into Australia, I draw the attention of the House to the devaluation of the Australian dollar against world currencies since 31 December 1984. The currency that we usually use for comparison purposes is the United States dollar, and against that the Australian dollar has experienced a 19 per cent devaluation in that 10-month period. Against the Japanese yen it has depreciated by 32.8 per cent, against the pound sterling by 34.6 per cent, against the German mark by 33.1 per cent and, most surprisingly of all, against the New Zealand dollar by 32.9 per cent. So it is not only in cricket that we are doing badly against New Zealand; we are doing badly with our dollar as well.

When we look at that comparison we must realise that this currency devaluation impacts on costs to the Australian community. I have mentioned fuel as one of those costs to industry but we have also the cost of the greater interest being paid to shore up the flagging dollar, as well as the increased cost of imports. All of these things are costs to the Australian community. The Government now seeks to impose restrictions on refiners obtaining cheaper crude oil from overseas as a result of deficiencies in its own economic policies. The Government is concerned to gain as much revenue from crude oil as it can before it runs out. After all, it is a finite resource.

What happens when the taxation exploitation of this product puts the Australian industry out of production altogether? The Government is not concerned with Australian consumers possibly benefiting from cheaper oil supplies but rather with grabbing as much revenue as possible for its own benefit. This is despite the fact that Government revenue has increased substantially following the unanticipated increase in production and the depreciation induced price increases. This increased revenue for 1985 over the Budget estimates by $507m in the crude oil levy and $56m in excises. In other words, the Government has profited from devaluation at a cost to the consumer. As I have mentioned before, all of this has resulted in more expensive fuel at the bowser.

In fact the Government will have had windfall gains in the order of some $800m by the end of the financial year resulting solely from a discredited currency. Still this greedy Government is not satisfied and now it seeks to introduce further controls in an attempt to maintain and increase its revenue from petroleum. It is conceivable that the Government could stand to raise about $25m per month through this draconian proposal in the unlikely event that all six refiners remain in a shortfall situation for an extended period. As I have already mentioned, Government taxes and charges already account for more than 60 per cent of the price of fuel to Australians. The Government should be moving to decrease its dependence on fuel for revenue, not attempting to bolster it.

At a time of severely depressed returns, Australia's primary producers are being further hampered by high input costs. Government taxes and charges can significantly affect these costs. This Government should be moving to ease this burden, not casting about for ways to add to it. Australian fuel users should be allowed to benefit from cheaper world oil prices. This Bill seeks to prevent that. The Bill is contrary to the general deregulatory stance of the coalition and the coalition's commitment to introduce a free oil market. The coalition will reverse the trend to greater government ownership and control at the expense of private enterprise, initiative and reward. The Opposition has no option but to oppose this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Stand-By Duty) Bill 1985 forms part of the Government's policy on domestic crude oil marketing arrangements. It is a policy which was announced by a former Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, on 9 October 1984. The purpose of the Bill is to enable the imposition of a special Customs duty of 3c a litre on the importation of certain petroleum oils, only in the circumstances of that proving necessary in the event of a shortfall or underlifting of indigenous crude oils by local refiners. As has been noted, I think in the explanatory memorandum, the commencement date of this Bill will be the day on which it receives the royal assent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill enables refiners' performance prior to the commencement date of the Bill, but after June 1985 in respect of Bass Strait oil and after March 1985 in respect of minor oil, to be taken into account in determining whether the provisions for the imposition of the special duty need to be invoked. The provisions of the Bill however do not enable the imposition of any duty in less than two months after the date of royal assent.

Before touching on some of the points made by the Opposition, I emphasise that before the imposition of any duty under this legislation a series of steps would have to be taken. As I said, those steps are outlined in the explanatory memorandum. Very briefly, a number of steps would have to be followed. They provide that a refiner would have had to have had, during each of the three consecutive annual months that occurred after June 1985, a shortfall of Bass Strait oil or an underlift of minor oil from a particular oil source during a period of six consecutive annual months that occurred after March 1985. The Minister for Resources and Energy also has to be satisfied that the shortfall of Bass Strait oil or the underlift of minor oil from a particular oil source was principally within the control of the refiner.

The Bill further provides that, if the refiner does not respond within the calendar month or the information supplied does not satisfy the Minister, the Minister is required to take a number of steps. Firstly, the Minister is required to notify the refiner that he or she is satisfied that the shortfall or underlift was within the control of the refiner and, secondly, unless precluded by a further provision of the legislation, that he or she proposes to issue a certificate to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce stating that it is appropriate that duty be payable.

The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who spoke before me in this debate, when indicating that he did not support the legislation, made some comments about the prices of petroleum products in Australia, particularly their impact on certain sectors of the community-those sectors such as our primary industries which are price and cost sensitive. He suggested that obviously the larger part of the price of petroleum in Australia was in effect the result of government taxes and charges and that a responsible government ought to be reducing those taxes and charges in order to reduce burdens on certain industries.

I think it is appropriate to say in the context of those remarks that indeed in industries in which cost pressures are placed on producers as a result of the prices of petroleum products the Government in fact has taken steps to reduce the impact of those prices on such producers. In fact, only two months ago, in the August Budget, the Government announced the excising and rebating of off-road diesel for primary producers, which in effect reduces the price of diesel to primary producers by approximately 2c a litre. That was a decision taken in a budgetary context and in the context of duties, taxes and charges by this Government at an annual Budget cost of about $35m. That is something we did to reduce the cost impact on primary producers in terms of their petroleum product usage.

The general assertion made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dawson, that Australians are paying far too much for their petrol and diesel and that they are not getting the benefit of reduced prices in the international market is something I would not accept or support. The fact is that on an international basis petrol prices in Australia are amongst the lowest of any of our trading partners or any of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Indeed if we look at the prices paid even very recently by the 20 or so nations with whom we trade we will find that Australia ranked amongst the lowest two or three in terms of petrol pricing per litre. I know it is something there is concern about, particularly in the country areas of Australia.

I repeat that we do have a policy of import parity pricing. It is a policy that was introduced by the previous Government and it is a policy which is soundly based. It is necessary for all sorts of reasons, not the least being that if we do not price our petrol and our petroleum products at an international price, if we price them lower, there will be greater incentives for local production to be exported to get the international price. Also there will be increased consumption of locally derived petroleum products because of the lower price, which would more quickly deplete the available stocks. Of course petroleum is a precious resource and, I suppose, one of the key elements of import parity pricing is that we do conserve this very vital resource. Even at present pricing levels and the returns that are provided to producers discovering new oil in Australia, there is every likelihood that by the year 2000 we will be considerably less self-sufficient in oil and petroleum products than we currently are.

Even with the increases in the price of petrol in the last year or so, it is a fact that consumption has continued to increase in real terms. It is interesting to note that last year the sales of V8 motor cars of over 4.2 litres increased, if my memory serves me correctly, by about 12 1/2 per cent. So while the high price of petrol may be hurting some people on low incomes, on a general measure of its price-demand and so on throughout the community it is not at such a price as to be prohibitive; in fact all the indications are that it is still very competitively priced and consumption continues to rise. The simple fact is that if we want local exploration to continue we need to establish a price that gives a reasonable return on that exploration.

The last point I want to touch on, since it was raised by the previous speaker, is the overall question of whether import parity pricing does reflect accurately the true level of world prices. A number of points can be made about that. IPP is a system which is based on a formula that values indigenous crudes, as I said previously, at the cost of replacing them with imports. It is an appropriate basis of policy for Australia because Australia does not produce enough oil to meet our needs, and probably never will. As I said, the likely outcome is that we will become less self-sufficient over time in terms of oil production. The price of crude oil is a critical determinant of the way in which resources are used within the economy. It is therefore desirable that the price of Australian crude oil should reflect its true value. Import parity pricing helps ensure that consumers are encouraged to adopt the most economic pattern of energy use through conservation measures and, of course, in substitution away from oil.

As I indicated before, IPP encourages investment in exploration and development for oil and substitute fuels. The current IPP formula uses Arab light to reflect world prices. This crude is taken as the marker crude because it is the pivot of the Organisation for Petroleum Exporting Countries price structure. It is traded widely and in large volumes and it would have been a major import into Australia if local crudes had not been found. Recently the Government amended the formula to include spot price elements, which it has to be said now more accurately reflect world prices. The formula also takes account of the costs of importing the crude into Australia: The formula also includes a component to account for the different values of different crudes. That element is currently under review by a joint government-industry committee to make sure that it accurately reflects these differences. Finally, on that point, it needs to be said that as all world oil business is done in United States dollars the formula has to be converted to Australian dollars and the Reserve Bank of Australia exchange rate is used.

The financial impact of the measure is such that refiners who purchase the quantities or percentages allocated to them will not be required to pay any additional penalty customs duty. However, if a refiner does not purchase the amounts allocated the penalty duty may be imposed. In the event that a medium sized refiner is required to pay the duty, it is expected that approximately $4m would be paid to the Government each month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Stand-By Duty) Bill, a seemingly minor Bill which is before the House tonight, is another example of the burden that the Federal Labor Government is placing on small business and rural people, the wealth creators of our community, and I join with the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) in expressing my opposition to the Bill. As other members of the House have already pointed out, the purpose of the Bill is to impose a 3c a litre or $5 a barrel customs duty on crude oil imports by local refiners who do not pick up the full allocation of Australian crude. A similar proposal was introduced in 1984 and was very strongly rejected at that time by the oil industry. This new proposal which has come before the House is very similar, with extremely minor amendments on the basis of discussions with the oil industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition opposes the Bill for a large number of reasons but, in particular, the Bill will impose higher fuel prices yet again on the Australian community. It is another example of a greater degree of trade protection provided for a particular part of Australian industry. I think that all honourable members would realise by now-if they do not realise this they must be fairly unaware of feeling in the community-that Australians are sick and tired of these things. It is a seemingly minor piece of legislation and this is a debate which has been conducted with relatively little passion, but it does reveal a fundamental approach of the Australian Labor Party towards the oil industry.

Despite the rhetoric which sometimes comes from the other side of the House, the Labor Party, as far as the oil industry is concerned, is clearly committed to regulation, controls, higher prices and higher taxation. That is not surprising coming from a political party which is committed to the nationalisation of the oil industry through a hydrocarbons corporation. That commitment is in its policy and has often been spoken of by the Minister responsible for this portfolio. It is not surprising coming from a party which is committed to a resources rent tax, and it is not surprising coming from a party which is also committed, unfortunately now successfully thanks to the perfidy of the Australian Democrats, to the cash bonus bidding proposals. All of these measures push up taxes, costs and prices. The losers from these measures ultimately are ordinary individual Australian people who are trying to make a living and who have to buy fuel for the various functions that they conduct.

Until this legislation was introduced into the House, there was a voluntary agreement between the six oil refiners and the Federal Government on the proportion of locally produced oil to be used by the refiners. All the oil companies have agreed that that voluntary agreement has worked well, at least in the medium term. Sometimes there have been cases of what is described in the industry as under lifting, of the refiners not meeting their full requirements of use of locally produced oil. But the fact is that over the longer term they have been able to compensate for those shortfalls in the use of locally produced oil and I understand that everybody has been reasonably satisfied with the way the system has worked until now; there is no question about that.

As a result of this legislation, the nature of that voluntary agreement is quite obviously fundamentally changed. That is extremely regrettable. This Labor Government claims to be a government that operates on the principle of consensus. But it is only reasonable that I draw the attention of the House to the simple fact that the change involved in this legislation was not made with the agreement of the oil industry. It was not made with the agreement of anybody in that industry. In other words, it was not a consensus decision, just as the decision to impose on the community a capital gains tax was not a consensus decision. Indeed, I point out that the oil industry was not even consulted about this piece of legislation. The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, which is the principal body responsible for the industry, was not consulted on the drafting of this latest piece of legislation.

Coming back to the principle of consensus, it is a little odd that a government which argues consensus has not even bothered to consult the industry. The Bill has been opposed by all six of the Australian domestic refiners. The Bill has been opposed by the oil producers themselves. We need to ask why they have expressed such opposition, albeit not terribly public opposition, to this Bill.

There are three reasons why that opposition has been expressed. The first is a philosophical reason-that all those involved in the oil industry favour a much greater degree of deregulation in the industry. This Bill is seen as a retrograde step, as a step which is in a sense against the best interests of the industry. To make a concession to the Government, the industry and, indeed, the Opposition have welcomed the move to allow the industry long term export contracts. That was a very positive measure and it was an example of the Government's taking a couple of steps down the road to Damascus, but suddenly veering off into the bushes, with this particular regulatory imposition on the community.

It is certainly my view and the view of the Opposition that the oil producers should be able to sell the oil that they produce at the best possible price and under the best possible arrangements, whether the market be at home or abroad. What the Government is doing in this legislation is compelling the producers to sell a certain quantity of the oil they produce at home regardless of whether they can get a better price abroad and regardless of whether they can do a better deal abroad. I find it quite extraordinary that a government would impose that sort of regulation on the industry when what we should be trying to do is to encourage oil exploration, not discourage it, to encourage the producers to be able to get the best deal they can, not discourage them with the sort of anachronistic legislation and anachronistic regulation of which this Bill consists.

The second reason why the industry and the Opposition oppose this piece of legislation is that it is completely inconsistent. While it applies to the six oil refiners in Australia, it does not apply to the independent retailers. They can import as much oil as they like with impunity. Of course, under this legislation that does not apply to the local refiners. They end up paying this anachronistic duty on the oil that they import should they import more than a certain quantity.

The truth of this piece of legislation-and this is the third reason why I oppose it-is that in effect it is little more than a tax measure. It is little more than a revenue raising measure designed to boost government revenue through the crude oil levy, that levy which applies to locally produced crude. This is just another example, the second example in the last two days, of the Government using the oil industry as the milk cow for the Government's coffers. The same thing was done through the cash bonus bidding scheme, which again is just another piece of legislation introduced to raise revenue for the Commonwealth Government. This piece of legislation, which is less severe than the cash bonus bidding scheme, will raise $4m for each month that one of the medium sized refiners remains below quota. So there is clearly a very major potential for the Government to raise revenue in the event of a particular refiner falling below quota, for whatever reason that may be. There are a large number of reasons why refiners do fall below quota.

Of course, what is ultimately important about legislation is not the effect that it has on refiners or producers; what is ultimately important is the effect that legislation has on ordinary individuals in the community, and the fact is that in the longer term this legislation has the potential to be just another price impost on Australians who consume fuel and that, of course, is just about every single Australian. I speak from the heart when I say that because, as a member who represents a rural electorate, it is the rural users of fuel who pay a disproportionate price compared with metropolitan users.

Already the wholesale price of petrol in South Australia, which is admittedly incumbered by the policies of the Bannon Labor Government, is almost 53 1/2c a litre. The Federal Government takes 31.18c a litre. In South Australia the State Government takes 2.51c, the producers get 7.87c and the refiners get 12c. So a little over 31c goes to the Federal Government and the producers get 7.8c. That is what companies such as Santos, that have invested so much in the South Australian economy, so much in the Australian economy, get out of every litre of fuel that is sold in my State. Since March 1983 when the Fraser Government was evicted from office there has been a 56.5 per cent increase in excise on fuel. That amounts to about 10c a litre for super grade petrol, or 45c a gallon, for those who have yet to catch up with the change to litres.

In addition to these increases in excise, there has been a reduction in the fuel freight subsidy, and that affects one particular part of my electorate, that part which was very ably represented by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) before me, and that is Kangaroo Island. The people of Kangaroo Island suffer a distinct disadvantage in terms of their cost structure because they live on an island. They did at one stage benefit from the fuel freight subsidy. But as a result of the Government's changes, a further impost in fuel prices has been placed on them. The Government also at one stage took away the full diesel fuel rebate. That has been restored as a result of strong opposition from the Federal Opposition and strong complaints from the rural community. But it has been restored without any compensation for the period during which that diesel fuel rebate did not cover the full value of the excise.

On top of that, the import parity price system has obviously led to a very substantial increase in the price of oil as a result of the collapse of the Australian dollar, a collapse for which the Labor Government holds total responsibility. Now, on top of these things, a further impost has been added to the fuel bills of the consumers of Australia. I do not need to remind honourable members that it is the rural communities above all which will be most disadvantaged by this legislation and by the whole ambit of legislation which is forcing up the price of fuel in this country.

I believe that the House would do the Australian community justice by rejecting this Bill and taking additional measures to deregulate the oil industry in Australia and free up the oil market as much as it possibly can. That is the way, in the longer term, we will keep fuel costs to their bare minimum in this country. It is the way we will be able to help small business and it is the way we will be able to help primary producers during very difficult circumstances.

The Labor Party's alternative, which is spelt out so clearly in this piece of legislation, brings with it high prices for fuel and, in this instance, a rather curious increase in the level of trade protection-an increase in tariffs on fuel imports. The Labour Party alternative also includes a commitment in its policy to nationalise the oil industry. It is well known throughout the industry that the Federal Department of Resources and Energy is already considering the various functions that could be handed over to a hydrocarbon corporation. These are the things to which the Labor Party is committed.

Although this piece of legislation is regarded by so many people as a minor piece of legislation, it is symbolic of the commitment of this Government to the regulation of the oil industry, the pressure it has been placing on oil and fuel prices throughout the community, and the clear effect that that is having on the competitiveness of the Australian economy and the livelihoods of so many of our small business and rural wealth creators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Australian Labor Party's policy platform are words stating that that Party supports the socialisation of the means of production, distribution and exchange. As was pointed out so eloquently by my colleague and friend the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who has just spoken, the Customs Tariff (Stand-By Duty) Bill does nothing to promote the deregulation of the fuel industry. What the people of Australia demand are lower fuel prices. We all remember that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in 1983 claimed that the price of fuel would be reduced by 3c a litre. He was prepared to promise anything to crawl into office. His policy speech was ignored in this respect immediately upon the Government's election.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government originally introduced similar legislation in the 1984 autumn sitting. That Bill was to impose, under certain circumstances, a special stand-by duty on imports of certain light oils. For various reasons, that legislation was allowed to lapse and the Bill before the House tonight is supposedly a result of the Government's reconsideration of the crude oil marketing review. The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) has claimed that this Bill reflects the Government's determination that crude oil produced in Australia will, where possible, be refined in Australia. My colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) has pointed out in very clear and unequivocal terms that this Bill is an attempt by the Government to increase further its control over oil production in Australia. It will allow the Government to dictate the source and the amount of crude oil refiners must use. This Bill will impose a special duty of 3c per litre, or approximately $5 per barrel, on imports of light crude oils and petroleum products by local oil refineries which do not pick up their allocation of Australian crude oil. In other words, there will be more government control over the fuel industry.

The Bill will give the Government the power to maintain its revenue from the crude oil levy. It is the position of the National Party of Australia and of so many people who reside in my electorate of Fisher that it is totally wrong for a government to balance its budget by the use of a fuel tax. Governments, like others, must live within their means. It is totally unacceptable that the Government is prepared to slug the people of Australia an ever-increasing amount of money for the purpose of trying to offset the over-spending we have seen this Government since it was elected on that fateful day in March 1983.

As I stated previously, the National Party and, indeed, our coalition partners, the Liberal Party of Australia, are totally opposed to increased regulation of the oil industry. The National Party will vote against this Bill and makes no apology to the Government and no apology to the Parliament for doing so. We are prepared to say to the people of Australia, the citizens of this country, that we will not tolerate the continuing actions of this Government to charge ever increasing prices for fuel.
Our dollar has collapsed under the policies of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —A disaster.

—As the honourable member for Dawson has quite correctly pointed out, it is a disaster. But it is more than a disaster. It is a reflection of the international community's decision on the economic performance of the socialist Government presently operating in this capital of Canberra. It is in fact a recognition that we as a country have not performed well under Labor. It is a total international condemnation of the policies of this Government.
—Quite correct.

—Quite correct, as the honourable member for Hinkler has said in his usual perceptive manner. I know that the people in his electorate are very appreciative of his very many excellent contributions to this House. However, as the honourable member for Dawson has stated, the legislation is contrary to the spirit of the voluntary association arrangements and contrary to other measures to deregulate the crude oil market. As we know, longer term imports were permitted in the 1985-86 Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We in the National Party and the Opposition will move towards deregulation of the oil industry. We will allow the operation of free market forces to permit crude oil production and prices to reflect true world market conditions. We do not believe that the Government should impose ever higher duties on fuel. We believe that people ought to be entitled to receive a product at the cost of production plus reasonable profit. We do not apologise for this. We in fact make no apology whatsoever for opposing the Labor Government's approach.

SPEECH.PARA: It is incredible that this year fuel prices are rising at a time of world oil surpluses. Countries cannot get rid of their fuel. Prices have been tumbling and yet we in Australia are paying more and more for fuel. The consumers have simply had enough. What has happened to the Prime Minister's promises of fuel price reductions? What would have happened if he had said in 1983 that he would simply stabilise the price of fuel? He claimed he was going to drop the price by 3c a litre. It has gone up by 10c a litre or more than 45c a gallon over 30 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like interst rates.

—Yes. We know the baseless promises made by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister in that area. The home owners of Australia know how they were defrauded by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister and those incorrect statements relating to interest rates.
—Particularly in South Australia.

—Particularly in South Australia, but also in Queensland. The people of South Australia will have the opportunity to elect a National-Liberal Party government after the State elections to be held very shortly when Mr Bannon will be thrown onto the political scrap-heap. I am pleased that the proceedings of the House are being broadcast because the people of South Australia and, indeed, the people of the whole of the country must know what this Government has done to the fuel prices and the economy. They must know what the South Australian Government has done and they should be given the opportunity to vote both the South Australian and Federal Labor governments out of office as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: In the electorate of Fisher I have received deputations and inquiries from numerous constituents from varied backgrounds in connection with fuel prices. There is a great concern abroad in the community. People from all walks of life are worried. Every time they drive past a service station they find that the price of fuel has gone up. Of course, in Queensland, which is the only State not to have a State fuel tax, the prices are not so high as in other places. That is because we have a very good National Party Government in Queensland. But across Australia people are worried over the way in which prices continually increase. Our citizens do not require special treatment. What they want is simply a fair go.

This Government, Mr Speaker-and I welcome you back to the chair-is not concerned about high fuel prices. This Government has failed to reduce the price of fuel in line with the recent drop in the value of the United States dollar compared with the Australian dollar. When the comparative value is unfavourable, the consumer faces an increase; yet when the reverse occurs, the consumer is simply ignored and the reduction the consumer is entitled to simply does not come through. The Labor Government of this country is simply happy to pocket the increased revenue. It is important for people to realise that this Government is in effect acting like a robber and a thief. It is depriving them of money. It is continuing to do so and it will not do what it should in connection with fuel prices.

The Government has admitted through the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, that it is prepared to grab the increased revenue. Senator Evans, in referring to the consequences for Australia of a major oil price drop, said:
There are a number of negatives. First, in the short term, there would be a major decline in government revenue which would either blow out the deficit or force new or increased taxation elsewhere.

What about restraint? What about cutting the size of government? What about a reduction in spending? The Government is not interested in that. All it wants to do is to take more and more from the taxpayers of Australia. In a Press release of 23 October, I stated:
I believe it is high time for the Government to stop its dependence on fuel tax as a source of revenue.
If Labor wished to reduce the fuel cost burden it should bite the fuel tax bullet and slash prices.

Under this Bill the Government is seeking to impose restrictions on refiners obtaining crude oil from overseas. It is concerned with gaining as much income from crude oil as it can. That is yet another revenue grabbing venture. Despite the fact that revenue has increased due to an increase in production and depreciation induced price increases, the Government is continuing with that course of action. Government taxes comprise 60 per cent of the price of fuel. Honourable members may have seen and no doubt will continue to see signs pointing out that petrol costs 20c a litre plus a fuel tax of 30c a litre or more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten thousand million dollars a year.

—The sum of $10,000m is apparently what the Government is taking from the people of Australia, as the honourable member for Lyne has pointed out to this House. Primary producers and rural and urban dwellers depending on private transport are being hampered by this cost burden. Australian fuel users should be allowed to gain the benefit from cheaper oil prices.

SPEECH.PARA: We must allow a free market to exist. It is important to deregulate. It is essential to oppose the continual money grabbing approach of this Government. This Bill prevents lower fuel prices. This Bill ignores the demands of the taxpayers of Australia. This Bill continues to slug our citizens, and the Opposition will not under any circumstances support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I want to reply to the contribution made by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite).
—A good contribution.

—That may appear so. I shall refer also to the contributions of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). The honourable member for Dawson commented that the aim of the Customs tariff legislation was to generate extra revenue. The main point about this measure is that it is an integral part of the crude oil allocation scheme. That scheme has the prime aim of encouraging exploration and the development of indigenous crude oil.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dawson commented that there was industry opposition to the partial allocation scheme. That issue was considered in May-June this year as part of the review of crude oil marketing arrangements. Some producers and refiners opposed and others supported a continuation of the scheme. As the honourable member for Mayo conceded later in his speech, whatever opposition there was was not very passionate. At that time the concept of a stand-by duty was well understood by all in the industry. The honourable member for Dawson also said that independents were not included. It is not practicable to make them subject to the duty when they are not participants in the scheme. However, the Government has said that it will keep their position under review and that they will be included if the level of imports becomes significant.

The honourable member for Mayo said that the legislation really constituted only minor amendments. That is not correct. The Bill has been totally redrafted to change its basis from applicability across the whole industry to applicability to individual companies. The honourable member commented that the industry was not able to get its best price. That is wrong. The combination of import parity pricing and the allocation scheme has been to guarantee a market for indigenous production at a world-related price. The honourable member said that there was industry opposition, although he conceded that it was not all that passionate. It is true that there was strong opposition to the earlier Bill. However, those views have been taken into account and there has been very little opposition-

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not know whether there has been opposition because you did not consult them.

—Of course there is a constant process of consultation, as there was a constant process of review. We take the business of consultation almost, one would think, to the point of obsession at times. That is one accusation that cannot be properly levelled against this Government. The honourable member for Fisher made his customary passionate defence of the free market, but he is lamentably ill-informed. Let me say something about his constant appeal to the need to reduce price. Its needs to be pointed out that in Australia we still have one of the cheapest fuel prices of member countries of the Organsiation for Economic Co-operation and Development. I have repeated again and again-but honourable members opposite will not learn the lesson-that in April, of all the OECD countries, we had the lowest fuel price at the petrol pump, although in metropolitan areas, I concede. Our price was below that of the United States and Canada. It is true that the Australian price now is higher than that of the United States and Canada, but only a relatively few cents.

SPEECH.PARA: The price of Bass Strait crude has fallen five times since this Government came to office. When we came to government in 1983 the Bass Strait price for crude oil per barrel was $36.90. It decreased in July to $36.53, in January 1984 to $34.68 and in July 1984 there was a small increase. Considering the degree of inflation and considered on an index basis, we have maintained the price extremely well. I make the following contribution for the benefit of the honourable member for Fisher. When we had the Secretary-General of the OECD, Mr Jean-Claude Paye, with us a month or two ago he expressed great concern-I think all who heard him were impressed by what he said-that there would be a collapse of fuel prices in the Western world. He commended all efforts to maintain price stability, even if in the short term they were unpopular domestically.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the taxpayers?

—Listen to what I am saying and to what Mr Paye is saying, someone with a somewhat broader grasp of world economics than even the honourable member for Fisher. Monsieur Paye's concern was that a fuel price collapse generally would lead to a dramatic fall in oil exploration because, as is recognised, there is something like a glut situation now, but that glut might very well turn into a dearth if there is a significant fall in oil exploration. If there is then a collapse in supply the next swing of the pendulum might bring about a very sharp increase in fuel pricing along the lines of the celebrated oil shock of 1973-74, resulting in a period of profound instability, not just in the world fuel price but in the world economy generally.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one would ever accuse the honourable member for Fisher of taking the long view. He appeals constantly to the parish pump-in this case the petrol pump. What the Government has done has been completely responsible and deserves the strong support not only of the House but of the community as a whole. Opposition members should go back and tell this to their constituents. They should ask themselves whether when they are discussing fuel prices in Australia they point out where we stand in world terms, or whether they just take the line: `There you are, Canberra is slugging you again'. But if they have a responsible attitude towards their constituents, they should be given both sides of the story.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I know that it is a refreshing novelty for the honourable member for Barker, but it is about time that we did it. If one is to bring about the situation of which Monsieur Paye was talking, where there would be a drying up--
—Pie in the sky.

—That is an assinine comment even from the honourable member. Of course, it is a significant amount. We are saying that it is an attempt to maintain price stability, and in world terms we have stood up extremely well. The Opposition is conscious of the reason why it was brought in. Of course it is a source of revenue, but it is also a method of maintaining the price at a rational and reasonable level-a price that in world terms, taken throughout the OECD, stands up extremely well. I think the record of the Government in this matter is excellent, and I ask the House to give strong support to this Bill.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
